mods:titleInfo.mods:title: How to Be Unmothered
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Trini Memoir

mods:mods.mods:abstract: I am a Trinidadian woman with a long maternal line. A legacy of mothers who does leave. Women who does conceive and abandon all they child. At 13 years old, after my mother took a one-way flight, I read Annie John say to her mother, 'I wish you were dead'. This to the mother who enmeshed then rejected her, from whom Annie in self-preservation fled. And, in Kincaid's semi-autobiographical novel, I finally found someone who told the truth. My truth. Of my abusive mother. The one relegated to my head. The maltreatment that had to go unsaid. Because Caribbean realities, like Caribbean families, live behind gauzy, white curtains. There is no ugliness. None is allowed to escape. We save face. Our social conduct is hinged on secrecy, on never bringing shame. And too few rent the veil. But I am a storm. I do not comply with the norm of Caribbean writers, sometimes complicit, hiding behind fiction and not apprising the world. Caribbean writers concealing the domestic and societal abusive ills visited upon our girls. Understandably. To an extent. Since, trust me, I get deep trauma isn't easy to face. J. Brooks Bouson argues that Kincaid is still bound to her shame. That her endless repetition evinces her inability to confront and work through the past. And much the same some say of Roxane Gay who, after nearly thirty years, has confessed to her Haitian parents and is writing of her gang rape and defensive weight gain at last. But I pen memoir and reveal our ugly truths. Exposing such is my responsibility. And not since Annie John has a Caribbean work of literature showcased an evil mother as my collection of essays do. I am writing to that 13-year-old little girl who needed someone to say it's not just you. How To Be Unmothered's narrative begins with me at nine years old when, for once, I'm not guarding my mother from my father knocking her out cold. In revenge, my mother sends me down the drugs and rape-laden Covigne Road. Then, deserted at 13 when my mother secretly leaves, I begin tracing my un-mothering lineage across five generations. All the mothers in my maternal family line abandon their children. I link this tendency to my mother, Smiley, who has incestuous affairs. She bites and fights in-laws before running away from Trinidad, leaving me ill and neglected for years. Till I am 19 and execute a dangerous escape from my father who nearly kills my younger sisters and I one night. Desperate for safety and reunion with our mother in Brooklyn, we take flight. But a woman who does abuse is never a refuge. The soucouyant unmother in another country is just the same. Thus, alone, eyes blown wide open, without my mother-loving sisters, I head for JFK. In this text, I reflect on the multi-faceted cruelties of this mother who subjects all her daughters to neglect. And I ponder, what if abandonment is good luck from a mother who turns out to be worse? A mother who can cause more harm than a father using his fists to make it hurt. My memoir charts dawning realisation, without which I would still be my mother's victim. Narrated in poetic prose and the rhythmic patois of Trinidad and Tobago, HOW TO BE UNMOTHERED explores Caribbean history from pre-colonialism to the contemporary. It invokes cinematic scenes of aquamarine seas and the islands' lush greenery. It journeys from Trinidad to Grenada, England and Canada, to New York City. It provokes questions about the chokehold of African spirituality. And reveals the role of choice in determining multi-generational legacy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
abandonment, Caribbean, domestic abuse, memoir, mother, Trinidad
Elizabeth Stuckey-French, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lisa Wakamiya, University Representative; Ravi Howard, Committee Member; Susan C. Ward, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Examining Ethnoracial Status as a Predictor of Changes in Body Mass Index and Eating Pathology over 20-Year Follow-Up

mods:mods.mods:abstract: While eating disorders were historically considered to be mental illnesses primarily affecting White women, it is now understood that eating disorders occur across all racial and ethnic groups. Prior research demonstrates that Body Mass Index (BMI) differs across certain racial and ethnic groups and that elevated BMI is a well-established risk factor for eating disorders and pathology. Presently, there are mixed results as to whether eating pathology differs across racial and ethnic groups. The current study examined ethnoracial status and its intersection with gender as a predictor of levels and changes in BMI, Eating Disorder Inventory (EDI) Bulimia scores, and EDI Drive for Thinness scores over a 20-year follow-up period in a longitudinal survey-based study of health and eating patterns. The current study used data from cohorts of university students established in 1982 and 1992 respectively, who provided survey responses at baseline (n=1415; 71% female) and then were sought for additional survey responses at 10- and 20-year follow-up. At baseline, the ethnoracial breakdown was 74.3% Non-Hispanic White, 13.2% Non-Hispanic Asian, 6.4% Non-Hispanic Black/African American, and 6% Hispanic White. Multilevel models indicated that Non-Hispanic Black/African American and Hispanic White ethnoracial groups demonstrated greater increases in BMI over time compared to Non-Hispanic White and Non-Hispanic Asian ethnoracial groups. With regard to eating pathology, both EDI Bulimia and Drive for Thinness scores were comparable across ethnoracial groups in college. Trajectories for Drive for Thinness were also comparable across ethnoracial groups. Conversely, ethnoracial status was a predictor of differing trajectories of EDI Bulimia among women, such that Non-Hispanic Black/African American women's Bulimia scores demonstrated significantly less decline over time compared to Non-Hispanic White and Non-Hispanic Asian women's scores. Given that BMI did not moderate the effect of ethnoracial status X time on EDI Bulimia scores, future studies should consider other factors beyond BMI that might explain ethnoracial differences in bulimia pathology trajectory, including minority stress.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Body Mass Index, Eating disorders, Eating pathology, Ethnicity, Gender, Race
Pamela Keel, Professor Directing Thesis; Thomas Joiner, Committee Member; Chris Schatschneider, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Kindergarten Teachers' Adoption and Experiences during Covid-19 Distance Learning in the UAE

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on education, with the sudden shift to distance learning and the closure of K-12 classrooms worldwide. Kindergarten teachers faced unique challenges in adapting to this new mode of instruction as young children required hands-on learning experiences, social interaction, and immediate feedback. Despite these challenges, limited research existed on how kindergarten teachers adapted to the changes in the learning process during the pandemic. This study used a convergent parallel mixed methods design to gain a better understanding of kindergarten teachers' adoption, perceptions, and preparations as they transitioned to distance learning. Data was collected using an online survey from 255 kindergarten teachers in public schools in the United Arab Emirates (UAE), who taught online classes between March 2020 and December 2021. Quantitative and qualitative data were collected at the same time and then separately analyzed and triangulated to provide a better understanding of the topic. Regression analysis revealed that teachers' beliefs regarding the appropriateness and effectiveness of distance learning, perceived effectiveness of professional development, and parental involvement significantly influenced their confidence levels in implementing distance learning. The thematic analysis of the open-ended questions revealed insights into kindergarten teachers' successes, challenges, reflections, and recommendations for improving the use distance learning in kindergarten the future.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
distance learning, Kindergarten teachers, kindergarten teachers' adoption, online learning, The COVID-19 pandemic, United Arab Emirates (UAE)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Fault Tolerant Control for Large-Scale Hierarchical Nonlinear Systems with Uncertainty in Parameters and Disturbance

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This document reviews the fault tolerant control (FTC) problems, approaches, and ideas. Chapter one provides the motivation of the need for an FTC, then an overview of the FTC systems and basic terminologies are provided defining faults, fault detection and fault tolerant control systems, then faults are categorized into actuator, sensor, plant, and control input faults. It also discusses the types of fault in the structural point of view, which is additive and multiplicative faults. In chapter 2, the fault diagnosis problem is illustrated. It discusses the design procedure of fault diagnosis including three fault detection, localization, and estimation. The former just checks if a fault happens, while the second step finds the place where a fault occurs, and finally the magnitude of the fault is estimated. Different kinds of methods are discussed depending on having access to the model of the system, system's signal pattern, or knowledge about the system, or exciting the system using an input, and then the idea of fault detection is given for model-based fault diagnosis approach. In chapter 3, the controller part of an FTC is discussed in more details by categorizing it into the passive FTC and active FTC. While the former is designed offline using robust control theory, the latter uses a fault diagnosis along with the controller and it is online. The required terminology for large-scaled system is reviewed in chapter 4 by discussing distributed FTC (model based) and then providing formal definitions for graph theory concepts, and finally two kinds of communication schemes are illustrated for distributed FTC. Then, open problems are discussed in chapter 5. Chapter 6, and 7, provides case studies for an aero-electro-mechanical system, and pure electrical system, respectively. In chapter 6, multiple FTCs are designed for the wind turbine application so that the FTCs mitigate the pitch actuator faults. In chapter 7, FTCs are designed for the application of inverter-based resources. In this chapter, the controller deals with abrupt grid voltage disturbance, and also uncertainty in the transmission line parameters. Finally, chapter 8, provides conclusion and future works.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Adaptive Control, Power Inverter, Robust Control, Wind Turbine
Olugbenga Moses Anubi, Professor Directing Thesis; Victor DeBrunner, Committee Member; Rodney Roberts, Committee Member; Carl Moore, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Novel Statistical Methods to Characterize the Genetic Basis of Human Complex Traits

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A major objective in modern human genetics research is to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying human complex traits. Although genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have been successful in detecting thousands of trait-associated and disease-associated genetic variants (i.e., single‚Äênucleotide polymorphisms [SNPs]), the genes responsible for these associations remain unclear because these SNPs explain only a small proportion of heritability. To characterize the genetic regulations of GWAS variants on traits and diseases, many statistical methods such as transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs) and their extensions have been developed to integrate GWAS results with gene expression data. However, despite successes, existing TWASs suffer from substantial power loss since they miss many important biological contexts within trait or disease pathways. This thesis presents three novel statistical studies that incorporate those contexts leveraging the information of functional elements (e.g., cross-tissue correlation of gene expression and enhancer-promoter interactions) and post-transcriptional events (e.g., alternative splicing and RNA editing) to provide more insights into the underlying genetic landscape and etiology of traits and diseases. In the first chapter, we propose a computationally efficient testing method, referred to as Integrative Test for Associations via Cauchy Transformation (InTACT), that effectively combines information across multiple tissues and thus improves the power of identifying associated genes. Through simulation studies, we show that InTACT maintains high power while properly controlling for Type 1 error rates. We applied InTACT to the largest GWAS of Alzheimer's disease (AD) to date and identified 227 genome-wide significant genes, of which 130 were not identified by benchmark methods, TWAS and MultiXcan. Importantly, InTACT identified five novel loci for AD. We implemented InTACT in publicly available software, "InTACT.'' In the second chapter, we perform a comprehensive splicing transcriptome-wide association study (spTWAS) to identify the susceptible splicing introns for AD risk. A total of 111,326 (46,828 proxy) cases and 677,663 controls of European ancestry were studied. We identified 343 associations of 233 splicing introns (143 genes) with AD risk after Bonferroni correction. Fine-mapping analyses supported 155 likely causal associations corresponding to 83 splicing introns of 55 genes. Eighteen causal splicing introns of 15 novel genes were identified for the first time to be related to AD susceptibility. Our study identified novel genes and splicing introns associated with AD risk, which can improve our understanding of the etiology of AD. In the third chapter, we reveal the impact of genetically regulated adenosine-to-inosine (A-to-I) RNA editing on various traits, by systematically analyzing datasets of A-to-I RNA editing, a post-transcriptional process crucial for adapting innate immune response. We conducted both editing-site- and gene-level association studies of predicting A-to-I RNA editing and testing its associations with the analyzed 37 traits or diseases. Based on our prediction models of 49 tissues, we identified 383-21,098 editing sites and 44-1,338 genes per trait or disease, of which 86.5\% and 79.2\% were validated for causal attributions, respectively. We highlight our findings for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases to characterize the role of A-to-I RNA editing in adjusting the immune sensing system.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Xufeng Niu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Nowakowski, University Representative; Chong Wu, Committee Member; Jonathan Bradley, Committee Member; Fred Huffer, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Perceptions and Antecedents of the Malleability of Prejudice across Targets and Nontargets

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Malleability beliefs have been shown to have wide-ranging effects across several domains of personality. However, malleability beliefs regarding prejudice are quite understudied, and the factors contributing to the formation of these beliefs are unknown. Furthermore, most prejudice research has focused on the perspectives of the perpetrators of prejudice, not the targets themselves. Across two studies we examine malleability beliefs regarding prejudice among both the targets and nontargets of prejudice, with Study 1 examining prejudice directed at Black individuals and Study 2 examining prejudice towards gay individuals. We found a target/nontarget difference in perceptions of the malleability of prejudice between Black and nonBlack individuals in Study 1. This target/nontarget difference, however, did not replicate in Study 2. Across both studies, individuals who perceived nontargets as behaving in a nonprejudiced manner as a result of internal motivations, as opposed to external motivations, believe prejudice to be more malleable. Additionally, the more one believed legislation to be important for achieving equity, the more one believed prejudice to be changeable. Implications regarding the downstream consequences of malleability beliefs and comparisons between perceptions of the target groups studied (Black vs gay) are explored.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
E. Ashby Plant, Professor Directing Thesis; Irmak Olcaysoy Okten, Committee Member; Diana Williams, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Statistical Inferences for Shape Graphs and Time Series of Graphs

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This research provides theoretical and computational developments in statistical shape analysis of shape graphs, and demonstrates them using analysis of complex network-type object data such as retinal blood-vessel (RBV) networks. The shape graphs are represented by a set of nodes and edges (planar articulated curves) connecting some of these nodes. The goals are to utilize shapes of edges and connectivities and locations of nodes to: (1) characterize full shapes, (2) quantify shape differences, and (3) model statistical variability. We develop a mathematical representation, elastic Riemannian shape metrics, and associated tools for such statistical analysis. Specifically, we derive tools for shape graph registration, geodesics, statistical summaries, shape modeling, and new data generation. Geodesics are convenient for visualizing optimal deformations, and PCA helps in dimension reduction and statistical modeling. One key challenge here is comparisons of shape graphs with vastly different complexities (in number of nodes and edges). This work introduces a novel multi-scale representation of shape graphs to handle this challenge. Using the notions of (1) "effective resistance" to cluster nodes and (2) elastic shape averaging of edge curves, one can reduce shape graph complexity while maintaining overall structures. This way, we can compare shape graphs by bringing them to similar complexity. We demonstrate these ideas on 2D Retinal Blood Vessel (RBV) networks taken from the STARE and DRIVE databases and 3D Neuron networks from the NeuroMorpho database. Graph-based representations are becoming increasingly popular for representing and analyzing video data, especially in object tracking and scene understanding applications. Accordingly, an essential tool in this approach is to generate statistical inferences for graphical time series associated with videos. This research develops a Kalman-smoothing method for estimating graphs from noisy, cluttered, and incomplete data. The main challenge here is to find and preserve the registration of nodes (salient detected objects) across time frames when the data has noise and clutter due to false and missing nodes. First, we introduce a quotient-space representation of graphs that incorporates temporal registration of nodes, and we use that metric structure to impose a dynamical model on graph evolution. Then, we derive a Kalman smoother, adapted to the quotient space geometry, to estimate dense, smooth trajectories of graphs. We demonstrate this framework using simulated data and actual video graphs extracted from the Multiview Extended Video with Activities (MEVA) dataset. This framework successfully estimates graphs despite the noise, clutter, and missed detections.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
geodesic deformations, Kalman smoothing, motion tracking, nonlinear manifolds, shape graphs, statistical shape analysis
Anuj Srivastava, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric Klassen, University Representative; Fred Huffer, Committee Member; Wei Wu, Committee Member; Thomas Needham, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Female Student-Athlete Leadership, Mentorship, and the Transition to the Post-Collegiate Labor Force

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This past year (2022) marked the 50th Anniversary of Title IX of the 1972 Education Amendments, which prohibits sex-based discrimination in any school or any other education program that receives federal funding (Hextrum and Sethi, 2022). This federal anti-discrimination law has had a particular impact on sport, directly leading to an increased amount of participation in sport by girls and women, thus showcasing much talent from female athletes. Since the enactment of Title IX, women have come a long way in sport, however, there is progress still left to be witnessed for women (Acosta and Carpenter, 2009). Female athletes are gaining attention not just from fans and marketers, but venture capitalists are pouring their financial efforts into women's sports (Strauss and Hensley-Clancy, 2021). Given the heightened focus on female athletes especially-whether in media coverage, endorsements (for professionals) or Name-Image-Likeness (NIL; for collegiate) sponsorships, discourses of empowerment, and the promotion of women as leaders in the workforce more generally- it is critical to explore the preparation and development of leadership skills that female student-athletes are receiving during their collegiate career. There is a general acknowledgement in the literature on leadership concerning an underrepresentation of women in leadership positions, globally (Evans and Pfister, 2021). It is important to understand what female student-athletes' needs and desires are while still in college and how a university can invest in women to meet these needs through resource accessibility. Investigating at the collegiate level is imperative because education and opportunities available for the development of essential leadership skills can begin earlier for female student-athletes before they reach the workforce. This could potentially increase the number of women set to take on leadership positions in the industry of sport. As such, in this dissertation the focus is to understand current and former DI female student-athletes' perspectives on leadership development, mentorship opportunities, and preparation for the post-collegiate labor force. This study encompassed five research questions: RQ1: What are the perceived professional needs of current DI female student-athletes which could allow for the attainment of success in leadership roles in the workforce? RQ2: What are the professional needs identified from former DI female student-athletes which could equip current student-athletes allowing for the attainment of success in leadership roles in the workforce? RQ3: How do DI female student-athletes experience types of leadership and mentorship opportunities at the university level? RQ4: What types of leadership and mentorship opportunities do DI female student-athletes seek to obtain? RQ5: What types of leadership/mentorship experiences do former DI female student-athletes believe would help a current female student-athlete prepare for the workforce? Using thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), I identified themes from interviews of both current and former DI female student-athletes concerning their experiences with leadership training, mentorship they received, and preparation for the post-collegiate labor force. Key findings and summarized themes involve mentorship, student-development, communication, community, and leadership skills development. The need to focus on effective communication skill development was highlighted throughout this study. Participants explained the importance of entailing communication skills to be of significance for a leader to possess. Communication skills were also understood to be of importance to assist others in need, as well as function effectively in the workforce. Potential implications and recommendations for future research are identified that involve specific direction of leadership development and mentorship to be offered at the collegiate level to ensure effective preparation is present for DI female student-athletes concerning the post-collegiate labor force.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sport Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Controlling the Activation Threshold of Innate Immunity
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Regulation of cGAS and GBP2

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The innate immune system acts as the first line of defense against invading pathogens throughrecognition of pathogen associated molecular patterns or danger associated molecular patterns. Several germline encoded receptors, known as the pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) can specifically recognize molecules that are exclusively associated with the pathogens that include structural elements like lipopeptides, peptidoglycans, lipopolysaccharides, flagellins, mannose, fucose and glucan carbohydrate or genetic material like deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) or ribonucleic acid (RNA). These PRRs trigger the activation of NF-Œ∫B, type I interferons (IFN), inflammatory pathways and cell death pathways that help to eliminate the pathogen without any self-harm. Prevention of self-harm is very crucial and hence it is essential that the PRRs should be able to distinguish infectious non-self from harmless self-molecules and then decide whether it is worth taking any action. A part of this recognition strategy depends on the fact that PRRs can recognize only those molecules (specially the structural elements associated with the pathogens) that are exclusively present in pathogens, necessary for their survival and are absent/suppressed in host. Although the pathogen nucleic acids may sometimes have exclusive patterns, the overall structure and sequences do not vary much between the host and the microbes and hence pathogen recognition through nucleic acid sensing is tricky. In the case of nucleic acids, besides structural differences, cellular localization, and concentration are also important factors that guide the PRRs to distinguish between self and non-self. Since recognition is the first step of innate immune activation, most pathogens try to evade the PRR mediated activation of innate immune responses by negatively regulating the recognition step. The pathogens have evolved various mechanisms to avoid being detected by the PRRs, especially the nucleic acid sensors. The pathogens either hide their genetic material or directly target the PRRs to avoid recognition. The second chapter of this dissertation reports the molecular mechanism by which dengue virus (DENV) suppresses the induction of type I interferons by antagonizing cGAS-STING signaling. Using recombinant proteins and in vitro cleavage assays, we have shown that the DENV protease NS2B3 is capable of cleaving cGAS in the N-terminal region without disrupting the C-terminal catalytic center. This generates two major cleavage products: cleavage product N-terminal (CP-N) and cleavage product C-terminal(CP-C). We observed a reduction in DNA-binding affinity of CP-C as compared to full-length cGAS. Reduction in DNA-binding affinity is also correlated with the decrease in enzymatic activity of CP-C. CP-N, on the other hand, has almost comparable DNA-binding ability as that of the full-length cGAS. In fact, CP-N competitively inhibits cyclic GMP-AMP production by both full-length cGAS and CP-C. We hypothesize that high DNA-binding affinity of CP-N enables it to sequester the DNA from CP-C and noncleaved full-length cGAS and thus reduces the rate of enzyme activation and cyclic GMP-AMP synthesis. Furthermore, we found that NS2B3 physically interacts with full-length cGAS and CP-C, laying the basis for their shuttling to and eventual degradation in the autophagosome. Overall, our study highlights a multifaceted and effective strategy by which an RNA virus antagonizes cGAS-STING signaling which may be useful for the design of antivirals targeting viral proteases. The third chapter of the dissertation reports how an IFN-inducible GTPase, the guanylate binding protein 2 (GBP2) controls its own activation threshold by intrinsic structural rearrangements. Biochemical and enzymatic characterization of recombinant GBP2 led us to understand how nucleotide dependent oligomerization and GTPase activity of GBP2 are controlled by an interaction between the catalytic domain (GD) at the N-terminus and the helix ‚ç∫12 at the C-terminus. Structure guided mutagenesis led us to identify E554 and E561 as the key residues responsible for stabilizing this GD-‚ç∫12 interaction. Structural analysis of GBP2 by small angle X-ray scattering helped us to confirm that in absence of GD-‚ç∫12 interaction, GBP2 assumes a flexible conformation that facilitates its dimer formation and GTPase activity. GD- ‚ç∫12 interaction imparts a structural rigidity in GBP2 that raises the activation threshold for its enzymatic activity. Overall, our study shows how intrinsic structural changes can control the activation of an innate immune protein. This also highlights how the host keeps a check on activation of immune responses. GBPs are usually expressed at basal level in immune and nonimmune cells, and it is necessary to control their actions in absence of infections. Since dysregulated or exaggerated immune response may lead to pathological inflammation and autoimmune diseases, it is necessary to restrict the signals at an optimal level that is sufficient to fight off the invader but is not cytotoxic.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Program in Molecular Biophysics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Anti-Slavery War on Evangelicalism
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Critical Interrogation of Abolitionism, Evangelicalism, and Apocalypticism

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation examines the dynamic relationship between apocalypticism and social reform as manifested within the abolitionist movement in antebellum America. A prevalent argument contends that during the nineteenth century a liberal postmillennialism made the evangelical majority a dominant force in social justice causes, such as anti-slavery. This liberal socio-political character supposedly defined evangelicalism until it was coopted by a pessimistically conservative premillennialism that drew the collective away from social reform. This "Great Reversal" narrative is supported by a theorized dichotomy between premillennialism and postmillennialism that pervades the academic discourse. The Adventists (also known as Millerites) have provided some of the strongest evidence scholars have used to craft and perpetuate the premillennial-postmillennial binary that informs a wide body of scholarship. However, I argue in this dissertation that the Adventists have been misrepresented as ex-abolitionists. During the 1830s and 1840s, Adventism was primarily disseminated through abolitionist networks. Though the long anti-slavery schism disrupted former associations, the Adventists remained active within the movement and made many contributions to the cause as new tactics for combating slavery and "Jim Crow" emerged. While the Adventists were activated by their immediate premillennialism the evangelical majority used their gradual postmillennialism to either abstain from anti-slavery activism or remain anti-abolitionists. For this reason, the Adventists joined other apocalyptic abolitionists in launching a non-violent war on evangelicalism and came out of "Babylon" in a mass exodus once they realized that the evangelical churches could not be reformed. This history challenges binary socio-political understandings of apocalypticism and exposes the fictitious nature of the "Great Reversal" theory by demonstrating that the evangelical majority has always been conservative.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Religion in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Abolitionism, Adventism, Anti-Slavery, Apocalypticism, Evangelicalism, Social Reform
John Corrigan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Guenter Kurt Piehler, University Representative; Michael J. McVicar, Committee Member; Sonia Hazard, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Music Therapist Perspectives on Working with Clients Who Have Experienced Spiritual Abuse and or Trauma

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study is to collect information from board-certified music therapists regarding their experiences working with clients who have suffered from Spiritual Abuse (SA) and or trauma. Based on the perspective of music therapists, this study examines the prevalence and efficacy of spiritual abuse interventions for clients. A survey was conducted and sent to 9,829 board-certified music therapists by email using an anonymous link to the survey. The survey was open for responses for three weeks. The survey found 64% (n = 177) of participants have worked with clients who have experienced SA and or trauma. Ninety-three percent (n = 251) of participants agreed that religion plays a role in client identity after counseling. Findings concluded that lyric analysis, songwriting, improvisation and music for relaxation were the most effective interventions based on the opinions and experiences of the participants.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
Flor Del Cielo Hernandez, Professor Directing Thesis; Jayne Standley, Committee Member; Sarah D. Gregory, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Improving Teaching Quality
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Assessing Teacher Candidates' Professional Dispositions

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The objective for all three phases of this study was to make improvements to an existing measure, the Dispositional Evaluation Rubric (DER), and then establish reliability and validity of the measure, which will support schools and teacher preparation programs in measuring teacher candidates' professional dispositions. This study was designed to utilize a mixed-methods approach, employing qualitative survey results, as well as a quantitative correlational and dimensionality analyses. Potentially, this instrument could contribute to the enhancement of teaching evaluation systems and teaching effectiveness, ideally for both pre-service and in-service teachers. The findings in this study underscore the significance of the need for the development and utilization of effective rating instruments for teacher candidates' and teachers' professional dispositions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Amy R. Guerette, Professor Directing Dissertation; Patrice Iatarola, University Representative; Elizabeth Jakubowski, Committee Member; Sandra Lewis, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding the Use of Therapeutic Techniques within Medical Music Therapy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The goals of this study were to examine the frequency at which medical music therapists use counseling skills in their daily practice, as well as their comfort level implementing these techniques relating to their clinical training. Participants (N=193) for this study were board-certified music therapists (MT-BCs) in the United States recruited through an email list purchased by the researcher from the Certification Board for Music Therapists (CBMT). The survey sent out contained 16 multiple choice, free response, or rating questions. The results of this study revealed that MT-BCs working within a medical setting often implement counseling techniques and interventions to address the emotional needs and mental well-being of their patients. Additionally, participants reported a need for enhanced clinical training relating to counseling practice prior to beginning their clinical internship. Multiple responses indicated that there is a strong desire towards better training with the technique of verbal processing. Findings of this study may be a resource for music therapy training programs and educators to incorporate greater emphasis on counseling techniques and their implementation within sessions. Moreover, the results may be useful for practicing music therapists to guide their professional development. Further results and implications are discussed more extensively in this paper.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Music Therapy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
Flor del Cielo Hernandez, Professor Directing Thesis; Jayne M. Standley, Committee Member; Dawn Iwamasa, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Type Ia Supernovae
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Progenitor Properties and Host Galaxies via Light Curves

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are rather homogeneous astrophysical objects and can be used as cosmological distance ladders. Despite that, significant diversity among SNe Ia luminosity (by a factor of ~ 10) and spectral properties have been studied in the past thirty years, and higher precision is needed for modern-day cosmology. This thesis presents the analysis of the visual light curves (LCs) of Type Ia Supernovae (SNe Ia) using an eigenfunction method. The observed LCs used in this work were obtained by the Carnegie Supernova Project (CSP). This method, using our Secondary Parameter Analysis Tool, or SPAT, investigates the diversity of SNe Ia, as needed for high-precision cosmology. With the variation of progenitor parameters in explosion models, characteristic variations of LC are seen. Our eigenfunctions are based on these variations, and describe the differences in the observed monochromatic LCs. Therefore, this method links the SNe Ia LC with their progenitor and explosion mechanism. The analysis is constructed within the framework of the Chandrasekhar mass (MCh) explosion, and delayed detonation (DD) scenario. In this scenario, the amount of deflagration burning governs the brightness decline rate ([Delta]m15) or equivalently, the LC stretch parameter (s). The initial central density [rho]c of the white dwarf (WD) and the main sequence mass MMS have been identified as secondary parameters, allowing the reproduction of the observations within ‚âÖ 1%, corresponding to diversity in peak-brightness from ‚âÖ 0.1 magnitude based on s alone to about 0.01 magnitude. This work shows the importance of having LC data up to 60 days after the maximum light. Subgroups among SNe Ia (e.g. 91T - the potential first generation of stars observable with JWST, or 99aa-likes) can be identified using this method. Other "outlier" subgroups such as 03fg-likes or 02cx-likes can be filtered out to avoid pollution of SNe Ia samples used for cosmology. The distribution of MMS and [rho]c are shown and properties of host galaxies of the SNe Ia have been related to them. Clear evidence for two distinct groups of MMS has been found, corresponding to a fast ‚âÖ 65 Myrs and a slow (‚âÖ 200 Myrs) stellar evolution time. Most under-luminous SNe Ia in the sample have hosts with low star formation but high MMS, suggesting long evolution times of the progenitor system. As possible evidence for two distinct groups, a few of the transitional SNe Ia in the sample show low [rho]c but those are in galaxies with active star formation. The method of this analysis and results have been discussed within the framework of multiple explosion scenarios, and in light of upcoming surveys.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
91T-like, central density, host galaxy, main sequence mass, spherical delayed detonation, Type Ia supernovae
Peter Hoeflich, Professor Directing Dissertation; Wei Yang, University Representative; Yi Chi Eric Hsiao, Committee Member; Jeremiah Murphy, Committee Member; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: How and When Do Girls and Boys Become Segregated into Different Stem Career Paths?
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Testing the Relationships among Gender, Academic Achievement, Motivational and Cultural Factors, and Career Aspirations

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this dissertation study, I aimed to 1) investigate gender patterns in students' career aspirations, in both STEM and non-STEM fields, and 2) identify factors contributing to persistent gender differences within specific STEM disciplines. Drawing on Gottfredson's (date) model of circumscription and compromise, I examined gender patterns and shifts in students' career aspirations. Additionally, Eccles's expectancy-value theory (date) was adopted to examine the influence of achievement and motivational factors, particularly in mathematics and science, on gender differences in STEM-related career aspirations. Specifically, I investigated the relationships among students' math and science achievements, attainment values of math and science tasks, and students' STEM-related career aspirations. Furthermore, I explored the role of cultural beliefs, primarily gender stereotypes, in shaping math and science motivations of girls and boys, potentially leading to distinct pathways in STEM careers. I used data from the High School Longitudinal Study of 2009 (HSLS:09) to examine gender patterns in students' career aspirations and to analyze the relationships among gender, academic achievement, motivational factors, and career aspirations. The results revealed significant gender disparities in STEM career aspirations, with boys expressing a preference for career fields of physical science, engineering, mathematics, and computer science, while girls expressed a preference for fields of social, life, and health sciences. The results also highlighted the complexity of students' career development. For example, the results emphasized the importance of students' mathematics and science motivations, particularly attainment values, in mediating between their past academic achievement and STEM-related career aspirations. Furthermore, I found that students' endorsement of socio-cultural beliefs such as gender-ability stereotypes in math and science moderated the relationship between students' prior academic achievement and attainment values of math and science tasks. I discuss implications regarding the research findings.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Jeannine E. Turner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lara Perez-Felkner, University Representative; Yanyun Yang, Committee Member; Sherry Southerland, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Formal and Dramatic Implications of Reprise in Two Musicals by Jeanine Tesori

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Reprise is a key element of Broadway musicals. In this dissertation, I analyze reprise in two musicals by Jeanine Tesori‚ÄîFun Home (2015) and Shrek the Musical (2008)‚Äîbecause their use of motives, themes, and songs complicates the general notion of reprise. Generally, reprise can be understood as the performed return of a song within a show. However, I posit that reprise can be understood more broadly as the re-presentation of some coherent and identifiable musical element. A musical element could be a song, melody, phrase, or motive. In broadening the concept of reprise in Broadway musicals through formal and dramatic features, the goal of this dissertation is to construe reprise as a way in which an earlier dramatic context informs the meaning and significance of a later one. Because the concept of reprise entails the existence of two musical segments at separate points in the show, I create a five-step methodology to aid in analysis: determining, analyzing initial element, analyzing reprise, projecting, and incorporating. To show relationships between dramatic contexts in a show, I use elements of Dora Hanninen's associational methodology. Her associational graphs, contextual domain, and contextual criteria allow me to relate reprises with their initial presentations. To connect the musical reprise to a dramatic context, I develop a dramatic domain that allows for relationships between musical segments and dramatic interpretations. Jeanine Tesori's music, as well as that of other present-day Broadway composers, exhibits features of both Tin Pan Alley songs and more recent popular/rock music (since around 1960). Because of the variety of meanings of verse, chorus, and refrain in the literature, I develop TPA- (Tin Pan Alley) and P- (Popular) versions of each to refine and clarify their formal functions as well as expand the role of reprise in Fun Home and Shrek. Chapter 1 outlines my key definitions and assumptions and then situates my study within the context of existing musical theater scholarship in music theory and musicology. In Chapter 2, I describe my analytical process, TPA- and P- terminology, and use of Hanninen's theory. Chapter 3 analyzes Fun Home, with attention to how the reprise of certain motives and themes informs the formal analysis of songs as well as the characters' development and show's dramatic arc. In Chapter 4, I explore the dramatic implications of large-scale formal features in Shrek, specifically involving the numbers "Big Bright Beautiful World," "I Know It's Today," "This is How a Dream Comes True," and "Who I'd Be." Chapter 5 examines the ramifications of reprise for thematic and character development, particularly Fiona's revelation that she is an ogress ("Morning Person Reprise") and the show's professed multicultural unity ("Freak Flag" and "Finale"). Ultimately, my project explores how the analysis of a reprise's general formal features‚Äîassumed to transfer across performances, productions, actors‚Äîcan inform specific dramatic interpretations. In my analyses of Fun Home and Shrek, I show reprises that exhibit general, organizational principles of both Tin Pan Alley and recent popular music; at the same time, these general structural relationships can inform particular dramatic readings that vary by analyst, production, and performance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Associational Analysis, Broadway, Fun Home, Musicals, Reprise, Shrek the Musical
Michael Buchler, Professor Directing Dissertation; Elizabeth Osborne, University Representative; Rachel Lumsden, Committee Member; Nancy Rogers, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Tracing Principles and Self-Inflicted Constitutive Luck

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Control-based theories of moral responsibility are premised on the idea that agents are morally responsible only for that which is within their control. The connection between control and responsibility is quite intuitive. However, it is no less intuitive that agents are sometimes morally responsible for behaviors they cannot control, as is the case when a heavily intoxicated driver causes a car accident. Drunk drivers are blameworthy for the accidents they cause despite their lack of control over their vehicles. This commonplace observation seems to reveal that control-based theories of moral responsibility are susceptible to easy counterexamples. Not so. Many control-based theories of moral responsibility feature tracing principles to handle cases of moral responsibility in the absence of proximal control (e.g., drunk drivers). Tracing principles tell us, roughly, that an agent can be morally responsible for a behavior over which he lacks proximal control if at an earlier time the agent exercised control over some action or decision and could foresee that her action or decision would (or probably would) lead to uncontrolled behavior. In Chapter 2 of my dissertation, I argue by way of two counterexamples that many standard tracing principles are false. In Chapter 3, I consider various ways one might try to modify standard tracing principles to avoid the counterexamples developed in Chapter 2. Each of the proposed modifications surveyed in Chapter 3 seems promising initially, but I argue that none are tenable. In Chapters 4 and 5, I lay the foundations for a more promising solution to the problem I raised for tracing in Chapter 2. In Chapter 4, I explain the concept of constitutive luck and defend it against two skeptical objections. In Chapter 5, I introduce a new concept, self-inflicted constitutive luck, and argue that a tracing principle that takes account of self-inflicted constitutive luck will avoid the counterexamples advanced in Chapter 2.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Philosophy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
constitutive luck, luck, moral responsibility, tracing
Alfred Mele, Professor Directing Dissertation; Martin Kavka, University Representative; Randolph Clarke, Committee Member; Marcela Herdova, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: How Internal and External Focus of Attention Affect Clutch Performances in Golf Putting

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study was to investigate the affects of internal and external attentional focus while under pressure. The design of the study was a field based, using a within-subjects design. 36 participants were provided with internal and external focus of attention instructions under low and high pressure conditions. Putt accuracy and putt duration were measured as dependent variables for attentional focus and pressure manipulations. A significant interaction was found between attentional focus and pressure. Additionally, significant main effect was found for putt duration, specifically, the external focus condition yielded higher putt duration times than the internal condition. Results supported previous attentional focus research, where an external focus yielded greater putting accuracy when pressure was higher.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Program in Sport Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Attentional focus, clutch, golf, Pressure, putting

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Georg Joseph Vogler's Samori
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Representation and Difference in Early Nineteenth-Century Opera

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation offers a critical examination of Georg Joseph Vogler's opera Samori, focusing on its portrayal of Indian identities and cultural heritage. Utilizing my newly developed Intercultural Positionality Framework (IPF), the study addresses limitations in traditional opera analysis by providing an interdisciplinary approach to scrutinize cultural depictions. The IPF, rooted in positionality theory, incorporates a threefold heuristic assessing positionality, views of the Self and Others, and representations of the Self and Others. My ethnocentrism-relativism spectrum within the IPF aids in distinguishing cultural viewpoints among creators, ranging from ethnocentric to relativistic. The dissertation contributes to three main areas. First, it introduces the IPF as a tool for analyzing musical works within a cultural and power-dynamic context. Second, it broadens our understanding of Vogler's interactions with non-European cultures, thereby enriching interpretations of his works. Third, it situates Samori within the broader landscape of late eighteenth and early nineteenth-century exoticist works, specifically in relation to German perceptions of India. Through an exploration of Vogler's life, works, and evolving perspectives on cultural difference, the study also illuminates contemporaneous shifts in German intellectual thought about India. Vogler's approach to depicting India in Samori, sourced from scholarly writings‚Äîincluding works by Pierre Sonnerat, Georg Forster, and Fra Paolino da San Bartolomeo‚Äîexemplifies a complex interplay between cultural exoticism and relativism. This detailed depiction provides a meaningful examination of cultural representation in opera. The study offers a distinctive perspective to ongoing discussions in musicology about diversity and identity and underscores the potential of the IPF for future scholarship.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Difference, Exoticism, India, Musicology, Opera, Representation
Charles E. Brewer, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jane P. Clendenning, University Representative; Sarah Eyerly, Committee Member; S. Douglass Seaton, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Multigenic Drosophila Model of Colorectal Cancer Reveals Complex Signaling Networks Mediating Tumorigenesis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a complex heterogeneous disease characterized by multiple mutations affecting critical signaling pathways. Limitations in therapeutic treatments due to the development of resistance mechanisms, toxicity, and relapse of metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) have led to its high mortality rate worldwide. The epistatic interactions of aberrant signaling pathways in CRC contribute to the complexity and limitations of treating this disease. Thus, rapid development and identification of new potential druggable options in CRC is essential. Drosophila is a particularly useful model organism to dissect molecular mechanisms underlying CRC and to find potential new druggable targets. In this dissertation, we looked at critical signaling pathways driving CRC progression to identify novel therapeutically targetable nodes. Two important aspects affecting intestinal transformation in CRC genetic landscapes in Drosophila are the alteration of global phosphorylation networks driving CRC and the role of oncogene-induced-senescence (OIS). The regulation of phosphorylation of important pathways involved in cancer development and progression is governed by kinases and as a result, kinases are frequent targets of drug discovery efforts. However, target identification of kinases that are drivers of disease phenotype is challenging in cancer with mutations in multiple pathways. In this dissertation we report 2 classic genetic modifier screens focusing on Drosophila kinome to identify kinase regulators in 2 different CRC genetic backgrounds: KRAS TP53 PTEN APC, a multigenic cancer model targeting 4 recurrently mutated genes in human colon tumors and KRAS alone, a simpler single hit model targeting one of the most common altered pathways in cancer. Results from the screens in Chapter 2 suggest that classic genetic modifier screens in heterozygous mutant background with a modest reduction in candidate gene activity is a particularly useful approach for systemic drug treatment in identifying the most rate-limiting genetic vulnerability in disease model as ideal candidate drug targets. Additionally in this dissertation, we demonstrate that intricate epistatic interactions of underlying multi-kinase pathways in KRAS TP53 PTEN APC drive tumor progression via OIS. Senescence plays a crucial role in cancer, though this role can be either tumor-suppressive or tumor-promoting, depending on the genetic context and the microenvironment. The highly heterogeneous, dynamic, and context-dependent nature of senescence-associated features and the relatively small numbers of senescent cells in tissues make in vivo mechanistic studies of senescence challenging. As a result, which senescent-associated features are observed in which disease contexts and how they contribute to disease phenotypes remain largely unknown. Similarly, the specific mechanisms by which various senescence-inducing signals are integrated in vivo to induce senescence and why some cells become senescent while their immediate neighbors do not are unclear. In this dissertation, we identify a small number of cells that exhibit multiple features of senescence in a genetically complex model of CRC-induced intestinal transformation, in the Drosophila larval hindgut epithelium. These cells emerge in response to concurrent activation of AKT, JNK, and DNA damage response pathways within the transformed tissue. Eliminating senescent cells, genetically or by treatment with senolytic compounds, reduces overgrowth and improves survival. This tumor-promoting role is mediated by Drosophila macrophages recruited to transformed tissue by senescent cells, which results in non-autonomous activation of JNK signaling within the transformed epithelium. These findings emphasize complex cell-cell interactions as potential druggable nodes in cancer.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
cell signaling, colorectal cancer, Drosophila, druggable nodes, kinase, senescent cells

Erdem Bangi, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michelle N. Arbeitman, University Representative; Henry W. Bass, Committee Member; Jiang Feng, Committee Member; Kathryn M. Jones, Committee Member; Jerome Irianto, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Feeling the Hot Breath of History
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Influence of Forrest Carlisle Pogue on United States Military History

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study examines how Forrest Carlisle Pogue (1912 - 1996) critically influenced the writing of official United States military history and helped validate oral history as a legitimate historical resource in the late twentieth century. Drafted into the Army in 1942, Pogue was handpicked to serve as one of a handful of newly minted combat historians to serve in the United States Army during World War II. With few precedents upon which to rely, Pogue and his fellow combat historians were left to their own devices regarding their mission of collecting historical information in the European Theater of Operations. From a LST floating in the English Channel on D-Day, to Pilzen, Czechoslovakia on V-E Day, Pogue conducted oral history interviews with participants directly from the battlefield and sometimes under direct enemy fire. During the immediate post-war years, Pogue coupled his formal training as a historian with his wartime experience as a combat historian to write The Supreme Command, the third volume in the government-sponsored U.S. Army in World War II series more commonly known today as the "Green Books." In 1956, the George C. Marshall Research Foundation selected Pogue as the executive director for their planned research library and the official biographer of George Catlett Marshall. From 1956 to 1987, Pogue wrote an epic, four-volume biography consisting of George C. Marshall: Education of a General, 1880 - 1939 (1963); George C. Marshall: Ordeal and Hope, 1939 - 1942 (1966); George C. Marshall: Organized of Victory, 1942 - 1945 (1973); and George C. Marshall: Statesman, 1945 - 1959 (1987). In 1988, the Society of American Historians (SAH) recognized Pogue's work with their prestigious Francis Parkman Prize for Special Achievement. Pogue's efforts to utilize oral sources as the foundation for The Supreme Command and the Marshall biography garnered the attention of organizers who were trying to professionalize the burgeoning field of oral history. During the late twentieth century, Pogue became directly involved in establishing the Oral History Association and assisted aspiring oral history groups get their fledgling programs established. Pogue's involvement supported the study and practice of oral history emerge as a legitimate historical resource that continues to evolve.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Guenter Kurt Piehler, Professor Directing Dissertation; Mark Souva, University Representative; Andrew Frank, Committee Member; Jennifer Koslow, Committee Member; Jonathan Grant, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Oxysulfide-Based Fast-Ion Conductors for Solid-State Lithium Batteries

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The tunability of a material's structure is highly useful for designing a material with specific properties to meet current and future technological demands. This dissertation investigates the structure-property relationships of mixed-anion structural frameworks in novel solid electrolyte (SE) and semiconductor materials. Mixed-anion materials, which are materials with a combination of anions within their sublattice, allow for precise tuning of a material's properties based on atomic size, valence charge, polarizability, etc. Leveraging structural modifications on the atomic scale enables significant improvements in charge transfer as well as chemical and electrochemical stability. By employing diverse synthesis methods and an extensive array of advanced characterization techniques, we investigate the mixed-anion oxysulfide category of lithium thiophosphate solid electrolytes, denoted as Li3PS4-xOx, and examine its performance within all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSBs). In addition, we have also characterized the semiconductor F:In-O for use in thin-film transistors. Solid-state NMR is leveraged to study the change in local structures upon mixed-anion introduction. In Li3PS4-xOx, the optimal O substitution (x = 0.31) introduces PS3O3ÔÄ≠ units into the structural framework. This structural disruption causes a change from 2D to 3D Li+ transport with a 7X increase in ionic conductivity and a decrease in activation energy from 0.39 eV to 0.34 eV. Essentially, the disorder on the atomic scale leads to a flattening of the energy landscape, i.e., Li-ions are not trapped by the anions thereby improving the Li+ dynamics. In the case of the F:In-O semiconductor, anion disorder via incorporating FÔÄ≠ decreases the crystallinity. Mixed-anion frameworks can also yield enhanced stability. Li3PS3.69O0.31 shows improved stability against Li metal, resulting in an increased critical current density. Compared to the pristine Li3PS4, ASSB half-cells utilizing Li3PS3.69O0.31 show improved cycling stability and capacity. Mechanochemical milling of Li3PS4 or Li3PS3.69O0.31 SEs with TiS2 cathode active material generates a material that utilizes both cationic (Ti3+/4+) and anionic (S2ÔÄ≠/nÔÄ≠) (n<2) redox, contributing to two-fold capacity increase. ASSBs utilizing high-energy-milled catholytes containing TiS2 and Li3PS3.69O0.31 show improved high-rate cycling capacity and long-term cycling stability. Mixed-anion materials demonstrate novel or enhanced functional properties that surpass what their mono-anion counterparts can offer. The advancement of effective synthesis methodologies and comprehensive characterizations plays a pivotal role in expanding the accessibility of mixed-anion materials, making them increasingly valuable for critical technological applications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
batteries, EIS, electrolytes, energy storage, NMR, sulfide
Yan-Yan Hu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Chen Huang, University Representative; Mykhailo Shatruk, Committee Member; Oliver Steinbock, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Pairing Due to Emergent Gauge Fields

mods:mods.mods:abstract:
In this thesis, we study interlayer pairing of composite fermions in the $
u=1/2+1/2$ quantum Hall bilayer as a possible framework for understanding the transition to a bilayer quantum Hall state. In the large layer spacing limit, ignoring disorder and for perfectly balanced wells, the interlayer pairing interaction mediated by the Chern-Simons gauge fields in the two layers is singular with both attractive (out-of-phase) and repulsive (in-phase) components. It was previously shown that if only the singular attractive interaction is included, the pairing gap obtained by solving the gap equation is proportional to the inverse of the layer spacing squared. We analyze the effect of both the pairing and pair-breaking gauge fluctuations on bilayer pairing as a function of layer spacing. We focus on the balanced case and take the point of view that the system can be described for large layer spacing as two composite fermion metals whose low-energy physics is described by the Halperin-Lee-Read theory, with appropriately renormalized effective mass. We analyze the solution to the $T=0$ gap equation using a model with frequency dependent interaction meant to describe the $
u=1/2+1/2$ bilayer quantum Hall state starting from the limit of large layer spacing. This effective interaction contains a singular attractive interlayer pairing interaction, a less singular repulsive interlayer pairing interaction, as well as a non-singular coupling which we expect to depend on details of the system. The primary tool we use for our analysis is the so-called local approximation applied to the frequency dependent $T=0$ gap equation. Within this approximation we derive analytic and numerical results for the combined effect of the pairing and pair breaking. The local approximation solutions are then used as a starting point to iterate the full Eliashberg gap equations to assess the validity of the approximation in this limit. We first keep only the most singular interactions, both pairing and pair breaking. In the local approximation we find when the less singular repulsive interactions are included the energy gap is strongly suppressed, but still falls off as inverse layer spacing squared, consistent with recent Renormalization Group (RG) analysis. We also compare the results of the local approximation to exact solutions of the gap equation obtained numerically, verifying the essential validity of the approximation. We then describe our results for what happens as the short-range, non-singular interaction strength is varied, and the crossover from the weak gauge pairing we associate with the large layer spacing limit, to the strong BCS pairing due to strong short-range interaction in some angular momentum channels. We argue that within this interlayer pairing scenario, the experimentally observed transition from two compressible layers to an incompressible bilayer quantum Hall state, may reflect the strong crossover from a gauge pairing regime to a more conventional BCS type pairing. Next, we study the non-Fermi liquid behavior of this $
u=1/2+1/2$ bilayer due to the self-energy effects. When only the pairing interaction is considered, its self energy only slightly lowers the pairing gap compared to the case where self-energy is ignored. This means in this case the effect of self-energy is small and we wouldn't see non-Fermi liquid physics here. The superconducting gap is big enough to cut off the divergence in self-energy before Fermi liquid theory breaks down. However, when including the pair-breaking interactions, the energy gap is greatly suppressed and the system is allowed to get closer to the non-Fermi liquid phase before pairing occurs. When the two kinds of self-energy is combined, their effect gets larger and additional suppression to the energy gap is enhanced. Lastly, we study the different pairing angular momentum channel by using the full Random Phase Approximation (RPA) interactions, and show that the $p-$wave pairing in the $l=1$ channel is favored over $l=0$ channel, and has larger energy gaps for various layer spacing. However, this difference becomes small in the large layer spacing limit.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bilayer Quantum Hall System, Chern-Simons Gauge Fields, Composite Fermion, Majorana Fermion, Strongly Correlated Electrons, Superconductivity

Nicholas E. Bonesteel, Professor Directing Dissertation; William S. Oates, University Representative; Hitesh J. Changlani, Committee Member; Peng Xiong, Committee Member; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Voice in the Back of My Head
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Latinas' Testimonios on the Development of Their Science Identities in a Hispanic Serving Community College

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Latinas often experience a double bind as they navigate STEM trajectories, a result of multiple layers of marginalization associated with their intersecting identities. Although developing robust science identities is key to the persistence, success, and sense of belonging of minoritized students in STEM (Carlone & Johnson, 2007; McGee, 2020), many Latinas struggle to identify themselves as science people. Using a testimonio approach, the present study explored how seven Latinas pursuing vertical science transfer pathways at a Hispanic serving community college in Northern California built their science identities, and how mentoring relationships contributed to that process. Testimonio data were collected through individual writing prompts and individual and focus group interviews. Latino Critical Race Theory (Delgado Bernal, 2002; Villalpando, 2004), intersectionality (Crenshaw, 1989), Carlone and Johnson's (2007) model of science identity, and Yosso's (2005) model of community's cultural wealth were used as conceptual frameworks. This study builds on and expands existing research in multiple ways. First, it intentionally centered Latinas' positionalities and cultural wealth as key aspects in their science pathways, mapping how the process of building their science identity was shaped by participants' intersectional identities as Latinas, daughters of immigrants, and first-generation Latina college students. Second, this study amplified the role of the Hispanic serving community college, which became a place where participants could explore their place in science, engage in counterspaces (i.e., spaces, physical or ideological, that facilitate collective processing and resistance of experiences of marginalization, usually connected through shared elements of identity) (Shirazi, 2019), and interrogate Eurocentric meanings of science and being a science person. Finally, this study expanded the scope of mentorship beyond faculty-student dyads, including family and community members, and student support professionals at the community college. Participants' testimonios showed how their science identities were impacted by the opportunities mentors provided for them to develop their science competence and perform science skills, mentors' validation of participants' abilities and potential in science, and mentors' support in leveraging and expanding their community's cultural wealth. These findings suggest the need for community colleges and STEM departments to create intentional counterspaces for Latinas; expand professional development for faculty, student support professionals, and administrators on culturally competent practices; create opportunities for Latinas to explore community-based approaches to science; and design STEM mentoring programs guided by critical and culturally relevant frameworks. Future research should explore how specific groups of Latinas (e.g., Chicanas, Afro-Latinas) position themselves in science and build their science identities; explore the experiences of mentors at Hispanic serving community colleges; examine the experiences of Latinas who have not identified mentors or have sustained non-effective mentoring relationships in their science trajectories; and move towards more integrated models that examine the impact of effective mentorship on core aspects of Latinas' identities beyond their science identities.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Community College, Latinas, Mentorship, Science identity, STEM
Alysia Roehrig-Bice, Professor Directing Dissertation; Tamara Bertrand Jones, University Representative; Jeannine Turner, Committee Member; Beth Phillips, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Ne Bist Tu Wurme Fode?
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Disgust Didacticism in the Thirteenth-Century Ancrene Wisse

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The thirteenth-century guide for anchoresses, Ancrene Wisse, incorporates a wide array of disgusting images; from body products like pus and vomit to animals like toads and snakes, the text is replete with analogies and allusions that cause aversion and even nausea in the reader. This dissertation explores the didactic outcomes of such inclusions through the framework of behavioral psychology. Incorporating concepts such as associative conditioning, extinction conditioning, and memory augmentation via affect, this project considers the impact of recurrent exposure to disgust elicitors through daily reading of the text.Though the text is frequently identified as a rule, a genre not often associated with affective qualities, I first set out to establish just what Ancrene Wisse is. By reviewing naming conventions in Early English Text Society editions of the work, analyzing a century of scholarly approaches to the text's genre, and explicating the text itself for notes on its character and purpose, I provide a multi-faceted study that details Ancrene Wisse's intergeneric quality. My research points to a case of curatorial intervention that fixed perceptions of the text's genre for the past few centuries, possibly producing misperceptions around the emotional scope and tenor of the guide. Grounded in the concept of literatures of knowledge and power as defined by Thomas De Quincey, my investigation considers how emotion-provoking inclusions participate in a program of education for newly-minted anchoresses. Further, a systematic review of the text of Ancrene Wisse provides statistical analysis of disgust-provoking inclusions, allowing for a greater understanding of the proportion of certain categories of disgust elicitors and their areas of overlap. The dissertation includes a few appendices that report this data and its explication, where textual examples are coded according to Disgust Domains as defined by Haidt et al. and subtypes within each domain. The success of this application of behavioral psychology language and concepts leads to a discussion of possible future endeavors along the same methodology.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Affect, Anchorite, Ancrene Wisse, Disgust, Emotion, Psychology

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Unmasking Contemporary Racism
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: How Motivation to Be Nonprejudiced Shapes Responses to Inequality

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Contemporary racism poses a serious barrier to addressing the pervasive issue of racial inequality. Thus, it is important to identify the characteristic features of such racism and who are the kind of people more likely to perpetuate it. With this aim, the current work aimed to unmask some of the underlying features of contemporary racism and show how people's internal (IMS) and external (EMS) motivation to be nonprejudiced (Plant & Devine, 1998) plays a crucial role in determining who engages in such racism. Across four studies, we show that IMS is associated with other-focused justice sensitivity (Study 1), other-focused and affiliative language (Study 2), unambiguous acknowledgment of racial issues (Studies 2-4), support for systemic measures to combat inequality (Studies 2-3), and more information seeking of information related to racial-issues (Study 4). In contrast, EMS is associated with greater self-focused justice sensitivity (Study 1), psychologically distant and ambiguous language (Study 2), distancing from racial topics (Studies 2-4), overestimation of racial equality (Study 1 and 4), and less information seeking of race-related information (Study 4). Overall, the current work demonstrates that one of the keys to addressing the issue of racial inequality and contemporary racism is to find ways to foster internal motivation to respond without prejudice.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
E. Ashby Plant, Professor Directing Thesis; Jon Maner, Committee Member; Walter Boot, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Models and Solution Approaches for the Vessel Schedule Recovery Problem with Conflicting Objectives

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Global supply chains depend heavily on liner shipping networks, which connect countries and continents over a great distance at low transit costs. More than 80% of the world's trade in goods is carried out by international shipping activities. As such, liner shipping companies invest significant time, resources, and effort in network planning and scheduling. Each liner shipping firm typically designs the network for cargo shipping at the strategic decision-making level over a predetermined time. A detailed vessel schedule design (e.g., determination of sailing speeds at sea voyage legs, determination of port times, deployment of own vessels, deployment of chartered vessels, etc.) is conducted at the tactical level. However, many factors and unexpected events are beyond the control of liner companies and can undermine even the most carefully conceived plans. For example, disruptions can emerge in the forms of adverse weather events, congestion in channels, or container terminals. In some cases, these disruptions may render a previously optimized schedule highly suboptimal or even infeasible. In addition, they can have a significant impact on the liner shipping companies' profitability and the economic development of different countries. Liner shipping companies monitor their operations and take actions to recover their schedules and mitigate the impact of irregularities. This process is generally called "vessel schedule recovery problem".
