Examples of actions considered during the vessel recovery process include swapping two port calls or omitting one entirely, vessel sailing speed adjustment, port skipping with and without container diversion, and handling rate adjustment. The vessel schedule recovery problem becomes even more complicated as liner shipping firms have to adhere to the International Maritime Organization (IMO) policies. The IMO imposes restrictions on the type of fuel that vessels can use within Emission Control Areas (ECAs), limiting the types of fuels that could be adopted and emission amounts. One critical challenge associated with the vessel schedule recovery problem is the conflicting nature of objectives we aim to optimize in this process. In maritime shipping, sustainability considerations are often complicated by multiple and often conflicting objectives. For instance, in the presence of the disruption, the liner shipping company may decide to increase the sailing speed to meet the agreed level of service; however, the fuel consumption and vessel emission will be increased. Consequently, total route service costs will increase too. Another example is when the liner shipping company employs slow steaming to comply with the IMO regulations, which reduces vessel emission and fuel consumption and thus lowers operating costs. On the other hand, liner shipping companies are under pressure to address the service level agreements with cargo customers (ensuring on-time deliveries) while implementing slow steaming as a recommended practice. Notably, it is impossible to employ slow steaming to reduce fuel consumption while improving service levels simultaneously. In previous studies, all conflicting objectives are often combined into one objective function. This approach restricts the ability of liner shipping companies to make trade-offs between conflicting objectives. The main disadvantage of this approach is that it cannot find Pareto-optimal solutions, particularly in the case of a nonconvex objective space. Consequently, multi-objective mathematical formulations are necessary to analyze trade-offs between conflicting actions, albeit being ignored by the current state-of-the-art. To overcome these challenges, this dissertation aims to explore new multi-objective mathematical models for the vessel schedule recovery problem, considering various important operational attributes (i.e., fuel costs, emission regulations, potential cargo diversion via intermodal networks, increasing port handling costs due to faster service). A set of customized solution approaches will be proposed in order to solve the presented multi-objective mathematical formulations in a reasonable computational time. Furthermore, a set of computational experiments will be conducted to illustrate critical managerial insights and important trade-offs between conflicting objects in vessel schedule recovery. Such insights would be essential to the associated stakeholders, including shipping lines, terminal operators, and inland operators.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Maxim A. Dulebenets, Professor Directing Dissertation; O. Arda Vanli, University Representative; Ren Moses, Committee Member; Eren Ozguven, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Applications of the Latest Deep Learning Based Natural Language Processing (Nlp) Methods in Biomedical Domain

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In the past decade, there has been an exponential increase in the volume of biomedical literature, creating a wealth of life sciences knowledge in need of automated curation. This automated extraction process is termed Information Extraction (IE), a sub-discipline of Natural Language Processing (NLP). Concurrently, NLP technologies have developed rapidly and the performance of the NLP models has continuously improved, leading to better IE results. Named entity recognition (NER), Relation Extraction (RE) and Text Classification serve as the key tasks underpinning IE. Various approaches such as rule-based methods, traditional machine learning methods and deep learning methods have been employed for these tasks. Notably, deep learning techniques have surpassed other methods over the past five years and have become increasingly popular. In this dissertation, we focus on the applications of NER, RE, and Text Classification in the biomedical domain. Utilizing the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) model and its variants, we achieved state-of-the-art (SOTA) performances in the BioCreative Challenge 7 and Litcoin NLP Challenge. For the tasks of Disease Risk Factors Extraction and Drug Targets and Biomarkers Extraction for Diseases, the same BERT-based approaches were employed, yielding promising performances in NER, RE, and Text Classification. The dissertation is organized as follows: Chapter 1 introduces the background, techniques, evaluation metrics, and offers a succinct overview of application projects involving NER, RE, and Text Classification in biomedical contexts. Chapters 2 to 5 delve into the applications of these concepts in biomedical settings: Chapter 2 reviews the BioCreative 7 Challenge Track 2; Chapter 3 explores the Litcoin NLP challenge; Chapter 4 examines Disease Risk Factors Extraction; and Chapter 5 covers the Drug Targets and Biomarkers Extraction for Diseases.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Jinfeng Zhang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Zhe He, University Representative; Adrian Barbu, Committee Member; Chao Huang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Spirit of Carnival
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Entangled Influences in Junior Panorama and Trinidadian Youth Centered Spaces

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Since its inception in 1976, Junior Panorama, Trinidad and Tobago's youth steelband competition, has continued to grow in popularity, solidifying its prominent position within Trinidad's Carnival festivities. While the competition has been historically smaller than its senior Panorama counterpart, Junior Panorama has flourished over the past twenty years with up to sixty bands competing across three categories in recent competitions. Over the years, various stakeholders have taken a vested interest in the competition and the role that youth ensembles play within Trinidadian culture; at times, the aims of these stakeholders are in direct conflict with one another. In this dissertation, I analyze the Junior Panorama competition and the entangled influences that have developed within Trinidadian youth steelpan spaces. More specifically, I analyze local, national, and neoliberal approaches to the "Spirit of Carnival" within the competition. In his 2007 article "'Come to Life': Authenticity, Value, and the Carnival as Cultural Commodity in Trinidad and Tobago," Green argues that there are two dominant representations of Carnival: one marked by exuberance and colorful costuming, the other marked by cultural liberation (208). Building from these two representations and their role within national and neoliberal understandings of the competition, I also argue a third approach to Carnival is present within the competition, an approach that is fundamentally rooted in local small-scale networking within neighborhoods and communities. I expand Green's understanding of Carnival to include this third representation, creating three distinct conceptualizations of a critical cultural practice. Further, I place these understandings of Carnival within childhood studies. Limited research exists on children's Carnival practices within Trinidad and Tobago. As such, this work represents one of the first academic forays into conceptualizing and theorizing children's place within Carnival on a larger scale.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Musicology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Carnival, Childhood Studies, Junior Panorama, Steelpan, Trinidad and Tobago
Frank Gunderson, Professor Directing Dissertation; Stephanie Zuilkowski, University Representative; Panayotis League, Committee Member; Maria Ryan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Inventory of Fire Emissions Estimates for the United States and Its Implications for Air Quality and Health

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Fire is a natural phenomenon that plays pivotal roles in terrestrial ecosystems but is ultimately tightly bound to human influence. In the United States (U.S.), fires (wildfires, prescribed fires, and agricultural fires) are the leading emission source of primary particulate matter with diameters less than 2.5 microns (PM2.5), a pollutant which poses a significant risk to human health. Wildfires in the western U.S. are known for their destructive capabilities and negative impacts on air quality. Prescribed (i.e., controlled) fires and agricultural fires are common in the southeastern U.S., where they are credited with reducing fuel loads, limiting wildfire occurrence and severity, sustaining biodiversity, or for removing crop residue around harvest. However, due to their prevalence, properly estimating their emissions and air quality impacts is crucial. Unfortunately, underrepresentation of small and short duration prescribed or agricultural fires and their emissions is common in many fire emissions inventories that use polar-orbiting satellites to detect fires, which overpass only several times a day. This dissertation uses thermal fire detections from a satellite in geostationary orbit over the U.S. (GOES-16), and regionally appropriate emission factors for eastern U.S. land cover types, to develop the GOES-16 Eastern U.S. Fire Emissions Inventory (GEUFE). Fire emissions from GEUFE are evaluated against 8 other inventories and causes for differences or biases in other inventories are explored. We find GEUFE to represent more prescribed and agricultural fires than most inventories, owing to the high temporal resolution satellite returns from GOES-16, and GEUFE is generally in the high-end of emissions estimates. Using GEUFE and several other inventories in a chemical transport model (GEOS-Chem) to simulate PM2.5 concentrations and aerosol optical depth (AOD), we find GEUFE emissions result in the best model comparison to networks of ground site observations and to aircraft measurements from the Fire Influence on Regional to Global Environments and Air Quality (FIREX-AQ) field campaign. GEUFE indicates annual mean smoke PM2.5 concentrations of 2-5 ¬µg m-3 in the southeastern U.S., thereby suggesting that emissions from prescribed and agricultural fires are higher than previously thought. We then perform a health impact assessment of attributed mortality and asthma morbidity (emergency department visits and hospital admissions) from chronic and acute smoke PM2.5 exposure from western and eastern U.S. fire sources, and in urban and non-urban areas. We identify the most smoke impacted cities and non-urban areas, and we attribute nearly 26,000 annual deaths to chronic exposure to smoke from U.S. fires, of which 73% are attributable to smoke from eastern U.S. fires due to the proximity of those fires to high population densities in the eastern U.S. Lastly, we explore the differential impacts of four common fire types in the U.S. (western fires, eastern wildfires, eastern prescribed fires, and eastern agricultural fires) to PM2.5 air quality and to exceedances of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) for daily mean PM2.5. We find emissions and smoke PM2.5 from eastern prescribed fires to be comparable to, and higher in some instances, than western U.S. fires during the study period. While we find western fires to cause a higher number of NAAQS exceedance days than eastern U.S. fires, the air quality and health impacts from prescribed and agricultural burning are generally higher than past estimates. Despite prescribed burning having many other benefits that can potentially outweigh its negative health and air quality impacts, this dissertation identifies a need to perform additional cost benefit analysis of the common burning practice.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
air quality, emissions, fire, health, PM2.5, satellite

Christopher D. Holmes, Professor Directing Dissertation; Bryan Quaife, University Representative; Alyssa R. Atwood, Committee Member; Henry E. Fuelberg, Committee Member; Mark A. Bourassa, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cross-National and Cross-Document Analysis of Media and Policy Framing of Education for Displaced Persons in Canada and the United States

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In the face of economic, environmental, and security crises, forced displacement is increasing globally, drawing millions of men, women, and children from their homes and placing them into often unpredictable and indefinite states of transition. For these people, education can provide the knowledge and skills needed to resettle in another country, as well as provide a sense of stability and empowerment in an otherwise difficult context. Since displaced populations (DP) rely heavily on the resources of host countries for the provision of education services, the way that media and policy actors frame and label displaced groups may impact these groups' ability to access quality education. The descriptive mixed-methods analysis in the current study provides an overview of how frames and labels are used in media and policy documents related to the education of displaced populations in Canada and the United States. Examining articles from four national newspapers (n=146) and federal legislation from the U.S. Congress (n=67) published between 2013 and 2022, this study uses Goffman's (1974) Framing Analysis to compare how frames and labels are employed across the sample and how they are used to develop overarching neoliberal, human rights, and threat frameworks. The results of the current study show notable similarities and differences in the use of framing and labeling between Canadian and U.S. media and between U.S. media and legislation. Considering the overall use of framing observed in the sample, this study also addresses the way overarching neoliberal and human rights frameworks compete with one another while overarching threat frameworks can fragment a document's overall framing. This study adds to the body of literature on the framing of DP by placing this discussion in the North American context and by providing qualitative analysis to a set of literature that is mostly composed of quantitative studies.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
frame analysis, labels, media, NVivo, policy, Policy Frames Codebook
Stephanie Zuilkowski, Professor Directing Dissertation; Russell Clayton, University Representative; Patrice Iatarola, Committee Member; Toby Park-Gaghan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Pilot Randomized Control Trial of a Conditioning Paradigm to Increase Affinity for Sacredneses of Life and Decreasee Experiences of Suicide-Related Thoughts and Behaviors
Pilot Randomized Control Trial of a Conditioning Paradigm to Increase Affinity for Sacredness of Life and Decrease Experiences of Suicide-Related Thoughts and Behaviors

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Suicide-related experiences are a form of self-directed violence that affects millions of people every year. Through decades of research, interventions targeting these experiences have developed with varied empirical support. However, many treatments require regular attendance to sessions with a trained behavioral health professional. Limitations of in-person services have led to the development of digital-based interventions, such as Therapeutic Evaluative Conditioning (TEC). TEC is based in evaluative conditioning principles and is a brief (1-2 minutes) web-based intervention designed to increase aversion to self-injurious behaviors while decreasing aversion to the self through a match game-like task. Initial assessment of the intervention demonstrated promising results although treatment effects did not remain a month following treatment. Separately, sanctification, or the process through which aspects of life are perceived as having divine character and significance, can come from a theistic or nontheistic background and does not require a belief in a God or higher power to be experienced. When something is discovered as sacred, that sacredness becomes a priority for the individual, with motivation to conserve what is viewed as sacred. The primary aim of the current study is to develop and test the effectiveness of an adapted version of the TEC paradigm designed to increase affinity for sacredness of life and increase the connection to life as a mechanism for decreasing suicide-related experiences (TEC ‚Äì Sacredness of Life). Participants were recruited via online web forums with inclusionary criteria of a history of depressive symptoms and/or suicide-related experiences. Participants were randomized to one of two groups, intervention and control. The intervention group received the active condition, which included a matching game- like paradigm pairing positively valenced stimuli with stimuli representing the sacredness of life, as well as self-related words with life-related stimuli. Tasks were completed online, and consisted of assessments at baseline, weekly intervals (one month), and one month following treatment completion. Results did not support the effectiveness of TEC ‚Äì Sacredness of Life, with all results suggesting a non-significant relationship between the conditioning paradigm and all study outcomes of interest, except for self-report measure of perceived sacredness of life and reasons for living. For these two outcomes, a significant relationship was found between condition and outcome, such that those in the control condition endorsed higher levels of perceived sacredness of life and reasons for living at the end of the treatment month. This relationship was no longer significant at one month following the completion of the intervention month. This study is foundational work in a novel approach to address the public health priority of prevention and treatment of suicide-related thoughts and behaviors. Discussion includes lessons learned and directions for further intervention development.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Thomas E. Joiner, Professor Directing Dissertation; John Corrigan, University Representative; Norman B. Schmidt, Committee Member; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Christopher Schatschneider, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Secure Communication over Container

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Containers such as Docker and Singularity encapsulate complex programs with their dependencies in isolated environments and offer fast, customizable, portable, and flexible deployments of applications. The containerization technology eases the deployment of High-Performance Computing (HPC) instances in the cloud computing environment, facilitating the migration of HPC applications to the cloud. Another important aspect for HPC applications to run in cloud environments is security. Encrypted communication is essential for HPC applications that process sensitive data. Encryption and decryption operations are expensive operations. Hence, new algorithms and protocols need to be developed to efficiently support security. Additionally, cloud computing platforms employ virtualization technology, and achieving efficient secure communication on virtualized environments presents added complexity. In this dissertation research, we have developed and evaluated techniques to support secure communication, in an efficient way, over virtualized environments using container technology. This exploration occurred in multiple steps. Initially, we developed novel algorithms for the collective operations within the Message Passing Interface (MPI) library, with a specific focus on the all-reduce operation. Additionally, we contributed to the development of a secure MPI library called CryptMPI. We participated in integrating and standardizing the developed encrypted operations within CryptMPI. In the second step, we examined CryptMPI's behavior across container clusters. We evaluated CryptMPI's performance on various container engines, such as Docker and Singularity, to gauge its effectiveness within the virtualized clusters. Moreover, we conducted a comprehensive comparison of the different built-in encryption mechanisms offered by container managers, specifically focusing on Docker Swarm and Kubernetes, and compared the gathered results with those of CryptMPI. In the final step, we explored other encryption schemes for CryptMPI, offering better performance for small message sizes. In this survey, we combined all of these state-of-the-art techniques to develop a novel and well-designed secure MPI library.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Container, Docker, Encryption, High-Performance Computing, Kubernetes, MPI
Xin Yuan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sherry Southerland, University Representative; Viet Tung Hoang, Committee Member; Zhenhai Duan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Information, Motivation, and Co-Creation Behaviors of Literary Tourists and Their Quest for Meaningful Experiences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The research project Information, motivation, and co-creation behaviors of literary tourists and their quest for meaningful experiences explores the behaviors of travelers seeking experiences related to authors, books, or characters. Though travel has experienced a resurgence following pandemic closures, travel uncertainty prompts travel professionals to consider unique options to entice travelers. Literary tourism could allow travelers to connect to destinations as their favorite book characters do, yet little is known about the information-seeking behaviors, motivations, and needs of literary tourists when searching for and sharing literary activities in online environments. Understanding the information and motivation behaviors of literary travelers could help information professionals and tourism operators better understand this population and the experiences that inspire co-creation of knowledge within their online communities. This project gathers data about literary travelers and their information-seeking behaviors during the pre-planning phase, their observations during travel, and their sharing behaviors following literary travel experiences. What motivates the literary traveler in choosing activities and how does their experience during travel affect their motivation to share and co-create knowledge? This project on literary travelers began with a netnographic observation (Kozinets, 1998; Kozinets, 2006; Kozinets, 2020) of three fan-based Facebook groups, collecting 45 posts from 38 users. Online self-interviews were completed by 31 literary travelers and interview questions were informed by Dervin's sense-making theory (Dervin, 1983; Foreman-Wernet & Dervin, 2016; Souto et al., 2012). Both deductive and inductive coding were utilized during data analysis, and Pine and Gilmore's (1998; 1999) experience economy model was used to correlate the varied literary traveler activities to the experience realms for insight into how these experiences engage the literary traveler. This project revealed literary travelers in this study practice a virtuous circle of information behavior through social media post interaction in fan-based groups, promoting a sense of community, and choose literary experiences aligned to their motivation for the activity, customizing it to their needs.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Information in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Co-creation behaviors, Information Behaviors, Literary Tourism, Literary Travel, Meaningful experience
Marcia A. Mardis, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jennifer Proffitt, University Representative; Michelle Kazmer, Committee Member; Margaret Zimmerman, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Hearing the Cry of the Oppressed
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Comparative Liberation Ethics

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation provides a comparison of religious ethics between Christian and Muslim sources to describe an anti-imperial liberation ethic. It takes three subjects ‚Äì Gustavo Gutierrez, Camilo Torres, and Ali Shariati ‚Äì and extrapolates from their writings a three-part framework to facilitate this comparison. This framework consists of: 1) a theory of oppression (from which one is liberated); 2) a critique of the status quo, both politically and theologically; and, 3) a focus on experience and praxis. The comparisons made and the framework provided will help to justify intuitive comparisons by other scholars as well as establish future comparisons of liberation theologies.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Religion in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Christianity, Comparative Religious Ethics, Ethics, Islam, Liberation Theology
John Kelsay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Will Hanley, University Representative; Adam Gaiser, Committee Member; Martin Kavka, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Strategic Applications of Regioselective Pyridinium Dearomatization

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Since antiquity, alkaloid natural products have served as medicinal ingredients that still contribute as an inspiration for the development of novel therapeutics. For the synthetic chemist, much of the importance of natural products lies in their acting as a forcing-function for the invention of new synthetic strategies and tactics for molecular assembly. With this rich history in mind, it remains an important goal for chemists to build nitrogenous structures with greater efficiency, abiding by economies of synthesis. Nitrogenous aromatic feedstocks have been an intriguing starting point for the functionalization and construction of alkaloids for several decades, but recent advances in reaction design have opened new doors for leveraging abundance in concise synthesis. Herein, advances in this area of synthetic ingenuity will be summarized with the aim of instructing chemists towards considering dearomatization as a strategic avenue for both target-oriented and diversity-oriented synthetic campaigns. Overall, syntheses are evaluated, compared, and contrasted to give a systematic overview of this continued area of research.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Joel Michael Smith, Professor Directing Dissertation; Cathy W. Levenson, University Representative; James Frederich, Committee Member; Brian Miller, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Longitudinal Investigation of Interpersonal Functioning and Eating Pathology in Adult Men and Women

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Research examining associations between eating pathology and interpersonal functioning has largely been cross-sectional and focused on female adolescents, with existing longitudinal investigations focused on a model in which interpersonal difficulties increase risk for eating pathology. To date, no studies have simultaneously examined bidirectional pathways between eating pathology and interpersonal functioning. As such, we know little about how these variables change over adult development and how these changes relate to each other over time. Accordingly, we investigated the course of, and directionality of associations between eating pathology and friendship satisfaction, as well as between eating pathology and interpersonal distrust, over time. To achieve this, we used a longitudinal design over twenty years representing transitions from emerging, established, and middle adulthood measured in two cohorts of men and women. Results from latent growth models indicate that friendship satisfaction and Drive for Thinness were stable over time, while Bulimia and Interpersonal Distrust declined over time. No moderating effects for gender or cohort were observed for growth trajectories. Autoregressive paths from results of latent variable cross-lagged panel models and mean scores random-intercept panel models showed that most variables of interest had consistent carryover effects. Few cross-lagged effects were found, and none were consistent across samples, suggesting that when accounting for between-person factors (in RI-CLPM models only) and within-person effects, eating pathology and friendship satisfaction or interpersonal distrust failed to predict one another over time. Treatment implications of these findings are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Pamela K. Keel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Anne E. Barrett, University Representative; Thomas E. Joiner, Committee Member; Richard K. Wagner, Committee Member; Andrea L. Meltzer, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Statistical Analysis of Extremes in Non-Stationary Surface Air Temperatures

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The threat of anthropogenic climate change on extreme weather events such as extreme heat and cold warrants an investigation to improve how extreme weather is identified and forecasted. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) defines an extreme temperature event based on a certain temperature threshold or as an event that is below or above the 10th or 90th percentile of a probability distribution, respectively. The problem with this approach is the IPCC uses two meter surface temperature data that contains high and low frequencies embedded. These frequencies contain non-stationary properties that make it difficult to determine how extreme temperatures are changing due to the concept of a moving mean. This thesis proposes a timescale decomposition that extracts the higher frequencies and leaves out the non-stationary influence. By focusing on the probability distribution functions (PDF) of the higher frequencies, statistical moments, such as standard deviation, skewness, and kurtosis, can be used to spatially and temporally locate extreme temperatures. While other data analysis methods exist, most of them either do not apply to non-stationary data or are not as simple as the decomposition scheme used in this project. The timescale decomposition method is very effective in providing piecewise moment plots and global contour figures depicting the moment values and how they changed with time. A specific grid point, region, or globe can be analyzed through decadal intervals to fully observe trends in the moments and can even be used to detect atmospheric patterns. The procedure also revealed a multi-decadal rate of change in the moments which is left unexplained and for future researchers to investigate.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Climate Change, Data Analysis, Kurtosis, Skewness, Statistical Moments
Zhaohua Wu, Professor Directing Thesis; Vasubandhu Misra, Committee Member; Philip Sura, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Financial Strain and Health
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Exploring the Moderating Role of Religious Involvement

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The existing literature acknowledges that financial strain is a crucial stress source that deteriorates a wide range of health-related outcomes. Researchers reveal that having economic problems is linked to triggering negative mental health issues and worsening physical health outcomes. In this regard, inquiries have focused on the association between financial strain and health in several ways; however, important questions have not been addressed about the moderating role of religious dimensions. By using the stress-process model, I aim to augment the literature by exploring the role of dimensions of religious involvement in conditioning the effects of financial strain on depression and self-rated health. I analyze data coming from the Nashville Stress and Health Study (2011‚Äì2014), a cross-sectional probability survey of black and white working-age adults from Davidson County, Tennessee (n = 1,252). Multivariate regression models provide several key findings: First, financial strain is positively associated with depression, net of statistical control variables. Second, the dimensions of religious involvement (religious identity, organizational religiosity, non-organizational religiosity, and perceived divine control) moderate the exacerbating effects of financial strain on depression. Third, the moderating role of the dimensions of religious involvement on the association between financial strain and depression varies by gender and race. Fourth, financial strain is inversely associated with self-rated health, net of statistical control variables. Fifth, the dimensions of religious involvement (religious identity and non-organizational religiosity) mitigate the deleterious effects of financial strain on self-rated health. Sixth, the moderating role of religious dimensions on the association between financial strain and self-rated health varies by gender and race. Overall, these findings suggest strong empirical associations among financial strain, depression, self-rated health, and religious involvement of NSAHS participants. I discuss study implications, limitations, and future research avenues.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Depression, Financial Strain, Gender, Race, Religion, Self-rated Health

Amy M. Burdette, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jeannine E. Turner, University Representative; John R. Taylor, Committee Member; Patricia A. Homan, Committee Member; Michael E. Nielsen, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Melodies of China
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Guide for Understanding Adapted Folk Tunes in Solo Piano Works by Zhao Zhang

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this treatise, I have examined twenty solo piano works from the book Melodies of China. These twenty pieces span various folk song melodies representative of distinctive regional characteristics from East, South, West, and North China. By individually introducing the historical background of each piece, and digging into the analysis of their tonality, harmony, rhythm, and musical textures, I explained the cultural essence and folk tales embedded within each composition. In summary, this treatise provides a comprehensive exposition of each piece from historical, ethnomusicological, personal, and musical perspectives, offering those interested in Chinese folk melodies an opportunity to grasp their profound significance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
Stijn De Cock, Professor Directing Treatise; Michael Buchler, University Representative; Diana Dumlavwalla, Committee Member; David Kalhous, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: #Black Girls' (Opinions) Matter
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Instagram in 2020, BLM, & Racialized Differences in Girls' Perceptions of Police and SROs

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation investigates Black and White teenage girls' perceptions of police and how those perceptions are informed by two distinct sources: school resource officers (SROs) in high schools, and social media content related to police violence in the aftermath of George Floyd's killing by Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin. Existing sociological research on young peoples' perceptions of police has found that their attitudes vary according to race, gender, neighborhood, as well as vicarious and personal experiences with police. Vicarious police exposure refers to police interactions they observe in the neighborhood or hear of from friends and family members. This work finds that Black girls are more likely to have negative perceptions of police than White girls, in part due to their higher rate of negative vicarious experiences with police. Little is known, however, about how the recent proliferation of police brutality videos on social media affects teenage girls' perceptions of police or racial differences in those perceptions. Additionally, police perceptions research tends to focus on only one type of police by asking general survey questions like, "How good or bad a job is being done for the country as a whole by the police?" Most of the research on the social determinants of attitudes towards police does not include SROs. This dissertation research contributes to both the literature on perceptions of police and the literature on SROs by investigating teenage views and experiences with police in and out of schools and their experiences on social media in 2020. Data come from in-depth interviews with 30 girls (18 Black girls and 12 White girls) who attended a public high school in 2020 that had at least one SRO. Transcripts of interviews were analyzed through coding, memo-writing, sorting narrative blocks, and comparing life-event narratives. Unlike other studies that find more negative views of police among racialized minorities, the Black and White girls in this study rated police similarly. However, they arrived at these views by very different means. Black girls developed negative perceptions of police at much earlier ages than White girls and, according to their recollections, for different and more numerous [or "varied"] reasons compared to most White girls. White girls recalled their views of police as being vague or positive in childhood and early teen years, but most had developed quite negative views of police by their late teen years. White girls were more influenced by viewing videos of police brutality on social media in 2020 compared to Black girls, because Black girls all reported being familiar with police brutality prior to 2020. Black and White girls described different experiences on social media, including racially patterned emotional responses to watching videos of police brutality and racialized differences in motivations to post/not post about police brutality on social media in 2020. Black and White girls also shared similar views of SROs. Findings reveal that if students like an SRO, it does not diffuse to other police personnel because SROs are not seen as real police unless they engage in behaviors that many students see as inappropriate and criminalizing. Lastly, the majority of girls reported not feeling safe because of SRO presence and were not able to clearly describe SRO roles, with many girls reporting that SROs mostly sat around and made casual conversations with students and staff.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Black girls, Black Lives Matter, Perceptions of police, School to Prison Pipeline, Social media, SROs
John Reynolds, Professor Directing Dissertation; Patricia Warren-Hightower, University Representative; Shantel Buggs, Committee Member; Douglas Schrock, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: College, Community, and the Long Road to Recovery
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Academic Excellence in the Aftermath of a Hurricane

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this Dissertation in Practice was to explore the experiences of Gulf Coat State College faculty in the wake of Hurricane Michael, in effort to better understand how the storm, as well as the institution's response, shaped instruction and student success. The intent of this study was to determine if the policies and practices implemented by the institution supported or interfered with the work of faculty. This was an exploratory case study seeking to determine how Hurricane Michael affected faculty members' instructional practice and their perceptions of student success and academic engagement post-disaster. The setting of this study was Gulf Coast State College, a 2-year institution located in the Panhandle of Florida, and focused on faculty members teaching courses at Gulf Coast State College during the fall 2018 semester, when Hurricane Michael made landfall. Interviews were conducted with faculty participants to determine what faculty believed to be the most important factors contributing to academic excellence and student success post-hurricane. Using a qualitative research design, I hoped to create awareness of a subject where there has been little previous research, define the obstacles to maintaining academic excellence faced by faculty specific to natural disasters, and assess the policies and practices implemented by Gulf Coast State College to facilitate teaching and learning. By illustrating how this event has shaped Gulf Coast State College over time, this research can be used as a template for the institutional support of faculty and student academic success or institutions facing similar challenges.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

Eric Ludwig, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Patrice Iatarola, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Phil Hiver, University Representative; Cameron Beatty, Committee Member; Shouping Hu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring the Role of Interpersonal Communication, Social Cohesion, and Collaboration in Team Science Dynamics
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Qualitative Content Analysis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In scientific research, a collaborative approach to problem-solving has been widely embraced. While team-based research may encourage innovation and complex problem solving, scientific teams are known to experience challenges that impact their ability to integrate knowledge, share information, and make decisions. At the individual level, negative social interactions with team members, such as presentation of unpleasant or obstructive behaviors, can impact a researcher's ability to work collaboratively and their overall satisfaction with the project. At the team level, interpersonal communication breakdowns can impede functionality and a team's ability to produce desired results. Contemporary issues of global significance, such as climate change and the ongoing threat of current and future health pandemics, make the need for effective teams both desirable and urgent. As part of a growing body of literature, scholars researching the Science of Team Science (SciTS) have attempted to address this by researching how science teams collaborate and by sharing empirical findings that can be used to enhance team science practices. This study explored the extent to which interpersonal communication is present in the literature and how SciTS scholars are describing and addressing it in the context of scientific teams in order to gain a deeper understanding of other factors that may impact the presence of interpersonal difficulties among team members. This research also underscored the need for empirically-driven interventions designed to improve the teaming and interpersonal communication skills of research collaborators. Further, these interventions should be co-created in unity and equal partnership with the scientists and others they are designed to prepare for the unique challenges of collaborative research. The prescription of best practices and models or frameworks cannot be limited to theoretical work; it must address and reflect community-based knowledge that exists within collaborative science communities.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Interpersonal Communication, Science of Team Science, Social Cohesion
Jessica Wendorf Muhamad, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric P. Chassignet, University Representative; Ulla Bunz, Committee Member; Katherine R. Dale, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Extrinsic Incentives, Voting Behavior, and Public Opinion
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Three Studies of the Influence of Extrinsic Incentives over Voting Choices, Turnout, and Attitudes Toward Clientelism

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation includes three studies that discuss the influence of extrinsic incentives on voting behavior and public opinion. In the first study, I propose a formal model that aims to explain how extrinsic incentives, the perceptions of voters about receiving these incentives, and the electoral environment affect individuals' voting choices. I find equilibria that show that yielding to the influence of exogenous incentives‚Äìwhether they are material or immaterial‚Äìis a best strategy under not very stringent conditions. Then, I illustrate the predictions from the model using three cases where it has been observed that material or immaterial incentives affected‚Äìor still affect‚Äìthe behavior of voters: vote-buying and voter coercion during the United States Gilded Age, the electoral behavior of African-Americans, and religious voting. The second study evaluates the effect on electoral participation of a turnout-buying program implemented in the state of Chihuahua in Mexico. Using a difference-in-difference design, with the states of Sinaloa and Zacatecas as control cases, I find evidence that suggests that this program has not met its goal of incentivizing participation. I also use a triple difference-in-difference design to explore if the program may have only had an effect on urban municipalities. The results of these additional estimations confirm that, at least at the municipality level, the program has not increased turnout. Finally, the third study explores a public opinion aspect of a phenomenon related to extrinsic incentives. Using data from the LAPOP AmericasBarometer Mexico 2018 survey, I address the question of the existence of social desirability bias regarding clientelism in Mexican public opinion. The results indicate that respondents that revealed that they had received a clientelist offer seemed to try and distance themselves from these offers by giving more negative evaluations of clientelism. This finding suggests that social desirability bias is present as respondents seem to use the evaluation question as a way to distance themselves from the offer they claimed to have received.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Extrinsic Incentives, Public Opinion, Social Desirability, Turnout-Buying, Voting Behavior
Brad T. Gomez, Professor Directing Dissertation; Javier Cano-Urbina, University Representative; Jens Grosser, Committee Member; Lonna R. Atkeson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Application of Artificial Intelligence for Detecting Power Distribution System Faults and Power Quality Disturbances

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Modern power distribution grid has become very complex, especially with the integration of distributed renewable resources and many electronic power devices. Maintaining power quality is becoming incrementally challenging due to the growing power electronic equipment in the grid. On the other hand, distributed renewable resources are making the current protection methods obsolete, which are mainly based on uni-directional power flow and acts based on some predefined threshold. The concept of a central control center and traditional protection system must be updated. To accommodate these needs, monitoring devices are placed throughout the distribution system, enabling real-time monitoring of the system and collecting system information with high resolution from different points in the system during any event. This large amount of system data can be harnessed with machine learning algorithms to detect, classify, and locate the source of disturbances in the system. Data-driven approaches are gaining popularity due to their high accuracy and less dependency on system parameters. However, deploying artificial intelligence (AI) techniques for power system applications needs more labeled data. This dissertation is focused on artificial intelligence applications for power distribution event detection and location identification. The first topic is developing an AI application for distribution system's fault management. Faults are the most catastrophic events in the power system responsible for sustained outages. The traditional approaches suffer from inaccuracy and are often dependent on system parameters or preset thresholds. Data-centric approaches based on available sensor or meter data can be deployed for fault management applications. However, the amount of accurately labeled data is very limited, which is an impediment in training deep models for better accuracy. This dissertation proposes an ensemble network combining standalone machine learning algorithms like artificial neural network (ANN), K-nearest neighbour (K-NN), and random forest (RF) for achieving higher efficiency with limited data. The proposed method utilizes event-driven voltage measurements from the existing smart meters in the system to classify and locate faults accurately. The method has been validated using a real-time simulator and has been tested under different adverse scenarios. The proposed method showed improved and robust performance in all cases. High impedance faults are invisible to existing threshold-based protection systems as they produce very low fault current. These events are hard to isolate from normal load changes and can evolve into catastrophic events like wildfires, life hazards, or equipment damage. As most of these events go undetected, there is little labeled data for training a supervised model. This dissertation proposes a generative adversarial network (GAN)-based unsupervised method along with a time-frequency analysis for extracting features from waveforms and isolating HIFs from other events like load variation or capacitor switching. The second topic addressed in this dissertation is applying unsupervised learning techniques for analyzing power quality waveforms. As power quality waveforms are often captured periodically, the huge amount of data can be overwhelming for PQ engineers to analyze manually. The dissertation proposed the development of an autoencoder and K-means-based unsupervised clustering method with field-obtained unlabeled data and cosine similarity-based event label identification using very few numbers of labeled data. PQ event analysis via an unsupervised method, especially utilizing field-obtained practical data, has been a less explored area in distribution grid analytics. The proposed method can help investigate a large number of captured waveforms quickly and isolate event data from normal recurring data. In summary, this dissertation proposes AI applications in distribution systems with limited labeled data. The first is a supervised technique that shows enhanced performance without requiring additional data. The other applications are unsupervised methods requiring very little amount of labeled data for event category selection. The proposed methods show good performances and address practical problems in the context of power quality event management in distribution systems.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
AI application in power system, Power quality, Power system analysis, Power system fault, Real-time simulation, Smart grid
Md Omar Faruque, Professor Directing Dissertation; Juan Ordonez, University Representative; Sastry Pamidi, Committee Member; Simon Foo, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Survey of the Benefits of Music Therapy in Disaster Preparedness, Mitigation, and Recovery

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Emergencies and disasters are happening more frequently in the United States. The current study investigates music therapist's perspectives on the use of music therapy interventions to facilitate care for clients impacted by a disaster. Using the quantitative research method of an online survey, data were gathered to document music therapists' experiences and interests in providing immediate and long-term therapy to clients following disaster displacement. Participants shared their perceptions on how music therapy can be effective in all stages of emergency management including preparation, mitigation, response, and recovery. Participants included that movement, instrument play, drumming, and songwriting interventions can be most helpful. Recommendations are provided. A limitation of the study was a small response rate (<.01%) that percents generalization of findings but does point for further study.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Music Therapy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
emergency management, Music Therapy, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder PTSD, preparedness, recovery, trauma
Flor del Cielo Hernandez, Professor Directing Thesis; Jayne Standley, Committee Member; Sarah D. Gregory, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Role of Home Literacy Environment in the Reading Development of Children with and without Learning Disabilities

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Home literacy environment (HLE) refers to children's exposure to and engagement in reading related activities in the home. Children's HLE prior to kindergarten is predictive of reading achievement in later years. Utilizing a sample of 2,090 children from the ECLS-K:2011 dataset, a large longitudinal nationally representative dataset, this study expands these investigations to children with learning disabilities (LDs), a population that is at heightened risk of experiencing low reading achievement. The results were that LD children are exposed to lower HLE than their non-disabled peers. Furthermore, HLE positively predicted reading achievement in kindergarten, which operated the same for both children with and without LDs. HLE is important to the reading achievement of both groups, but there is concern that LD children are receiving lower HLE and that LD children would benefit from better HLE. Finally, HLE predicted a less steep reading slope through fifth grade, however there is need for further investigation into if HLE predicts reading slope independent of its relation to early reading achievement.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Early childhood, Home environment, Learning disabilities, Longitudinal, Reading
Richard Wagner, Professor Directing Thesis; Sara Hart, Committee Member; Caterina Gratton, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Effect of Almond Snacking on Gut Microbiome in Adults with Overweight or Obesity

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: As research into the human microbiome increases, as does the interest in determining the role-specific foods have on gut microbiome and how this may impact an individual's health. Americans receive a substantial portion of their daily caloric intake from snacks, with tree nuts, such as almonds, being a popular snack choice. Research involving the impacts of almonds on the human gut microbiome is limited and widely inconclusive, especially in overweight and obese populations. To address this knowledge gap, the intent of this research is to determine the impact of almonds on the human gut microbiome and how this may play a role in gut and cardiometabolic health markers in adults who are overweight or obese. Participants completed two 4-week long intervention periods of isocaloric weight maintenance diets, subdivided by a 2-week compliance break, where they consumed either no treatment foods (average American diet; AAD) or 42.5 g/d of almonds (almond diet; ALD). Serum and fecal sample collections occurred at baseline (BAS) and after each study arm. Our results demonstrate that incorporating almonds as a snack into the diet has a moderately favorable impact on gut microbiome diversity. Moreover, snacking on almonds leads to an increase in the abundance of gut bacteria known to produce beneficial short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs; e.g., acetate and butyrate), which correlate with reduced levels of inflammatory biomarkers and improved physiological parameters associated with arterial health in adults with overweight or obesity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Exercise Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Ravinder Nagpal, Professor Directing Thesis; Prashant Singh, Committee Member; Bahram Arjmandi, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Relationship between Childhood Trauma and Academic Functioning
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Influence of Social Support as a Protective Factor

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Research has demonstrated a clear connection between childhood trauma and later life difficulties, including difficulties in academic functioning. Specifically, childhood trauma is associated with declines in academic achievement (Blodgett & Lanigan, 2018; Duke, 2020), attendance (Blodgett & Lanigan, 2018; Crouch et al., 2019), and school engagement (Bethell et al., 2014; Crouch et al., 2019; Iachini et al., 2016). Some research has identified that certain types of trauma might be associated with different types of academic functioning (Crouch et al., 2019; Duke, 2020) and that these relationships may differ for boys and girls (Duke, 2020; Hardaway et al., 2014). However, such specific relationships and patterns are understudied. As well, though social support has been shown by preliminary research to serve as a protective factor between childhood trauma and academic functioning (Samuel & Burger, 2020) research is greatly lacking in this area. Thus, the purpose of the current study was to explore relationships between childhood trauma, academic functioning, and academic functioning in adolescence while also examining potential gender differences. A sample of 380 adolescent participants (grades 9-12) were recruited from a Southeastern K-12 school and were included in the current study. The final sample (n=380) consisted of 45.8% boys (n=174) and 48.7% girls (n=185). The sample was 47.6% White Non-Hispanic (n=181), 22.9% Black or African American (n=87), 14.2% White Hispanic (n=54), 8.9% two or more races (n=34), 5.3% Asian (n=20), .5% American Indian (n=2), and .5% Native Hawaiian or Other (n=2). A cross-sectional design was utilized to investigate the following research questions: (1) Is childhood trauma associated with academic functioning for boys and girls?, (2) Are all 3 clusters of trauma (witnessing trauma, interpersonal trauma, and non-interpersonal trauma) associated with all three indicators academic functioning (academic achievement, attendance, and school engagement) for boys and girls?, and (3) Does social support (friend social support, family social support, and school social support) moderate the relationship between childhood trauma and academic functioning for boys and girls? Participants were asked questions related to childhood trauma experiences, social support, and academic functioning using the follow measures: Child PTSD Symptom Screener-5-Self-Report (CPSS-5-SR; Foa et al., 2017), the Delaware Student Engagement Scale (DSES; Bear et al., 2019), and the (CASSS; Malecki & Demaray, 2001). Students' GPA and attendance were also obtained and matched with students' responses on the surveys. Additionally, demographic items such as race/ethnicity and gender were obtained. Data were analyzed using structural equation modeling (Research Questions 1 and 3) and path analysis (Research Question 2). Results from analyses demonstrated that childhood trauma was significantly associated with declines in academic functioning and that path strengths were different, but the difference was not statistically significant in this sample (Research Question 1). Further, results partially illustrated that some types of trauma may be more detrimental to some types of academic success. Again, there was no significant difference between boys and girls in this sample with one exception: the path between non-interpersonal trauma and attendance was statistically significant with path being stronger for girls than boys. (Research Question 2). Social support was not found to moderate the relationship between childhood trauma and academic functioning (Research Question 3). Implications for theory, clinical practice, and future research are covered.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Lyndsay Jenkins, Professor Directing Dissertation; Christine Mokher, University Representative; Deb Osborn, Committee Member; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Numerical and Experimental Studies of Turbulence in Quantum Fluids

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In inviscid quantum fluids like superfluid 4He (He II) and Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs), rotational motion can occur when quantized vortex lines are present. A chaotic tangle of vortices then induces quantum turbulence (QT), turbulent flows in the quantum fluids. QT has become increasingly important in various physical systems, such as superfluid neutron stars, holographic superfluid models of gravity, and complex light fields. Many unanswered questions remain despite past studies on QT in He II and BECs. In this dissertation, we discuss four research projects, three of which are numerical and experimental studies on selected questions in the quantum fluids field, and the other is a numerical study on electron qubits floated on solid neon (Ne).The first numerical study involves the merging process of a stationary BEC with a rotating BEC. In classical fluid drops, rotational motion is transferred by viscous shear flow during the merging process. However, BEC is inviscid, and the corresponding mechanism is less clear. Our results reveal that soliton sheets play an important role in transferring angular momentum during the BEC merging processes. In the second numerical study, we study the two-dimensional (2D) QT in a spherical shell BEC. Although Onsager vortex (OV) clusters, which are persistent clusters of like-signed vortices, can form in the evolution of decaying 2D flat superfluid turbulence, our search for exotic OV patterns in a boundaryless 2D spherical BEC shows that OV clusters never form despite the annihilation of vortex pairs. The third topic is the numerical and experimental study of the anisotropy in thermal counterflow turbulence of He II. While turbulence in classical fluids generally becomes more homogeneous and isotropic as the scale reduces, it is theoretically predicted that counterflow turbulence can become more anisotropic in He II as the length scale reduces. Our experimental results support this idea, but our simulation results suggest the need to revise past theoretical models for this turbulence. Lastly, we numerically study electron qubits floating in a vacuum above solid neon, which is under development and has recently achieved a coherent time long enough for practical usage. We study the interaction between the electron and a small protrusion on the neon surface. Our results indicate the possibility of novel electron states spontaneously bound around the surface bump and the prospect of utilizing these states as a qubit.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bose-Einstein Condensate, Quantum Computing, Quantum Fluid, Quantum Turbulence, Superfluid

Wei Guo, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; David Collins, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Mark Sussman, University Representative; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member; Sean Dobbs, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Direct Ink Writing and Characterizations of Silicon Carbide with Boron Nitride Nanotubes Reinforcement

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In recent years, additive manufacturing (AM) has gained considerable attention for its potential to revolutionize technology through flexible, sustainable, and customized production methods. Among various AM techniques, direct ink writing (DIW) has emerged as one of the most adaptable 3D-printing techniques, offering rapid prototyping, small batch production, and on-demand manufacturing, without using expensive tooling. Silicon carbide (SiC) ceramics, known for their exceptional mechanical and thermal properties, are in high demand. With the aid of polymer-derived pyrolysis approach, DIW of SiC can be possible, facilitating the creation of a complex designed structure with reduced cost and lead times. However, during the pyrolysis process to obtain SiC ceramics, dimension shrinkage has been a critical challenge due to material decomposition and densification, inevitably leading to crack formation and structural instabilities. This research work aims to address these challenges with boron nitride nanotubes (BNNTs) reinforcement to produce 3D-printed SiC structures by using the DIW technique. The objective is to ensure the reliability and quality of 3D-printed ceramic materials, particularly in sectors like aerospace, electronics, and chemical industries, where precise dimensions, mechanical properties, and thermal performance are considered crucial. The study explores the impact of different ink viscosities on print quality and the effects of BNNT addition on the mechanical and thermal properties of 3D-printed SiC.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Zhibin Yu, Professor Directing Thesis; Tarik Dickens, Committee Member; Rebekah Sweat, Committee Member; Jizhe Cai, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Via Dolorosa

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In Via Dolorosa, The Way of Sorrows, a collection of poems, the speakers undertake a spiritual pilgrimage characterized by suffering and hope. The title is based on the devotional route in Jerusalem, also known as the Stations of the Cross, which is based on the path that Jesus took from the place of his judgment to the site of his crucifixion and burial. In this dissertation, the trail serves as an imaginal path blazed by the Paschal Mystery, a core tenet of Christianity which maintains that baptized people are incorporated into the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus as they become members of the church, known also as the Body of Christ. In these poems informed by this theological, ethical, and liturgical background, beauty and ugliness, compassion and cruelty, are held together in generative tension.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
James Kimbrell, Professor Directing Dissertation; Martin Kavka, University Representative; Barbara Hamby, Committee Member; David Kirby, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Post-Classical Sonata Forms in the Piano Works of Chopin, Schumann, Liszt, and Brahms
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Romanticism within Classicism

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Sonata form has a long history from the Baroque era to the present. Each period has displayed its own characteristics in its sonata forms. Increased inconsistency in the style of sonata forms became more noticeable after the Classical period, in particular following the death of Beethoven. This treatise will describe various sonata forms by post-Classical composers active between the 1830s to the 1850s, focusing works by Chopin, Schumann, Liszt, and Brahms. The main aspect of the treatise is a study of what may be termed "deformed" structures of sonata form, referring to the first-movement form of the sonatas. This treatise uses the theoretical taxonomy of sonata form established by Hepokoski and Darcy in "Elements of Sonata Theory: Norms, Types, And Deformations In The Late Eighteenth-Century Sonata" (2006), and also refers to a psychological and retrospective way of interpretation developed by Nicholas Cook in "Musical Form and the Listener" (1987), both of which can be helpful to understand the varied sonata forms of the Romantics. The treatise will examine musical elements including harmony, melody, rhythm, texture, and structure. I will offer a few performance suggestions based on these elements. As composers continued to explore different options in form and in purpose for their sonatas after the Classical period, there have arisen criticisms and misunderstandings about whether or not they were successful. I will show that we must view sonata forms through new lenses in the Romantic period, including identifying hybrid models that incorporate elements of the Fantasy along with traditional sonatas that follow changing philosophies both in society and for individual composers. I believe that post-Classical composers have created very successful sonata-form works, and will show some of the ways in which they accomplished that. The ultimate purpose of this treatise is to highlight the value and legitimacy of Romantically altered sonata form even if it differs from the conventionally accepted Classical form.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
Brahms, Chopin, Liszt, Romantic, Schumann, Sonata Forms
John Gainsford, Professor Directing Treatise; Enrique √Ålvarez, University Representative; Iain Quinn, Committee Member; Natalie Renee Sherer, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Integrated Optimization Models for Automobile Shipping

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The automotive industry stands as one of the most important industries in the U.S. and worldwide. As the sales of automobiles continue to increase, the demand for automobile shipping services experiences a corresponding upswing. Apart from the transportation of finished vehicles from auto manufacturers to dealerships, preowned automobile shipping has a larger presence in the automobile shipping industry, as the pre-owned car sales are almost three times as large as the new car sales. The shipping of preowned automobiles emerges in many contexts, such as individuals relocating to geographically distant locations, online car selling and home delivery, and transporting used automobiles to developing countries. Despite the significance of automobile shipping, a significant gap exists between academic research and industry practice in automobile shipping. Scholarly research only began incorporating automobile shipping optimization models in the 1990s, despite the industry's mass production dating back to the early 1900s. Highway-based automobile shipping involves various intertwined decisions, including partitioning, loading, routing, and reloading. A detailed survey of related literature reveals notable research gaps, particularly the lack of efficient algorithms for optimizing loading decisions. Some studies focused on optimizing loading decisions for given routes. None have presented an integrated model for precise routing and loading plans. Existing research prioritized routing optimization, potentially yielding suboptimal solutions without considering loading quality. There is a critical need to simultaneously address loading and routing decisions in solving the automobile shipping problem, bridging a notable literature gap. Consequently, the specific research objectives are described as follows: (a) the development of an efficient algorithm for optimizing loading decisions, and (b) the proposal of an integrated optimization method to address both auto-carrier loading and routing decisions concurrently. To achieve the first objective of this research, we investigate the impact of the degree of allowance in reloading on both solution time and overall cost efficiency in automobile shipping operations. A solution approach is developed based on a space-state network to optimize the loading decisions under various reloading policies while considering predefined auto-carrier routes. The outcomes of benchmark analysis demonstrate that the two proposed loading policies offer a favorable balance between cost efficiency and computational time. Next, an integrated optimization model is proposed that concurrently addresses routing and loading decisions, taking into consideration their interrelations. The methodology employed for solving this problem involves the utilization of a column generation-based heuristic. An essential aspect of this approach is the simultaneous evaluation of loading costs for each route, which directly influences the column generation process, thus accounting for the intricate relationship between loading and routing decisions. Furthermore, this study includes a series of comprehensive computational experiments aimed at comparing sequential and integrated optimization approaches to loading and routing optimization. The computational experiments yield compelling evidence that the proposed integrated loading and routing optimization approach consistently delivers superior outcomes within manageable computation time, particularly when addressing large problem instances. The developed integrated optimization method can be adapted for solving other optimization problems, especially those involving making sequential decisions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
auto-carrier, automobile, loading, optimization, routing, shipping
Yanshuo Sun, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eren Erman Ozguven, University Representative; Samuel A. Awoniyi, Committee Member; Omer Arda Vanli, Committee Member; Lichun Li, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Analysis of Sinkhole Morphometric Orientations and Lineament Orientations in Parts of Leon, Wakulla, Gadsden, and Jefferson Counties of Florida

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In Florida's karst terrain sinkholes pose a risk to critical infrastructure such as power plants, dams, solid waste facilities, water treatment plants, transmission lines, and chemical production plants. In-depth geologic and hydrogeologic site assessments are often required as part of regulatory permitting processes before construction. Lineament analysis is a common desktop study method used by geologic consulting companies and researchers to assess for potential subsurface geologic hazards. Consulting companies then spend considerable amounts of time and money conducting on-site investigations to assess the presence and nature of those lineaments, fracture traces, and their associated geomorphic features. High-resolution digital elevation models (DEM) created from remotely sensed light detection and ranging (LiDAR) data allow for quantitative shape analysis of sinkholes enabling an improved understanding of their geomorphology. In this research sinkhole shape analysis is explored as potential a new desktop analysis tool that can be used to assess and prioritize lineaments and the features that make them up potentially reducing costly on-site investigation time and money. Numerous authors have presented research tying sinkhole development to lineaments. With the advancement of high-resolution digital elevation models allowing morphometric studies of sinkholes, some authors have observed, though not researched, that alignment appears to exist between sinkholes' primary surface dimension axes and lineaments. For a karst terrain in north Florida, this study researched the hypothesis that sinkholes' primary surface dimension axes align with lineaments, to quantify the relationship, and use the relationship as a new conceptual method to prioritize the lineaments for future field studies. Two hundred and sixty-seven lineaments were interpreted at four different scales using a convention lineament ranking method found in literature, a qualitative ranking method, and the new percent deviation ranking method. Forty-five lineaments, 16.9%, were found to exhibit alignment with closed topographic depressions' (CTDs) primary surface dimension axes. Further, CTDs aligned with lineaments in the Tallahassee Hills Province share their orientations with surface drainage courses suggesting surface erosion controls the CTDs' orientations. In the Woodville Karst Plain Province, lineaments exhibiting alignment with CTDs appear to be influenced by regional groundwater movement in the Floridan aquifer system.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Florida, geomorphology, lineaments, morphology, morphometric, sinkholes
Ming Ye, Professor Directing Thesis; Seth A. Young, Committee Member; Maya F. Stokes, Committee Member; Jonathan D. Arthur, Committee Member.
