mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Development of PCR-Lateral Flow Assays for the Onsite Authentication of Atlantic White Shrimp and Red Snapper

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Atlantic white shrimp and red snapper are of great economic value to the United States and have implicated for species substitution which is a violation of Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act Section 403: Misbranding of food. This impacts food safety and economical activities in the seafood industry in the US. Current methods for authentication are expensive, time, and labor intensive, hence not desirable for wholesale and retail applications. We designed and validated a species-specific PCR-lateral flow assay utilizing a miniaturized and cost-effective PCR instrument with 68 shrimp, prawn and fish samples from 14 seafood species. L. setiferus was simultaneously amplified by the multiplex assay to give three visual bands, which distinguished it from other species having either one or two bands on the dipstick. To improve upon the specificity of the red snapper assay, we developed and validated a rhPCR lateral flow assay where the thermotolerant RNase H2 enzyme was included in the PCR reaction to activate the red snapper-specific rhPCR primer. Amplicons generated in the duplex rhPCR reaction were detected using dual target lateral flow strips. The standardized assay was validated with 108 barcoded fish samples from 16 finfish species. Samples identified as Lutjanus campechanus or L. purpureus by DNA barcoding formed three distinct bands, while other fish species formed only two bands on the lateral flow strips. A minimum of 0.05 ng crude DNA was needed to obtain a visible band on the lateral flow dip stick. Both assays showed 100% specificity and took 90‚Äì120 minutes for completion. Our results confirm the ability of PCR and rhPCR-lateral flow assays as an important, economical, reliable, and alternative tool for species authentication in the seafood industry to mitigate food fraud. The assay generated results that can be used to authenticate Atlantic white shrimp and red snapper at various levels of seafood processing and commerce.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Cytochrome Oxisase 1, Lateral Flow, PCR, rhPCR, RNase H2 enzyme, Seafood

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Evaluating Student Performance with Argument Mapping Software in Relation to Students' Critical Thinking Skills

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Program in Instructional Systems and Learning Technologies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate high school students' performance in analyzing complex arguments with the support of an off-the-shelf argument mapping software, Rationale‚Ñ¢, which provides diagramming tools with guided prompts. This study attempts to: 1) evaluate the quality of student's argument maps in terms of structural characteristics that equate to specific critical thinking skills measured in the Cornell Critical Thinking Test (CCTT); and 2) test for correlations between specific qualities observed in students' argument maps and their critical thinking skills measured with the CCTT. The results show that students can use argument maps to identify and analyze claims and arguments, but the quality of their analysis varies. This highlights the potential of the CAAM tool for enhancing critical thinking skills and text comprehension, but there are limitations. The weak correlation between CCTT and CAAM scores suggests that CCTT questions may not fully assess the skills needed for in-depth argument analysis. The study offers insights for future research and suggests new directions for exploring the relationship between CCTT and CAAM.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Program in Instructional Systems and Learning Technologies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Search for Meaning in Politically Motivated Music
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Rhetoric versus Pragmatics in the Zambian Political Soundscape

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study investigates the functional value of music in Zambia's political soundscape in the context of political rhetoric. It evaluates the meaning and influence of music in the political processes on the choices citizens make for supporting their preferred political parties. The study identifies rhetorical and pragmatic music as the two types of political music, which are responsible for informing the people's perspectives and the decisions they make during political elections. An examination of the influence of rhetoric and pragmatic lyrical content in Zambia demonstrates a higher acceptance of rhetorical content by and its impact on the country's election results. Furthermore, the study also elucidates various factors that contribute to the status quo, for instance, the type of lyrical content, the type of audience, the standard of creativity as well as political, and artistic motivation. The study also embraces the concept of "power of performance and the performance of power" to illustrate the varied manifestations of the power relations between politicians and musicians, and how these affect the political scene and the music industry in the country respectively. Although the analysis of politician-musician relationships reveals lopsidedness towards politicians, both entities possess undeniably significant powers to impact the political space and music creativity interchangeably in different degrees. By probing the lyrical content and influence of some of the campaign music used during selected elections, the study reveals a dominance of music with rhetorical lyrical content over that which contains pragmatic content. Additionally, the study also demonstrates that although politically motivated music contributed to the outcomes of past elections in Zambia, it is the rhetorical type that has been significantly more influential than the pragmatic kind. Zambians have since resolved to favor and embrace music that express pragmatic lyrical content over rhetoric and short-lived entertainment.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Impact, Music, Politics, Pragmatic, Rhetoric, Zambia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Using Extended Vocabulary Instruction to Support Students' Expressive Vocabulary

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of extended vocabulary instruction on the expressive vocabulary of two third-grade students with vocabulary deficits. According to the Common Core State Standards Initiative (n.d.), students in third grade should be able to determine the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade-level material, demonstrate an understanding of word relationships, make real-life connections with words and how they are used, and recognize shades of meaning among similar words. There is a relationship between vocabulary and comprehension (Ouellette, 2006). Furthermore, making inferences is also important for comprehension (Hall & Barnes, 2017). This study demonstrated the effectiveness of extended vocabulary instruction for supporting participants' target word knowledge and inferencing skills through a single-case multiple probe across word sets design. Two participants enrolled in third grade demonstrated improvements in target word knowledge growth and inferencing skills. Implications for practice are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Lindsay Dennis, Professor Directing Dissertation; Alysia Roehrig, University Representative; Nicole Patton-Terry, Committee Member; Ian Whitacre, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Human Chronotype Is Determineded by Period Oscillations
Human Chronotype Is Determined by Period Oscillations

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Circadian clocks are endogenous timekeepers, but they need to be synchronized, or entrained, with external cues such as solar time to stay in harmony with the external environment. The circadian clocks give selective advantages to humans by adapting and optimizing our body system in this 24 h living environment. These intrinsic circadian clocks intertwine with nearly all aspects of human physiology. Thus, disruption of circadian clocks is closely associated with diverse disease conditions such as metabolic, cardiovascular, and sleep diseases. Sleeping is regulated by two internal mechanisms, homeostasis and circadian rhythms. These two internal biological systems are synchronized with environmental cues to optimize the timing and duration of sleep closely related to the quality of life. More than 70 million people suffer from sleep disorders in the U.S. The deprivation of sleep interferes not only with cognitive function but also with personal mood. Specifically, circadian rhythm sleep disorders (CRSD) are caused by alterations in the endogenous circadian time-keeping system itself or a misalignment between the endogenous circadian clock and external circumstances. The CRSD patients are primarily treated by pharmacological strategies by targeting melatonin, orexin, or core clock genes. Behavioral approaches such as light exposure adjustment and scheduled feeding have reported promising outcomes. However, understanding the molecular mechanism and genetics of human CRSDs is at a very early stage. We examined the molecular mechanism of PERIOD (PER), a key factor in the circadian clock, by generating PER1-Luc and PER2-Luc cell lines using the CRISPR-mediated HDR system. This allowed us to monitor PER1/2 oscillations in real-time. Next, we targeted several key amino acids in the PAS and CKBD domains and monitored PER oscillation to identify functional sequence motifs in Per1/2. Our study revealed that PAS dimerization-induced phosphorylation is crucial for PER oscillations, leading to its translocation into the nucleus. Additionally, we explored the diverse roles of functional sequence motifs in CKBD. Deletion of FASP in-frame mutant PER1 and PER2 shortened the period, while newly synthesized FASP mutants accelerated phosphorylation and underwent hyperphosphorylation and earlier degradation. Mutants in CK1BD-A or CK1BD-B exhibited defective phosphorylation, resulting in a lengthened period. In CK1BD-B mutant PER2, hPer1 knockout disrupted phosphorylation, rendering PER2 stable and arrhythmic. Furthermore, we created PER1 and PER2 PAS B mutant mice, with Per1W448E/W448E; Per2W419E/W419E mice displaying a human FASP chronotype. These findings significantly enhance our understanding of PER's functional role in sustaining circadian clocks and regular sleep-wake cycles. We demonstrated the invaluable utility of PER-Luc reporter cell lines as a resource for studying the circadian clock. Additionally, we introduced a method for generating mutant mice with disrupted circadian rhythms. Through our approach, it becomes feasible to create mouse models mimicking human sleep disorders effortlessly. While our focus was on investigating functional sequence motifs in PER, the experimental approach employed in this study could be extended to other clock genes for studying sleep disorders.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Choogon Lee, Professor Directing Dissertation; Henry W. Bass, University Representative; Jerome Irianto, Committee Member; Yue Julia Wang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three Inequality Issues for Human Resource Management in Public and Non-Profit Organizations
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Disconnect between Policy and Implementation

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Inclusiveness has emerged as a notably significant topic within the realm of Human Resource Management (HRM), particularly in public and non-profit organizations (Riccucci, 2021). The rationale behind this growing focus is the recognition that these sectors serve diverse populations and require a workforce that not only reflects but also comprehends this diversity. Despite the recognized importance of diversity in HRM, organizations persistently struggle with including various employee needs while implementing the HRM policies, resulting in enduring inequalities and the underrepresentation of certain groups in the workplace. In light of these challenges and complexities, this dissertation delves into the under-subscribed benefits affecting underrepresented groups in public and non-profit organizations. Each essay examines the realms of employment, wage distribution, work arrangements, and retention within public and non-profit entities. Through this equity perspective, the dissertation aims to highlight the disparities and obstacles that impede the creation of inclusive workplaces. The introductory sections offer a detailed overview of these inequality subjects, shedding light on the root causes and suggesting potential strategies to cultivate a more equitable and diverse workforce.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Refining the Cycling Framework of Vanadium Isotopes in Marine Environments and the Future Application to Better Reconstruct the Ancient Marine Redox Variations

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Marine redox conditions are closely coupled with atmospheric oxygenation and essentially regulate the marine nutrient cycling (e.g., C, N, P, Fe, and S) in surficial processes, and marine life evolutions. Vast efforts have been invested, in the last decades, to reconstruct the geological marine redox perturbations, where the redox-sensitive elements, e.g., S, Mo, U, and Fe, including their sedimentary species and isotopic compositions, have been widely utilized to identify the strongly reducing conditions, i.e., anoxic conditions (oxygen- and H2S-absent water columns) and euxinic conditions (oxygen-absent yet with free H2S in the water columns). Recently, the V isotope system (50V and 51V) has emerged as a promising proxy to better constrain the previously underestimated low-oxygen environments in ancient oceans which can serve as the preceding stage of the widespread oceanic anoxia, essentially impacting the nutrient cycling pathways and casting oxygen-deprivation stress over the marine biological communities. However, research exploring the cycling of V isotopes in marine environments is still limited, thus, this dissertation research aims to: 1) better constrain the global variations of seawater V isotopic compositions (Œ¥51V); and 2) the authigenic sedimentary Œ¥51V values responding to different marine redox environments; hereafter, 3) V isotopes are applied to the relatively well-studied oceanic anoxic event 2 (OAE-2, ~ 94 million years ago), testifying the practicality of V isotopes to track the local and global marine redox fluctuations. The profiles of seawater V concentration ([V]) and isotopic composition were analyzed at ~40¬∞S South Atlantic Ocean off the west African coast. The sampling profiles, spanning from ~ 5 m to ~ 4500 m, intersected nearly all the major water masses, thus experiencing different and complicated circulations. The results show relatively homogeneous seawater [V] and Œ¥51V values in deep oceans below the euphotic zone (> ~100 m), providing the most robust dataset that V behaves with conservative cycling in the deep oceans, excluding the more negative Œ¥51V value in the Antarctic Bottom Water, which likely reflects regional influence from weathering input into the Antarctic continental margin. Such a negative shifting seems only local rather than extensive influence as suggested by the spatially consistent Œ¥51V values of oxic sediments deposited in different ocean basins. On the other hand, local/regional processes such as the weathering inputs in near-coastal areas and severely restricted basins and the biological uptake of V in surface seawater can cause potential shiftings of the seawater Œ¥51V values up to ~0.3‚Ä∞. The pore fluid [V] values and the sedimentary metal element concentrations and Œ¥51V values were studied in a setting of marine depositional environments along the California-Mexican oxygen minimum zone. The studied sites present major depositional variations in benthic redox conditions from oxic to anoxic and organic carbon burial rates varying between 0.08 8.4 mmol/(m2¬∑day). It shows that the authigenic sedimentary Œ¥51V signatures are primarily controlled by the benthic redox conditions, likely seeing the isotopic signature in the redox-controlling partition of vanadate and vanadyl species and subsequent scavenging processes, with more positive values documented in more reducing environments. The mineralogy of Mn and Fe oxides likely yields secondary impacts in oxic environments, with more negative authigenic sedimentary Œ¥51V values observed in Mn oxide-rich sediments. Furthermore, profiles of the pore fluid [V] and the sedimentary elemental authigenesis indicate potential remobilization and redistribution of authigenic sedimentary V, which is mainly governed by the pore fluid redox gradients, whereas the invariant authigenic sedimentary Œ¥51V values from surface sediments to depth at individual sites propose limited alterations of original signals by post-depositional diagenesis. Based on the fundamental framework of V cycling in modern marine environments, V isotopes were applied to three relatively well-studied sites documenting the OAE-2 event. At the Tarfaya Basin site and the tropical proto-North Atlantic Basin site, the authigenic sedimentary Œ¥51V profiles present variations plotting in the anoxic-to-euxinic conditions, consistent with previous biogeochemical evidence. In contrast, the Demerara Rise site presents pronounced authigenic sedimentary Œ¥51V variabilities, indicating wobbling benthic redox conditions between the low-oxygen conditions to the euxinic conditions. Especially, the negative Œ¥51V perturbations pointing to more oxic benthic conditions coincide with the reappearances of the low-oxygen-tolerant benthic foraminifers. Such short-term variations to more oxic benthic conditions allowing for the proliferation of opportunistic benthic faunas are not tracked by previous geochemical proxies, owing to redox sensitivities and/or complicated burial mechanisms. Altogether, our research provided an improved cycling framework of V isotopes in marine environments, allowing for more explicit interpretations of ancient sedimentary Œ¥51V records. Coupling with previous geochemical tools, this further allows for refining ancient temporospatial marine redox variabilities and associated nutrient cycling and biological perturbations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reading the Wings Mid-Flight
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Tripartite Exploration of Self-Reflection in Eudaimonic Entertainment Experiences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation is positioned within the area of positive media psychology and embarks on an in-depth exploration of self-reflection in eudaimonic entertainment experiences. The dissertation project is structured into three studies employing mixed methods, each contributing unique insights and findings to the overarching theme. Study 1, as a correlational study, looks at the big picture at the beginning. It develops an integrative scale of general engagement in eudaimonic entertainment experiences (GE4) and identifies a significant positive correlation between GE4 and tendencies for self-reflection Notably, it is recognized that self-reflection plays an effective role in bridging engagement in eudaimonic entertainment experiences to self-care outcomes, such as self-compassion, authenticity, and overall psychological well-being. Delving further into the realm of self-reflection, Study 2 adopts a qualitative approach to explore how self-reflection processes are facilitated by resonance with eudaimonic entertainment media content. Utilizing a phenomenology lens, the research explores the generators and characteristics of biographic and psychological resonance. Individuals resonate with portrayals of human virtues, especially when these align with their internal value systems, beliefs, and experiences. This resonance induces a series of self-reflective processes, which encompass reflecting on personal understanding and practices of virtues and envisioning an ideal self that embodies these virtues. Building on the insights obtained from the previous studies, Study 3 examines the potential positive outcomes of self-reflection within eudaimonic entertainment experiences. Specifically, it focuses on how individuals high in moral identity resonate with moral beauty, which further reinforces the moral ideal self and enhances autonomous prosocial motivations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Autonomous prosocial motivations, Eudaimonic entertainment experiences, Moral ideal self, Moral identity, Resonance, Self-reflection

Arthur Raney, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Katherine Dale, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Rachel Bailey, Committee Member; Arienne Ferchaud, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Artistic Evocations
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Inspiration and Impressions in Piano Works by Claude Debussy, Huang Ruo, and Liang Lei

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study explores a selection of solo piano works by the well-known French composer, Claude Debussy, and two contemporary Chinese composers, Huang Ruo and Liang Lei. The selected works demonstrate inspiration and impressions from various types of artworks, namely Oriental paintings and lacquer, an ancient story from Zen Buddhism, and Chinese folk songs. The document consists of two parts. The first part contains a brief biography of Debussy, Impressionist stylistic features, and musical techniques employed in Images I and Images II that represent the essence and characteristics of Debussian music, along with a descriptive analysis of each piece in the two sets. The second part provides biographical information about Huang Ruo and Liang Lei and literature related to the art objects that inspired their works. This section also details musical approaches and ideas employed by the two composers that deliver their distinct aesthetics and unique personal messages through their individual musical languages.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
Claude Debussy, Contemporary composers, Huang Ruo, Images I & II, Liang Lei, Piano

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Near-Threshold Resonance in 11B and the Puzzle of an Exotic Decay

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The study of near-threshold resonances in weakly bound systems is an exciting topic in experimental and theoretical nuclear physics since they provide important information on the interaction of discrete states with the continuum. Recent theoretical developments aim to describe the continuum interaction. However, questions on the behavior, structure, and properties of the many-body systems close to the particle emission threshold remain open, making the experimental studies of near-threshold states and their characteristics crucial for constraining theoretical efforts. In particular, a near-threshold proton resonance in ¬π¬πB has long been sought since it would provide a less exotic explanation to the controversial observation of the unexpectedly large Œ≤-p+ branching ratio in ¬π¬πBe. In this dissertation, we discuss two recent experiments at the John D. Fox Superconducting Linear Accelerator Laboratory at Florida State University. In the first one, a near-threshold proton state was observed at a resonance energy of 211 keV in ¬π¬πB via the ¬π‚Å∞Be(d,n)¬π¬πB reaction. In the second, results from the experiment realized using the Enge Split-Pole Spectrograph (SPS) at FSU where the alpha decay from ¬π¬πB was studied with the ‚Å∑Li(‚Å∑Li,t)¬π¬πB reaction will also be presented.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Sergio Almaraz-Calderon, Professor Directing Thesis; Munir Humayun, University Representative; Peter Hoeflich, Committee Member; Alexander Volya, Committee Member; Ingo Ludwig M. Wiedenhover, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Extending the Application of Genetic Algorithms from Scale-Shortening to Factor-Scale Construction
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Illustration Employing the Triarchic Model of Psychopathy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A genetic algorithm (GA) is a machine learning optimization technique inspired by evolutionary principles that, in psychometric contexts, has exclusively been applied to abbreviate established measures. Nevertheless, GAs are flexible tools that can be leveraged to develop new measures for indexing target constructs, by using latent factors of a measurement model as empirical representations of those constructs and sampling from an available item pool to find a subset of items that optimally approximate those latent factors. To illustrate this novel application of a GA, the current study used a modified GA to develop new scales for indexing the trait dimensions of the triarchic model of psychopathy (i.e., boldness, meanness, disinhibition; Patrick et al., 2009), using factor scores derived from a latent variable model of those dimensions as referents. The GA evaluated and selected item subsets from the Elemental Psychopathy Assessment (EPA; Lynam et al., 2011) based on their ability to efficiently capture variance in the target constructs (i.e., factor scores representing latent boldness, meanness, and disinhibition), with consideration given to scale intercorrelations and item polarity. Structural analytic and item modeling methods were then used to refine the GA-derived measures. The final 17-item EPA-Boldness, 19-item EPA-Meanness, and 20-item EPA-Disinhibition scales significantly correlated with their counterpart factor scores, and when entered as scale indicators of those factors in a latent variable model, exhibited the strongest loadings relative to other established triarchic scales.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Christopher J. Patrick, Professor Directing Thesis; Jessica Ribeiro, Committee Member; Chris Schatschneider, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Evaluation of Parameter Estimates and Standard Errors in Exploratory Factor Analysis with Ordered Categorical Data

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In education and psychology, exploratory factor analysis (EFA) is mainly used in scale development or refinement. To select a final EFA model, researchers take into account not only the number of factors, but also parameter estimates along with their standard errors (SEs). Previous methodological studies in EFA have mainly focused on methods for determining the number of factors. Some studies have focused on parameter estimation with continuous data when the number of factors is "correct". No studies have considered determination of the number of factors and evaluated parameter estimation for the EFA model with categorical data. The goal of this study is to evaluate the parameter estimation for the chosen EFA model when the optimal model is selected and when a non-optimal model is selected. In this study, I used statistical extraction approaches to examining parameter estimates and standard errors for EFA models with ordered categorical data via a Monte Carlo simulation study and demonstrated the methods using empirical data. In the simulation study, a variety of conditions were manipulated: the presence of minor factors, the magnitudes of factor loadings, the magnitude of factor correlations, sample sizes, the number of measurement indicators, the number of response categories, and the distribution of ordinal variables. Weighted least squares with mean and variance adjustment (WLSMV) and unweighted least squares with mean and variance adjustment (ULSMV) estimation methods were applied to analyze data. The chi-square statistics and two commonly used fit indices were used for model evaluation and model comparison to determine the final model. In the empirical study, data with three samples with sizes of 150, 300 and 600 which were randomly drawn from the 2019 Florida Standards Assessments for measuring English Language Arts (ELA) achievement of grade 4 students were used. Results from the simulation study showed that the optimal model was more likely to be chosen when the sample size was larger or when the true population model had a higher factor loading, a lower factor correlation, more measurement indicators, or a great number of response categories. When the optimal model was selected, the factor loadings and factor correlations were mostly accurately estimated when the true factor correlation was 0 but were severely underestimated when the true factor correlation was large (.5). The standard errors for factor loadings were substantially underestimated while the standard errors for factor correlations were substantially overestimated in most conditions. Parameter estimates and their standard errors were mainly impacted by the magnitude of the true factor loading or the true factor correlation. When the final model contained too few factors, the factor loading patterns were distorted. When the final model contained too many factors, the factor loading patterns for four of the factors were very similar to the factor loading pattern for major factors of the true model. The standard errors for indicators loaded on additional factors can be larger than the standard errors for indicators loaded on the four factors. Having small loading estimates and large standard errors for indicators for a factor could be a sign that this factor is a spurious factor. The empirical data were obtained from the grade 4 ELA data of 2019 FSA. All data were dichotomous. Eleven indicators measuring three areas of grade 4 ELA were chosen for the demonstration. The results were consistent with the findings from the simulation study. The model with the correct number of factors was selected as the final model when the sample size was large (i.e., 600). As the sample size increased, the factor loading patterns were closer to those of the correct model. Overall, the magnitude of factor loading, magnitude of factor correlation, sample size, the number of measurement indicators, and the number of response categories impacted the selection rates and the parameter estimation for EFA under most conditions. WLSMV and ULSMV performed similarly in estimating the parameters and standard errors, but WLSMV performed slightly better than ULSMV in selecting the optimal model under most conditions. The fit indices outperformed the chi-square statistics in selecting the optimal model as the final model. Findings from my study can help empirical researchers better understand the accuracy of parameter estimates and standard errors under different conditions in EFA when the optimal number of factors is selected, and the factor loading patterns when a suboptimal number of factors is selected. As a result, researchers can make better decisions in selecting the optimal model.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Yanyun Yang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Fred Huffer, University Representative; Russell Almond, Committee Member; Betsy Jane Becker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Potential Undoing Effects of Positive Math Attitudes on the Math Anxiety-Math Performance Relation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: It is widely accepted that math anxiety leads to poor math performance and therefore it is important to understand what factors might reduce this relation in order to inform the development of potentially effective interventions. Drawing on Fredrickson's broaden-and-build Theory‚Äîwhich posits that positive emotions broaden cognitive processes and build enduring personal resources‚ÄîI hypothesized that positive math attitudes, specifically interest and confidence, may alleviate the negative relation between math anxiety and performance. Using Structural Equation Modeling, I analyzed data from two samples of elementary school children (ns = 305 and 2872), spanning kindergarten through third grade. I also accounted for gender and age and tested whether relations look different at different ages. The results showed that contrary to initial expectations, positive math attitudes did not alleviate math anxiety's negative relation with performance. Instead, it was found that while math confidence generally relates to improved math performance, especially for older students, high confidence did not buffer the negative relation between math anxiety and math performance. In fact, the opposite was true, students at all confidence levels performed worse as their anxiety levels rose, but this relation was most pronounced for students with higher math confidence, a trend consistent across ages. On the other hand, math interest did not alter the anxiety-performance relationship and was negatively associated with performance, suggesting that increased interest, after accounting for math anxiety and confidence, is associated with poorer math achievement. These findings provide a nuanced understanding of the complex interplay between math attitudes, anxiety, and performance in this specific age group, underscoring the need for targeted interventions to specifically address math anxiety.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Fredrickson's Broaden-and-Build Theory, Interaction, Math anxiety, Math Confidence, Math Interest, Math performance
Colleen Ganley, Professor Directing Thesis; Robert Schoen, Committee Member; Tehila Nugiel, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Effects of Future Land Use Land Cover and Climate Change on Hillsborough County

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Changes in land use/land cover (LULC) and climate (CC) are expected to affect watershed hydrology in the future. LULC change due to urbanization and forest loss will result in more impervious surfaces and less soil infiltration, while CC will result in unprecedented rainfall patterns and subsequently larger runoffs. Combined together, such changes affect flood hazards and endanger local communities and physical infrastructure. To preserve natural hydrology and protect against these negative impacts, watershed models can be used to evaluate watershed response in terms of runoff under various LULC and CC scenarios. Despite past research on estimating such changes, studies in urban watersheds have been limited. Urban watersheds have several important details such as underground infrastructure and river/land management practices that call for high-resolution watershed models to predict the impacts of LULC and CC. In this research, a high-resolution watershed model‚ÄîPersonal Computer Storm Water Management Model (PCSWMM)‚Äîwas utilized to predict the individual and joint impacts of LULC changes and CC on surface runoff attributes (peak and volume) across the 369.9 km2 Hillsborough Watershed in Midwest Florida. My main research question was how LULC and CC affect surface runoff attributes (volume and peak) in urban watersheds? The relationships between LULC, CC and runoff attributes were also investigated to determine what stressors are most responsible for the changes and what watersheds are mostly sensitive to such nonstationary changes. The study watershed included 3,800 subwatersheds, which differ in terms of the drainage area, ground slope, imperviousness and LULC distribution. I studied six synthetic design rainfall events (5- to 500-year return periods) with 24-hour duration under historical and future (year 2070) climate and LULC. The PCSWMM was validated against multiple historical rainfall events. I then evaluated the response of the subwatersheds to the design rainfall events using the validated PCSWMM. The case study results indicated that, overall, CC has a greater impact on runoff attributes than LULC change. We also found that LULC and CC induced changes in runoff are more pronounced in greater return periods and watersheds with smaller drainage area, hilly slope and greater historical imperviousness. This research helps urban planners and floodplain managers identify the required actions and strategies to protect urban watersheds against future LULC change and CC.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Climate Change, Land Use Land Cover, PCSWMM, Peak Runoff, Runoff Volume
Ebrahim Ahmadisharaf, Professor Directing Thesis; Nasrin Alamdari, Committee Member; Xiaijun Yang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Applying Graph Neural Networks to Applications
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Brain Disease Detection, Recommendation and Fraud Detection

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Graph-structured data widely exists in the real world, including biomedical, e-commerce, and social areas. The graph-structured data contains objects and relationships among them, which refer to nodes and edges in the graph, respectively. Typically, to learn the information from graphs, we need to leverage both nodes and edges, which is hard for those traditional methods designed for i.i.d. since they do not capture the dependencies among data instances. Recently, graph neural networks (GNNs) have attracted increasing attention since they solve the drawbacks of traditional neural networks when dealing with graph-structured data. Empowered by the GNNs, research has extended to many areas that use graph data to model the interactions and get better results. Despite the success of GNNs in general tasks like node classification, more work is needed to handle task-specific problems. Typically, when facing various downstream tasks, GNNs often adopt sufficient changes according to the characteristics of the datasets for tasks and incorporate domain knowledge as well. The dissertation includes my research works on applying graph neural networks to brain disease detection, recommendation, and fraud detection. Since GNNs often lack interpretability and require node features, for brain disease detection, I focus on improving the interpretability of GNNs and learning the structural features without node features in Chapter 3. For recommendation, I focus on problems like modeling users' changing preferences based on pure historical interactions between users and items through time and the intrinsical oscillation problem brought by the bipartite nature of user-item graphs. In Chapter 4, I make dynamic recommendations by analyzing the historical data based on the life cycles of users and items. In Chapter 5, I discuss the oscillation problem, varying locality, and fixed propagation pattern for user-item bipartite graphs and provide an analysis of the propagation of GNNs. For fraud detection, I focus on solving camouflage and class imbalance problems. In Chapter 6, I analyze how the camouflage violates the "homophily'' assumption of GNNs and how it affects the learning process of GNNs first, and then propose a model that decouples the learning process of feature learning and structure learning. In Chapter 7, I alleviate the class imbalance problem by augmenting synthesized nodes that mimic the behaviors of real fraudsters. The nodes and their neighborhoods are automatically generated by the feature and edge generators, respectively. Our experimental results show that adding a few nodes to the original graph can improve the performance of the original GNN-based fraud detector. Lastly, I provide a conclusion about this dissertation in the final chapter.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Brain Disease Detection, Fraud Detection, Graph Neural Networks, Recommendation

Jiawei Zhang, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Xiaonan Zhang, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Adrian Barbu, University Representative; Xiuwen Liu, Committee Member; Peixiang Zhao, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Improving the Robustness of Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Meta-analysis is a widely used tool for synthesizing results from multiple studies. As such, it plays an essential role in evidence-based medicine and clinical decision-making. However, a few concerns may seriously affect the validity of the conclusion from systematic reviews and meta-analyses, as well as the robustness of decision-making. One critical problem in meta-analyses and systematic reviews is that outlying studies are frequently included, which can bias the results of synthesizing evidence. Outliers may be caused by several factors, such as study selection criteria, low study quality, etc. Although outlier detection is well-studied in the statistical community, limited attention has been paid to meta-analysis. Another major concern is publication bias or small-study effects, which is led by the phenomenon that studies with statistically significant results are more likely to be published than those with non-significant results. Several SE-based and sample-size-based regression tests were proposed to assess small-study effects and publication bias. However, studies' direction and sample size calculation are rarely accounted for. This dissertation aims to address these problems and strengthen the validity of systematic reviews and meta-analyses. For outlying studies, we propose a sensitivity analysis using an iterative framework with bagging to detect outlying studies efficiently and make valid inferences. Simulation studies showed that the iterative method can produce less bias, higher coverage probability, and better detection accuracy. Insights from a statistical perspective can be provided for further analyses. For small-study effects and publication bias, we propose a directional test to control type I error rates and improve the statistical power. The directional test can better control the type I error rates and produce higher power than the other competitors. Furthermore, we use a simulation study that takes account of sample size calculation to illustrate the unaddressed issue in sample-size-based regression tests for publication bias. The inflated type I error rates indicate that the underlying assumptions and the good properties of the sample-size-based tests may be challenged.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Direction, Iterative method, Meta-analysis, Outlier, Publication bias, Sample size calculation

Xufeng Niu, Professor Directing Thesis; Zhe He, University Representative; Chong Wu, Committee Member; Lifeng Lin, Committee Member; Fred William Huffer, Committee Member; Andres Felipe Barrientos, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Convention, Madness, and the Unruly Heroine in Two American Operas
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Libby Larsen's Clair De Lune and Daron Hagen's Amelia

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation examines the portrayals of unconventional and "unruly" female characters in two American operas of the late-twentieth and early-twenty-first centuries, Clair de Lune (1984) by Libby Larsen and Patricia Hampl, and Amelia (2010) by Daron Hagen, Gardner McFall, and Stephen Wadsworth. I explore how these recent works variously reflect, embody, and undermine the art form's historically problematic depictions of such women. Although one of opera's central pillars is its adoration and exhibition of the feats achievable by the female voice, female opera characters, particularly those who threaten the societal conventions depicted onstage, are consistently manipulated, sabotaged, and often violently removed before the final curtain falls. As my case studies demonstrate, the figure of the transgressive operatic heroine continues to captivate composers and librettists as they choose to center such a figure in their works. Clair de Lune and Amelia are each set in the twentieth-century United States and comprise largely historical and realistic plots. Both operas also feature an aviatrix as a major character. The presence of an aviatrix allows me to examine an atypical operatic character and an operatic portrayal of an exceptional kind of woman, as well as differing representations of flight in each work. These operas celebrate women who reject external attempts to control them; more importantly, perhaps, the women emerge from their respective plots alive and in some state of self-possession. Although each opera depicts a heroine who transgresses societal pressures, the ways in which the two operas treat her and the resolution she reaches by the final curtain articulate differing perspectives on the genre's historical treatment of women. These two works demonstrate an art form continuing to wrestle with its legacy, with differing degrees of success. Clair de Lune and Amelia reflect numerous ways in which opera's past casts a long shadow. Each opera reckons with inherited conventions, variously commenting upon, critiquing, or embracing them as a model. Each enacts self-conscious references to opera's history through quotation, satire, and structure. I focus particularly on how each opera engages with the operatic convention of the mad scene, and I explore how these portrayals are tied to a complex medico-cultural history of female hysteria. Within these sites of inquiry, I question the ways in which contemporary opera is still beholden to legacies of the past, and I explicate how these works speak to opera's potential and future as a vibrant and empowering art form that variously challenges or embraces the traditional roles of its women.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Aviatrix, Convention, Daron Hagen, Libby Larsen, Madness, Opera
Denise Von Glahn, Professor Directing Dissertation; Leigh H. Edwards, University Representative; Sarah Eyerly, Committee Member; Douglass Seaton, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Music Therapy Master's Equivalency
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Synthesis of Current University Websites

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine the current state of music therapy master's equivalency (MTME) university websites with the goals of identifying what information is publicly available, the user-friendliness of these websites, and make research-based conclusions on the potential user experience of the public and prospective students on MTME websites. A descriptive emphasis was placed on current graduate level music therapy admissions, available degree program information, and overall website design. Additionally, the objective experience while examining websites was documented and analyzed. Universities (N=37) were identified using the American Music Therapy Association's (AMTA) organization directory search (American Music Therapy Association, n.d.-g). The qualifier 'equivalency masters offered' was applied to identify universities offering MTME programs. The results of this study identified the current availability of MTME degree programs and their distribution across the United States. Nearly half of the universities examined offered additional non-music therapy related training which are referred to as 'music therapy plus' by the researcher. Further results revealed a majority of MTME websites had unclear or unlisted projected program timelines. Similarly, a majority of MTME programs did not publish music therapy handbooks, information on field specific materials or additional costs, or define the tuition type for their program's equivalency portion (either undergraduate or graduate credit hours). Finally, the researcher's objective experience collecting data revealed that on average it took 14 minutes to find information needed on each MTME university website, and in total, 220 clicks (individual URLs) were recorded to research all MTME programs examined. Findings may provide insight for future online recruitment and public communication in music therapy education. Moreover, the findings may be useful to assess areas of university website improvements to support a user-friendly experience for the public and prospective students who may be new to the field of music therapy. Further results and implications are discussed within this thesis.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Music Therapy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
Lori Gooding, Professor Directing Thesis; Jayne Standley, Committee Member; Flor del Cielo Hernandez, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Neutron Spectroscopy Studies Using (d,n) and (3He, n) Reactions

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Reaction rates are critical in understanding the nuclear evolution of stellar environments suchas Classical Novae and Type I X-ray Bursts. Nuclear properties of the neutron-deficient nucleus 18Ne are needed to reduce uncertainties in the reaction rate calculations of the sequence 14O(Œ±,p)17F(p,Œ≥)18Ne, which leads to breakout from the HCNO cycle. This thesis presents the results of branching ratio measurements of resonance states in 18Ne through the SiO(3He,n) re- action at E3He = 15 MeV. The 28Si(3He,n)30S reaction at E3He = 15 MeV was also measured to subtract the 30S contribution. Excited states of 18Ne at Eex. = 5.17 MeV, Eex. = 6.15 MeV, Eex. = 6.31 MeV, Eex. = 6.93 MeV, Eex. = 7.32 MeV, and Eex. = 7.87 MeV were analyzed, and their decay branching ratios were extracted. Using these branching ratios, new reaction rate parameters were determined for calculations of the 14O(Œ±,p)17F reaction for a temperature range of T = 0.1-5 GK, typical of Type I X-ray Bursts. These measurements were performed at the John D. Fox Laboratory at Florida State University using the CATRiNA neutron detector array in conjunction with the CHARON silicon detector array for coincidences between neutrons and charged particles. A method for extracting neutron energies without relying on time-of-flight information, called "spectrum unfolding", and a full characterization of the CATRiNA neutron detector array through reactions 9Be(d,n) and 27Al(d,n) are also presented. Furthermore, differential cross sections from low-lying excited states of 13N through the 12C(d,n)13N reaction were extracted using "spectrum unfolding" and time-of-flight information. The differences between the methods are discussed. The 9Be(d,n), 27Al(d,n), and 12C(d,n)13N were all measured at the Edwards Accelerator Laboratory at Ohio University.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
neutron detectors, nuclear physics, reaction rate calculations, spectrum unfolding

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: (Re)Framing Memory
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Stories of the Vietnam War in Contemporary American Art

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Although the Vietnam War officially ended on April 30, 1975, the destruction it yielded and the diaspora that followed continue to haunt those directly affected by it. Remembering trauma through storytelling has proven supportive of individual and shared healing, but how can such lived experiences, which remain at odds with established narratives, be legitimized, much less preserved? Despite renewed scholarly interest in the art of protest made in reaction to the Vietnam War, no publication has engaged with postwar artistic representations of this history. Also missing in the art historical scholarship is the study of an artwork informed by storytelling. My project combines a narratological approach with memory studies to examine how An-My L√™'s Small Wars (1999 ‚Äì 2002), Jessica Hines's My Brother's War (2006-2020), and Tiffany Chung's Remapping History: an autopsy of a battle, an excavation of a man's past (2015 ‚Äì 18) reconstruct fragmented and secondary memories into photo-based, diaristic narratives. Through building on the scholarship of landscape, documentary, and vernacular photography, I demonstrate how each artist stylistically refers to these genres to give form to acts of remembering and the conditions of displacement, grief, and loss. What results from these narratives are gaps, which arguably speak to the voices and stories excluded from official narratives of the war. Not only do Small Wars, My Brother's War, and Remapping History attest to the transnational significance of photography as a medium where artistic traditions, geopolitical histories, and cultural heritages converge, but they also promote a more inclusive memory of the war that highlights the plurality of American history.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Diaspora, Memory, Photography, Postmemory, Vietnam War, Vietnamese American studies
Karen Bearor, Professor Directing Dissertation; Guenter Kurt Piehler, University Representative; Adam Jolles, Committee Member; Kristin Dowell, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Tensor-Based Methods and Machine Learning
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Small Sample Set Pattern Recognition

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: With today's trend toward ever growing amounts of data, deep learning approaches are increasingly deployed with impressive success, notably in image recognition and time series classification applications. State of the art performance of deep neural networks (DNNs) and related variants is often highly dependent upon the availability of a relatively large and diverse labeled training data set; several well-known deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) were trained with over a million images for example, in large scale image recognition. For machine learning models which may not be considered "deep" neural networks, a relatively large training set remains a key factor in how well these models perform when trained "from scratch". Yet, in numerous important applications, very large labeled training data sets simply may not be available. Examples include certain medical applications, and specialized remote imaging in intelligence and military applications. Applying conventional or deep machine learning models, or adapting deep learning models in these cases, can involve particular challenges given the model complexity and tendency for overfitting often encountered with smaller data sets. Further, certain techniques to mitigate overfitting issues such as data augmentation can involve additional challenges due to the nature of the data: suitable augmentation may not involve just simple geometric transformations, and it may be difficult to represent the data distribution. On the other hand, utilizing transfer learning first requires the existence of a potentially suitable pre-trained deep learning model which can be adapted, and second, that the original large training data set for that pre-trained model is sufficiently similar to the data in the smaller set of interest. In data sets of the type we consider here, lack of a suitable model pre-trained using a large similar training data set is a definite possibility. Apart from overfitting aspects, identifying an optimal structure for the model is also a very significant consideration with smaller data sets; overall, a great deal of model customization and trial-and-error may be necessary where small data sets are concerned. The focus then is specifically on data sets which fall under the scenario just outlined, and the primary objective is finding an effective solution for classification which avoids many of the issues involved with a highly complex model. An example in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) automatic target recognition (ATR) is the "moving and stationary target acquisition and recognition" imaging set approved for public release by AFRL for research purposes. This radar imaging collection has relatively small training set, ranging from approximately 200 to 300 examples of a given target or variant under various conditions. Further, characteristics of radar imaging such as random scattering and reflection, speckle, and influence of background complicate automatic target recognition. Deep learning models from the literature devised for this application, or often adapted from conventional optical image recognition, produce high ATR accuracy, but are very complex, highly customized, generally require extensive provisions to mitigate overfitting, and some may fail to fully address background influence which, for this imaging set, can produce results which are overly optimistic. In this dissertation, a tensor-based approach is utilized to address the SAR ATR problem as an alternative with far fewer parameters, lower complexity, little customization, and taking into account the imaging background influence; further, this approach can naturally exploit multiple image views in this application to enhance ATR performance. We examine versions of the tensor Tucker decomposition, utilizing truncated HOSVD, sequentially truncated HOSVD, and higher order orthogonal iteration for single image view and multiple image view approaches. We show that tensor-based methods can offer a very attractive alternative to complex machine learning models for this SAR imaging application, highlighting a class of methods which may warrant consideration in other applications involving limited training data, where high complexity machine learning models may be difficult to adapt.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Challenging Assumptions
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Exploring the Extent of Biophilic Design in Interior Environments on Attention Restoration

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Interior Architecture and Design

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The use of direct attention ‚Äì one's ability to devote cognitive resources to planning, comprehension, and reflection ‚Äì emerged from the adaptive need to respond and attend to environmental stimuli. The constant calls to awareness presented by entertainment technologies and urban landscapes in the modern context contributes to the issue of individuals experiencing excessive cognitive fatigue or attention deficits. Attention Restoration Theory (ART) empirically and subjectively finds that the love of connecting with the natural world, or biophilia, facilitates the restoration of directed attention. Attention Restoration Theory also presents ten properties from a person-environment perspective that distinguish experiences as restorative. However, little is known regarding how much nature exposure is beneficial for attention restoration in interior environments, leaving much to be learned about how Attention Restoration Theory manifests in practical applications like schools, offices, and hospitals. This prompts the question, to what degree do multisensory outdoor biophilic environments restore attention? To what degree do multisensory biophilic interior environments restore attention? The challenge of directed attention deficits in the world today also impacts college students. This study used a mixed methods approach to further understand the critical threshold of nature exposure needed to see a positive impact on attention spans. While this line of research requires further investigation given the small sample size, the experiment and post-test questionnaire suggest that the highest degree of nature exposure is not necessarily the most effective environmental condition to restore attention deficits. Additionally, individuals who referenced a mindfulness practice scored significantly higher in all groups, regardless of degree of nature exposure. To this effect, the confluence of study findings and existing literature review on Attention Restoration Theory, embodied cognition, and biophilic patterns offered intentional frameworks to revitalize an educational space intended for sustaining and refreshing the directed attention spans of students.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Interior Architecture and Design in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
attention deficit, attention restoration, biophilia, environment, interior design, soft fascination
Stephanie Sickler, Professor Directing Thesis; Yelena McLane, Committee Member; Meghan Mick, Committee Member; Jill Pable, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Run for Something Bigger than Yourself
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Experiences of Group Dynamics in Collegiate Cross Country Athletes Competing in Track and Field

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Minimal research has investigated the group dynamics of individual sport teams. The social interdependence theory, as well as the current body of literature on individual sport teams, suggest that cross country and track and field are structurally unique from each other. However, an understanding of how teammates may experience the differences of competing in two individual sport teams is absent from the literature. The purpose of the current study was to contribute a contextualized examination of the experiences of group dynamics in collegiate cross country athletes competing in track and field to the body of literature. Therefore, a conceptual framework of group dynamics in sport is introduced to describe the factors influencing emergent states, group structures, and group processes. Data were collected through five focus group interviews with three women's and two men's teams from four NCAA Division II programs and one NCAA Division III program. A reflexive thematic analysis guided the interpretation of the data, in which three themes and seven subthemes were developed. The first theme represents participants' perceptions of their individual contributions to their cross country and track and field teams, titled "my contributions to these teams aren't always the same" and consists of two subthemes (a) "I run for something bigger than myself" and (b) "it is me over we‚Ä¶ unless we have a chance". The second theme represents participants' experiences of cross country, titled "we are all in this together‚Ä¶ until the end" and consists of three subthemes: (a) "it's in the beginning that "we" become 'us'", (b) "our training brings us together", and (c) "all eyes on 'the' team". The third, and final, theme represents participants' experiences of group dynamics in track and field, titled "we are not all we have, but we are all we really need" and consists of two subthemes: (a) "we bring history" and (b) "we would have it differently if we could". The findings suggest that the unique structure of cross country and track and field distinguishes teammate interaction and determines individual and team outcomes between sports. Researchers are encouraged to more closely investigate the nuances of group dynamics in individual sport teams. Although cross country athletes also compete in track and field, the current study supports the need for specialized application-based research for cross country and track and field, respectively. Consequently, individual sport teams should be considered as separate entities in research and practice.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Collegiate Cross Country and Track and Field, Group Dynamics, Individual Sport Teams, Reflexive Thematic Analysis, Structural Interdependence
Svenja A. Wolf, Professor Directing Thesis; David W. Eccles, Committee Member; Michael D. Giardina, Committee Member; Megan Buning, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Testament of Spring

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Testament of Spring is composed for orchestra in the Rondo form which employs both of tonality and atonality. It was originally inspired by a subheading from Î¶¨ÌÉÄÏùò Ï†ïÏõê(Rita's Garden), the Korean essay book written by Ahn Rita. The subheading is that all the seasons were testaments/last wills. In order to develop the initial inspiration to the specified theme for the musical work, I wrote a Korean poem, "Î¥ÑÏùò Ïú†Ïñ∏(Testament of Spring)." The musical piece focuses on the spring season among four seasons, and describes the testament of spring meaning the unreturnable past. Along with that, the musical piece implies a positive message that we can draw a better future/spring for those who are suffering from the trauma or sad memories in the past. Testament of Spring is a five-part Rondo form. The first section is a refrain with a theme having a pitch center. Beginning with a triangle refers to the Korean traditional music, Ï¢ÖÎ¨òÏ†úÎ°ÄÏïÖ(The Royal Ancestral Ritual in the Jongmyo Shrine and its Music) which has two different percussion instruments for the start and the end. To indicate the infinity of time, the percussion at the end is not used in this musical piece. It gradually builds up three pitch centers, A, C, and E throughout the section. Along with the A pitch-centered part, a motivic melody is introduced by oboe, which is inspired by traditional Korean music. The second section is the first episode consisting of four subsections. The first and second subsections are written with a three-beat dance which contains an unexpected time change from time to time. The second and fourth subsections are written with an expanded fragmentation of the second episode. The third section is similar to the first section, but it ends on A flat. It is a transition to the fourth section which is written in A flat major. Also, "Autumn Leaves" is quoted to emphasize the refrains' references to the returning springs. The last section unfolds differently from the previous refrains. While it still has the pitch centers, they are more moving along the contour of melody that I borrowed from "The Lord is My Shepherd" which is a Catholic hymn composed by a Korean nun, Gu Myung Rim. The duration of this piece is about 15 minutes.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Elementary Stem Teachers' Digital Curation for Lesson Planning

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Careful lesson planning is essential in elementary STEM education because the crucial role of STEM education at the elementary level is to help students develop fundamental skills employed in real life as a foundation for future learning. This study examined how elementary STEM teachers curate digital resources for lesson planning and the relevant factors impacting their digital curation. A qualitative multiple-case study was employed to explore elementary STEM teachers' digital curation for lesson planning from a naturalistic and holistic perspective. This study's participants are elementary teachers teaching STEM as a subject or applying STEM principles as either STEM-certified teachers or general classroom teachers. Seven elementary STEM teachers participated in two semi-structured interviews and one lesson planning session using a think-aloud method with screen capturing. I transcribed data using Whisper.ai and analyzed them using QDA Miner Lite using inductive thematic analysis.The elementary STEM teachers in this study used various digital resources in their digital curation for lesson planning, such as images, videos, quizzes, or games. Tools for managing and creating resources during the lesson planning were Google Workspace apps and Microsoft Office programs, Prezi, Pinterest, and YouTube. The main spaces for finding resources were search engines, online teacher communities for STEM teachers (e.g., Facebook), a textbook publisher's website, Instagram, Pinterest, and YouTube. The elementary STEM teachers in this study conducted their lesson planning as either a task-focused digital curation or a reflective digital curation to improve the quality of the instructional materials and teaching. In the task-focused curation group, elementary STEM teachers initiated their lesson planning by planning and searching for ideas and activities for inspiration or deciding on learning activities after checking their lessons' topics on the curriculum. They rarely revisited their curated materials and finished their digital curation after implementing prepared lessons. The reflective digital curation group's participants had unique ways to improve their lessons, such as sharing and reflecting on their teaching experiences in monthly meetings. The factors impacting elementary STEM teachers' digital curation for lesson planning were categorized as instructional, instructor, and environmental factors. Instructional factors involve a learner-centered approach, an authentic learning environment, and an instructional content presentation. Instructor factors include autonomy, creativity, and professional learning. Lastly, environmental factors are related to time constraints and organizational support. This exploratory study contributes to the literature about elementary STEM teachers' digital curation for lesson planning as one way to present their digital literacy and how to support teachers' digital curation for teaching practices in elementary STEM education.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Digital Curation, Elementary STEM Teachers, Lesson Planning

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Alloying Effects on the Upper Critical Field of Nb3Sn Superconductor

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Nb 3 Sn conductors are important candidates for high-field magnet applications for Future Protonor Muon Colliders, and they continue to be widely used for many laboratory and NMR magnets. However, the critical current density, J c , of present Nb 3 Sn declines swiftly above 12 ‚àí 15 T due to weak, sparse pinning. The present state-of-the-art Ta- and Ti-doped RRP design conductors exhibit upper critical field, H c2 , values of ‚àº 24 ‚àí 26 T (4.2 K) and J c (4.2 K, 16 T) values of ‚àº 1,300 A/mm 2 , significantly below the target J c of 1,500 A/mm 2 (4.2 K, 16 T) established by the FCC design study which serves as the present stretch target for Nb 3 Sn development. To meet this goal requires, at a minimum, greatly enhanced vortex pinning: recent investigations into doping Nb- Ta alloy with Hf and Zr, with and without internal oxidation, have demonstrated grain-refinement routes to higher vortex pinning. A second approach is to significantly enhance H c2 . In this study we have arc-melted multiple compositions of Hf, Zr, Ta and Ti added to Nb to investigate the possibilities of H c2 enhancement through alloying. These new alloys have been successfully drawn to wire size in Cu-Sn composites. H c2 (T) was measured down to 1.9 K and we have found that all alloys show good agreement with the standard WHH fitting procedure without the need to adjust paramagnetic limitation parameter (Œ±) and spin-orbit scattering parameter (Œª so ). We found excellent linear dH c2/dT slopes that in principle allow the deconvolution of the electronic specific heat coefficient Œ≥ and normal state resistivity œÅ so as to better understand alloying effects. So far we have observed that Hf alloying of pure Nb can enhance H c2 (0) by 3 ‚àí 4 T to ‚àº 28 T, while adding just 1 at.% Hf or Zr into the Nb4Ta base alloy can raise H c2 (0) to ‚àº 31 T, while also raising the recrystallization temperature above the usual A15 reaction temperature range 650 ‚ó¶ C ‚àí 750 ‚ó¶ C. The potential for further improvements in Nb 3 Sn properties will be discussed in the context of these results.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Parent Engagement Online
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Understanding How Parents Are Involved at Indiana Connections Academy

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Many researchers will comment on how vital parent engagement and participation is for student achievement, but there is limited research on this field in the online realm (Borup et al., 2019). This dissertation examined parent engagement at Indiana Connections Academy over the course of the spring semester of 2023 at the school. Since parent engagement is believed to be beneficial on student achievement, in an online program it is even more vital since there is no teacher in front of the students on a daily basis. Engagement at the school was believed to be low, and so this study sought to interview fifteen families enrolled in grade nine through twelve about their beliefs and practices in order to see how parents saw themselves fitting into the educational landscape at the school. Families were interview twice during the 2023 school year, once in March following the end of the winter enrollment period, and once in May at the conclusion of the school year. The results from these interviews helped to demonstrate that parents are engaging, and by and large are happy with their engagement. This finding from a qualitative study led to the recommendation that administrators need to reevaluate how they are measuring parent engagement and determine if the current expectations are sufficient. There are many future avenues for research as well, both at this school or comparing this data to other online programs. By and large, the data collected for this dissertation helped to answer the research questions of "How do parents see their role in the school system?" and "Does that parent perception change over the course of the year?" and provide new light and understanding of the Problem of Practice of perceived disengagement at the school.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
