mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Comprehensive Optimization of Rankine Cycles
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Physical and Working Fluid Design Perspectives

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This work presents two alternatives to optimize the performance of Rankine cycles. The first approach is focused on the spatial distribution of the areas used in the heat exchange process, and the second approach is intended to study the influence of working fluid properties in the performance of the cycle. The two approaches together form a comprehensive optimization tool for Rankine cycles under subcritical operation. The first approach introduces a mathematical model for the design and fundamental optimization of steam Rankine cycle (SRC) power plants. The model assumes that the plant irreversibilities are predominant in the heat exchangers, thus exergy destruction in the turbine, pump, fittings, tubes and other internal components are neglected. The NTU-effectiveness method was utilized to model the heat exchangers, and water was considered as the working fluid, which changes phase in both heat exchangers. Acknowledging that entropy is generated in any physical system, the fundamental optimization problem selected the dimensionless net power output, and second law efficiency as the objective functions to be maximized, after the identification of plant geometric and operating parameters to be optimized based on the intersection of asymptotes method, subject to a fixed total heat exchangers area realistic physical constraint, i.e., for a finite size plant. As a result, two levels of optimization were identified: i) the working fluid to hot stream mass flow rate ratio, M, and ii) the steam generator, xH, and condenser, xL, area fractions of the plant fixed total heat exchangers area. The model was experimentally validated for a heat recovery driven power plant. Sharp maxima were obtained in both levels, which is illustrated with a base case by ~60% second law efficiency variation in comparison to the obtained maximum for 0.05 < M < 0.25 in the first optimization level, and ~30% for 0.2 < xH < 0.7 in the second optimization level, so that (xf,H ,xfg,H ,xg,H )2wo= (0.14,0.13,0.23) , with (M,xH )2wo=(0.16,0.5) , in the base case considered in this study. The two-way optima results sensitivity to several plant geometric and operating parameters were thoroughly investigated. The optimized parameters are shown to be robust with respect to several system's design and operating conditions. Therefore, the herein reported fundamental optimization results are important for whatever actual SRC power plant. The second approach consists of developing a model that serves as a tool which facilitates the selection of a working fluid for different types of ORC applications, by determining the properties of a substance that optimizes the thermodynamic performance of the cycle under specified conditions. As the model relies on the Lee-Kesler's EoS to calculate the properties of the working fluid, it is conceived as a generalized tool that requires only few parameters to characterize an existent or to define a novel fluid. Meanwhile, the cycle is described through energy balances. The tool was validated with commercially available fluids, and it provided competent results. Approximately 97% of the validation cases had a relative error of less than 5%. After the validation, parametric analysis were conducted and some insights were obtained regarding the influence of working fluid properties in the performance of the cycle. Among the parameters considered, the critical temperature of the fluid, T_c, turns out to be the parameter with the strongest influence in the first law efficiency of the cycle.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Heat Transfer Area, Optimization, Rankine Cycle, Working Fluid Selection

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Assessment of Additive Manufacturing
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Meta-Learning Strategies for Layer-Based Manufacturing

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Robotic-Assisted Additive Manufacturing (RAAM) represents the cutting-edge of modern manufacturing, holding the potential to revolutionize production processes by seamlessly integrating contemporary sensing techniques for real-time data collection and decision-making. The inherent capability to influence production on-the-fly offers a pathway to next-generation manufacturing characterized by continuous precision, enhanced efficiency, and improved quality. However, the nascent status of RAAM, coupled with challenges related to trajectory errors in modern robotic platforms, imposes limitations on its widespread application. This comprehensive investigation into RAAM seeks to uncover the complex landscape of additive manufacturing errors and develop strategies to enhance precision. It involves understanding the interplay between the printer's kinematics and the manufacturing process, identifying error sources, and implementing effective mitigation techniques. By proposing an augmented design framework for a cyber-physical manufacturing paradigm enhanced through metalearning principles the study successfully to establishes a series of relationships between the printer and part which minimize geometric deviations. Key results include: i) The implementation of an 99.7% accurate artificial neural network predictive tool for print error. ii) A real-time gcode-modification regime which leverages control theory shown to reduce error in linkage trajectory. iii) A kinematic optimizer for part-printer position, showing up to 89% decrease of error along the printed path, 5.13% increase in tensile strength, and near 50% decrease in void percent. Furthermore, the research introduces an innovative error reduction strategy through a material-based insitu sensing technique with accuracy comparable to state of the art infrared tracking hardware. These findings provide valuable insights into motion planning and trajectory optimization, potentially leading to reduced overall geometric error, improved physical properties, and a wider adoption of RAAM.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Additive Manufacturing, Machine Learning, Meta-Learning, Process Control, Process Structure Property, Robotic Assisted Manufacturing

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Linear Analysis of Multi-Phase Phil Experiments

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Application of power hardware-in-the-loop (PHIL) experiment methodology has been increasing steadily in the past few years. As usage of PHIL technique expands, PHIL methodology is being applied to several areas of power system technology. One of the main concerns in PHIL experiments is tradeoff between accuracy stability and sensitivity of experiments as well as the PHIL interface. In recent years, studies have been conducted on application of a teleoperation framework in the context of PHIL experiments particularly using the extended lawrence architecture (ELA). Several interface algorithms have been realized through the use of the ELA framework and stability and accuracy of these interface algorithms (IA) have been assessed. Although in depth analysis of the PHIL experiments in the context of ELA framework has been provided, it has been limited to either single phase systems with a single PHIL interface or dual/multiple PHIL interface. The work presented here in details on extension of the ELA framework to multiphase PHIL simulations. Existing PHIL interface algorithms have been expressed using ELA framework, as well as derivation of relevant transfer functions and metrics for assessment of performance. The application and analysis provided in this work can be applied to multi-phase systems whose interface algorithm is implemented either as 'abc' frame, 'DQ0' decomposition or 'pn0' sequence decomposition. The research conducted here focuses on application and analysis of 3-phase balanced systems employing 'DQ0' transformation based interface algorithm. Stability and accuracy in the context of ELA framework is compared against the ideal system as well as rotating frame 'abc' tppe inteface algorithm. It can be concluded from this work that ELA framework can be extended to multiphase systems. The linear analysis framework used to predict stability and accuracy of PHIL simulations is also applicable to multi-phase PHIL simulations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Student, Administrator, and Teacher Experiences with Restorative Justice and How These Experiences Shape Perspectives of School Safety

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: School violence is a problem that affects students, families, teachers, staff, and administration (Crews, 2019). Restorative justice is a proactive, alternative method to penal discipline (Payne & Welch, 2018). My study sought to understand the perceptions of administrators, teachers, and students with a restorative justice program at Happy Valley Middle School (pseudonym) in Sunshine County (pseudonym), Florida. I conducted an exploratory, qualitative single case study. I used online semi-structured group interviews with four administrators and two teachers, and individual interviews with two students. I used purposeful sampling since I was seeking students who experienced the restorative justice program. Administrators, teachers, and students stated that restorative justice (RJ) is used at HVMS. Administrators feel that RJ is used as much as possible and feel that teachers are confident with it. Teachers feel that there should be more professional development. Administrators and teachers agreed that students should be more involved in the RJ process, such as training them to be mentors and run circles. Students agreed that RJ lets them speak and have their voices heard. Administrators, teachers, and students agree that RJ teaches students self-awareness. Administrators and teachers stated that HVMS is not collecting data. Data collection should occur in areas such as attendance, grades, suspensions, and expulsions of students who are participating in a restorative justice circle. This data should be collected and made available for all stakeholders, especially if HVMS is making a solid case for using RJ and its effectiveness.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
circles, restorative circles, restorative justice, restorative practices, school safety, school violence
Patrice Iatarola, Professor Directing Dissertation; John Myers, University Representative; Carolyn Herrington, Committee Member; Jeffrey Ayala Milligan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On Turbulent Separation Bubbles

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Pressure-gradient-induced (PGI) turbulent separation bubbles (TSBs) are a common occurrence in various fluidic devices and systems. When a separation bubble forms due to an adverse pressure gradient as opposed to a geometric discontinuity, its flow characteristics are notably different. Without a locally fixed separation point, pressure-gradient-induced TSBs have freedom of motion not only of the separation location but also the reattachment location, leading to large excursions in the separation bubble size and shape. The time scales of oscillations of the detachment and reattachment zones are on the order of 10 - 100 times larger than the characteristic time scale (L/U) of the flow. The physical mechanism responsible for generating such a low-frequency unsteadiness remains unknown and a challenge to simulate/measure. To further the understanding of the complex dynamics observed in these flows, this dissertation presents the results of an investigation of pressure-gradient-induced TSBs in a canonical framework. A low-speed wind tunnel equipped with a suction duct atop its test section is used to generate a substantial adverse pressure gradient on the top surface of an elliptic leading edge flat plate model to separate the incoming turbulent boundary layer. A novel sensor decontamination method based on conditional spectral analysis is developed and used to analyze the unsteady surface pressure signals from a linear array of sensors. A thorough characterization of the static and dynamic content observed in the PGI-TSBs is presented, discussed, and compared to what is observed in other studies. Spectral proper orthogonal decomposition of two-dimensional time-resolved particle image velocimetry (PIV) measurements in a plane reveals the spatio-temporal behavior of the characteristic 'breathing' and `shedding' modes of the PGI-TSB that are reported in the literature. To investigate the three-dimensional (3D) behavior, surface oil flow visualization is performed. Furthermore, non-time resolved (NTR) stereo-PIV at seven streamwise planes and one spanwise plane is captured with synchronous time-resolved (TR) pressure measurements and analyzed via the Spectral Analysis Modal Method (SAMM), with the goal of constructing a low-order reconstruction of the 3D flow. The three-dimensional (3D) dynamic behavior of PGI-TSBs is observed and analyzed. Low-frequency modes pervade the entire separated region, exhibiting pronounced variations in both the streamwise and spanwise directions. Spanwise unsteadiness near the walls reveals oscillations that interact with side-wall vortices. A 3D simplified model of the PGI-TSB showcases elongated fluctuations that periodically dominate a significant portion of the test section span, showing a wandering structural pattern across the span. The results offer new insights and interpretations of the characteristic unsteadiness in PGI-TSBs, providing a distinctive viewpoint for understanding their complex dynamics. Additionally, potential mechanisms contributing to the generation of low-frequency unsteadiness are explored.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
boundary layer separation, low frequency unsteadiness, pressure-gradient-induced separation, smooth-body separation, turbulent flows
Louis N. Cattafesta, Professor Directing Thesis; Rajan Kumar, Committee Member; Kourosh Shoele, Committee Member; Mark Sussman, University Representative.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigating the Pattern and Process of Mate Choice in a Tropical Lekking Passerine Bird

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Variation in female mate choice affects the strength of sexual selection, and understanding this variation is important to understanding the evolution of elaborate secondary sexual characteristics. However, female mate choice is a multidimensional process, incorporating complex male traits, variable female states, and environmental contexts. Despite decades of research on female mate choice, we still do not fully understand how these factors interact to drive variation in female mate choice decisions. My dissertation research investigates the causes and consequences of variability in mate choice in a population of lance-tailed manakins (Chiroxiphia lanceolata), a species of small Neotropical passerine bird. I address three aims with lance-tailed manakins as a study system: (1) understanding the causes and consequences of multiple mating in a lek mating system; (2) investigating the role of chemical signaling in mating behavior; and (3) characterizing the genomic structure of an immune system gene complex, the major-histocompatibility complex (MHC). Finally, I take a comparative approach to (4) investigate the relationship between sexual selection and gene duplication in the MHC across the passerine bird radiation. To understand variation in female mate choice in lance-tailed manakins, I combined data from long-term monitoring of a study population with data from short-term controlled field experiments. First, I explored variation among females in the choice to mate with one or more males in a reproductive bout. I tested several hypotheses about multiple mating in lance-tailed manakins, a system where female choice is unconstrained by the need to form a pair-bond. I found that multiple paternity within a nest was best predicted by male experience: males that were subordinate "betas" or that had fewer years of experience as an alpha male were more likely to share paternity in nests. Females may choose to mate with multiple males when their choices are not optimal. Second, I investigated chemical signaling in the mating behavior of a highly polygynous bird by experimentally altering the chemical cues at lance-tailed manakin courtship sites. I found that male lance-tailed manakins detect and respond to changes in the chemical environment on display perches, but females do not. The information conveyed by chemical cues may be most salient for males in this system, unlike trends reported in other passerine birds where both males and females respond to olfactory cues. While mate choice research in highly polygynous lek mating systems typically focuses on the most elaborate and obvious traits, the results presented here indicate that chemical signaling may be important to mating behavior. Third, I characterize the genomic structure of an immune system gene complex, the MHC, in lance-tailed manakins. Gene duplication and polymorphism in the MHC make it a challenging genome region to characterize. Using a recent high-quality genome assembly for lance-tailed manakins, I assembled and annotated MHC genes using two methods. Manual annotation methods more reliably recovered MHC loci, compared to the available algorithm-based annotations. Additionally, preliminary analysis of signatures of selection across an alignment of MHC sequences from several manakin species identified codons under positive and negative selection. These results set the stage for future analyses of the evolutionary consequences of sexual selection for the MHC. In my final chapter, I take a comparative approach to investigate the evolutionary consequences of sexual selection for gene duplication in the MHC. Across passerine birds, the MHC region is characterized by extreme copy number variation. Using whole genome assemblies, I estimated MHC copy number tested hypotheses about drivers of MHC duplication across the passerine bird radiation. I did not find any support for the hypothesis that sexual selection could drive accelerated duplication in the MHC region. Genome assembly quality was the only consistent predictor of MHC copy number, highlighting the challenges of characterizing complex and highly duplicated genomic regions. By examining variation within mate choice bouts, in relation to neglected signaling modes, and across long temporal scales, this work improves understanding of the axes of variation in mate choice and their effects on the evolutionary outcomes of sexual selection.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
chemical communication, major histocompatibility complex, manakin, mate choice, polyandry, sexual selection
Emily H. DuVal, Professor Directing Dissertation; Peter Beerli, University Representative; Kimberley A. Hughes, Committee Member; Don R. Levitan, Committee Member; Joseph Travis, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Characterization of the Variability of the Wet Season over Central America

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Central America exhibits a distinct seasonal cycle of rainfall, which is objectively defined in this study as having an onset date and a demise date of the wet season on the first and the last day of the year when its daily rainfall exceeds and falls below the annual mean rainfall climatology. This is defined at both a regional scale and the granularity of the rainfall analysis dataset. Additionally, the methodology diagnoses the onset/demise dates of the wet season from an ensemble of 1000 members per season by perturbing the original time series to obtain robust probabilistic estimates. The variations in the onset date, demise date, seasonal length, and seasonal rain are considered with the variations of the El Ni√±o Southern Oscillation, the Atlantic Warm Pool, and the Tropical East Pacific Warm Pool to better understand the influences of these large-scale climate variations. Our analysis reveals that these external factors have relatively less influence on the variations of the evolution of the wet season over Central America. It is shown that both onset and demise date variations have a bearing on the seasonal length and seasonal rainfall anomaly but impact them independently of each other. This study demonstrates that a seasonal outlook based solely on the onset date variations has useful prediction skills that portend for real-time monitoring of the onset date of the wet season.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Music Therapy Goals and Interventions for Individuals with ADHD
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Survey Study

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purposes of this study were as follows: to investigate the types of goals music therapists address for their clients with ADHD throughout the lifespan, and the types of interventions used to address those goals. Participants (N = 170) were board board-certified music therapists practicing in the United States who have worked with individuals with ADHD, who completed a 10-15 minute survey via Qualtrics. Participants were asked to indicate the age groups they worked with, the types of goals addressed for each age group, and the interventions they use to address each goal. Although participants reported utilizing a variety of interventions, there were certain interventions that appeared to be favored for each type of goal throughout the lifespan. Further results and implications are discussed within this paper.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Music Therapy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Critical Vulnerability and Community Care Towards a Resilience from Below

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In places where there is historical disinvestment in minority communities and public infrastructure, disasters like Hurricane Michael and recovery-resilience narratives provide possibilities for energizing community movement towards just community development and as rationalizing logic to maintain uneven status quo. This contestation makes the role and limitations of formal local government planning and community-based organization important. In 2018, Panama City was devastated by Hurricane Michael, a Category 5 (Saffir-Simpson intensity scale) hurricane, when it made landfall. The impacts of Hurricane Michael were differentiated across the coast of the different county not only due to the differences related to the magnitude of storm surge and hurricane winds but also because of the difference in physical infrastructure, social, and economic situation. Four years after Hurricane Michael, the City Government and different communities are still working on recovery projects and resilience plans, which are also subject to the different coastal geographies. This research looked at how Hurricane Michael impacted the daily life of people as well as government functions of Panama City. Consequently, it also critically examines the recovery and resilience building at the community and city levels. It utilized mixed methodology by combining interviews of community and local government officials with participant observation and document analysis of the formal long-term recovery planning conducted by the city and community-based planning conducted by a community-based organization. This research provides empirical evidence on how civic engagement and community care practices are leveraged by a community-based organization to advocate for transformative resilience that addresses historical vulnerability. I trace this argument of alternative forms of resilience we called "Resilience from Below" as the potential for continuing critical projects. This view of resilience is reflected by emerging literature from critical scholars, activists, artists, and communities vulnerable to environmental risk (climate change and its impacts). Resilience from below address the significant critique of mainstream resilience and provide a way to reclaim it as a potentially transformative concept. 'Resilience from below' involves 1) rethinking vulnerability and its causes using historical and intersectional lenses, 2) paying attention to the community care practices and moving away from financial-only metrics used in adaptation decisions, and 3) centering the community resilience building through collaborative and care work. Resilience in this frame recognizes vulnerable communities as active participants in resilience building, which allows for theoretical and political re-framing of resilience as a useful concept by ensuring that it is place-based, experience-based, transformative, caring, and justice-oriented.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Geography in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Community Care, Critical Vulnerability, Disaster Recovery, Planning Participation, Resilience

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Structural and Biochemical Characterization of Guanylate Binding Protein 2

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Pathogenic microorganisms gain entry inside the host cell by breaching anatomical barriers andinvading tissues. The host cell in turn depends on the sentinels of cell autonomous defense system to fight off the invading pathogen. This cell autonomous defense has a broad spectrum of microbial sensitivity and in addition maintains the signals for cellular homeostasis for the key housekeeping functions. The key players of the cell autonomous immunity belong to the family of interferon stimulated genes (ISGs). The ISGs can directly counteract the pathogenic microorganism, or they can act as immune editors to influence the other immune effectors. Prominent within the thousands of ISGs overexpressed during infection is a family of GTPases. Guanylate binding proteins (GBPs) are one of the four members of the interferon stimulated GTPase family and act as a major hub of defensive responses against a diverse array of pathogens. The myriad of roles played by GBPs in mediating host defense against bacterial, viral and protozoan pathogens has been established over the past 20 years. Recently, structural and biochemical studies are playing a key role in elucidating the molecular mechanism of the robust immunity mediated by GBPs. Such studies carried out on GBP1 in the past have proved that this family resembles the dynamin superfamily. GBP2 is one of the two highly inducible GBPs, yet little is known about the activation and regulation of GBP2. In our study, we characterized the GTPase domain of GBP2 both structurally and biochemically. By determining the crystal structures of the GBP2 G domain in the different nucleotide-bound states, we unveiled distinct conformational states adopted by the nucleotide-binding pocket and the distal regions of the protein in the course of GTP hydrolysis. The conformational changes in the G domain are further transmitted to the C-terminal helical domain as is evident from the comparative analysis of the nucleotide-free full-length GBP2. We also identified subtle differences in the G domain induced by different nucleotides that provide insights into the molecular basis of monomer-dimer transition and enzymatic activity. By employing biochemistry and small angle X-ray scattering, we have deciphered that the second to last alpha helix at the C-terminal end of GBP2 plays a role in regulating the activation of the protein. These findings pave the way for future investigations aimed at elucidating the precise molecular mechanisms underlying GBP2's role in the immune response and may facilitate the development of targeted therapeutic strategies against intracellular pathogens.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Influence of Bigram Frequency on Naming Speed
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Meta-Analysis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Rapid Automatized Naming (RAN) is a measure of lexical access in which a subject must name an array of visual stimuli as fast as possible. RAN has been shown to be highly predictive of reading ability and reading deficits. Most researchers agree that RAN assesses orthographic pattern recognition, among other factors. Bigrams refer to paired units of language, such as letters, syllables, or words (though, for the scope of this analysis, bigrams will be defined as units of two letters) and operationalizes a pattern of language. Given the pattern-matching components of RAN and the role of bigram frequency in word naming, it seems possible that the bigram frequency of any given RAN task could influence naming speed outcomes. The purpose of this meta-analysis is to determine whether bigram frequency relates to naming speed on serial RAN tasks with different bigram frequencies. Age, number of letters per task, and visual similarity were important moderators that were explored in this investigation, in order to determine whether the influence of bigram frequency existed above and beyond other predictors. Eight studies with multiple RAN matrices were included in the analyses; these eight studies yielded 70 effect sizes. A meta-regression was performed and showed that the relationship between bigram frequency and naming speed was significant (p = 0.0019) above and beyond other moderators. Individual moderator analyses also determined that no other factors were significantly predictive of naming speed. These findings speak to the predictive power of bigram frequency (and, by extension, other patterns of language) and help support claims that naming speed performance is a consequence of orthographic pattern recognition.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
bigram frequency, naming speed, statistical learning
Chris Schatschneider, Professor Directing Thesis; Donald Compton, Committee Member; Michael Kaschak, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Form and Function of Novel Brain Circuitry in the Female Zebra Finch

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In male zebra finches, the song learning process can be divided in to two distinct-but-overlapping stages: sensory, and sensorimotor, which are scaffolded by concurrent changes in the brain. In the male song network, dual premotor pathways provide distinct-but-overlapping contributions to auditory learning and sensorimotor learning of song. Female zebra finches can recognize certain familiar male songs ‚Äì indicating that they too are capable of sensory learning. However, female zebra finches do not naturally produce song. The contrast of sexual dimorphism in song production and apparent partial dimorphism in song learning provides a prospective within-species comparison which by process of subtraction may highlight the delegation of neural processes to sensory acquisition, and sensorimotor learning, respectively. Historically, the seminal neuroanatomical difference between male and female zebra finches was said to be the absence of nearly all male-typical song regions + connectivity in the female brain. The behavioral and neural development of female vocalizations have not been carefully investigated, if at all. These shortcomings in the songbird literature bias the investigation and understanding of song learning and production, and limit the generalizability of any conclusions drawn from study of zebra finch brain and behavior. Here I elucidate the female "song network" anatomically and test the necessity of key female "song network" regions for development and production of female zebra finch vocalizations. The male song network is composed of two major pathways, and HVC contributes to both. The AFP (anterior forebrain pathway) induces variability in the network motor output and is disproportionally influential during juvenile song learning. The CMP (caudal motor pathway) exerts the learned theme upon the network's motor output, growing more influential as development progresses and theme encoding strengthens. In this dissertation, bilateral injections of bidirectional fluorescent tracer ‚Äì one injection site per brain hemisphere - into female (a) Area X, (proper name) (b) HVC (acronym is the name), (c) LMAN (lateral magnocellular nucleus of the anterior nidopallium) or (d) RA (robust nucleus of the arcopallium) mapped the network connectivity of those nodes in the female brain, demonstrating that female and male zebra finches possess near identical extrinsic connectivity of those four nodes. Using the neurobiology of male vocal development and production as a guide, I tested whether behavioral functions are shared between female and male song networks. Female zebra finches produce several different vocalizations (calls), yet little is known about how they arise developmentally. Conversely, the behavioral and neural developmental trajectory of male song is well studied. Thus, I recorded and quantified the normal developmental trajectory of female calls from time of nutritional independence to adulthood. Then, in a second cohort of birds, I disconnected the AFP from the "song network" via bilateral LMAN ablation in juvenile females, testing the necessity of LMAN for female vocal development. Finally, I disconnected the CMP from the "song network" via bilateral HVC ablation in adult females, to test the necessity of HVC for female call production.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Validation of Satellite Radar Snowfall and Rainfall Retrievals by Surface Observations

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Precise satellite snowfall and rainfall measurements are crucial for the global water budget since there are immense climate and water resource applications. The validation of these satellite measurements is therefore necessary for determining the accuracy of global precipitation. In this study, satellite snowfall from CloudSat's Cloud Profiling Radar (CPR) and rainfall from the Global Precipitation Measurement Mission's (GPM) Dual-Frequency Precipitation Radar (DPR) are validated using ground station measurements from the Global Historical Climatology Network Dataset (GHCND). However, since the GHCND snowfall measurements were in solid form, it was necessary to convert them to their liquid equivalent before satellite comparison. Using a normalized frequency bin method, a relation equation was found between the snow density and the daily average temperature, which is the average of the maximum and minimum daily temperature. This relation equation was then implemented for the satellite snowfall comparison, with results showing a satellite overestimation near 10%. Rainfall satellite validation against GHCND data found a satellite underestimation of 20%. Regional patterns for both snowfall and rainfall exhibited enhanced overestimation and underestimation, respectively. Finally, performing satellite validation of satellite snowfall plus rainfall resulted in an underestimation of close to 5%, which suggests rainfall dominance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Guosheng Liu, Professor Directing Thesis; Vasubandhu Misra, Committee Member; Alyssa Atwood, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Undergraduate Student and Instructor Learning Experiences with Scientific Uncertainty

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A growing body of literature focusing on undergraduate biology education calls for students to engage in the ways of thinking, feeling, and doing that reflect those in which biologists engage. Such reform efforts suggest that learning is best fostered when students engage in practices, concepts, and scientific reasoning as they endeavour to explain phenomena. However, it is recognized that if this experience is to reflect authentic science, such work requires that students learn to wrestle with uncertainty. The embrace of uncertainty as a component of rigorous science learning experiences is relatively new and unexplored in undergraduate settings. In this dissertation I offer a curricular analysis of the nature of uncertainty structured in a non-major's biology laboratory, a description of instructional moves teaching assistants (TAs) use as their students' encounter uncertainty, and a case study of three TAs coming to understand scientific uncertainty and epistemic affect in an internship course. This dissertation study offers six types of scientific uncertainty that were present within a non-majors biology laboratory curricula, four outcomes of uncertainty that result from TAs instructional moves when students encounter uncertainty, an the resources three TAs drew upon as they came to understand scientific uncertainty and epistemic affect. I intend for this dissertation study to support understanding undergraduate non-majors' biology laboratory courses and the opportunities for students to engage in authentic science to develop biological proficiency.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
biology, non-majors laboratory, post-secondary, scientific uncertainty
Sherry A. Southerland, Professor Directing Dissertation; Joseph Travis, University Representative; Lama Jaber, Committee Member; Christine Andrews-Larson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Old Music, New Technique
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Using Medieval Music to Teach Half Position on the Double Bass

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This treatise features my arrangements of five pieces found in the manuscript GB-Lbl Ms Add. 29987 (or Lo) and demonstrates their pedagogical applications for half position on the double bass. It begins with a brief look at the history of the manuscript and its historical significance. Next, it examines how two popular books of double bass pedagogy, Essential Elements and New Method for String Bass, approach half position and explores how these arrangements can act as companion pieces to their half position exercises. After that, it describes my process of decoding the notation in the Lo manuscript. Finally, it introduces my editions of these pieces, discusses their applications for the double bass, and explains the decision-making process I used while making my arrangements.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Impacts of High-Resolution Ocean Surface Currents on Atmospheric Modeling in the Gulf of Mexico

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The atmospheric response to one-way coupled ocean surface currents is examined in this study through the use of merged ocean surface currents from NASA Doppler scatterometer data and Hybrid Coordinate Ocean Model (HYCOM) data in the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model. The focus of this study is the dynamic impact of ocean surface currents around a loop current eddy (LCE) in the Gulf of Mexico through various atmospheric parameters with the key diagnostic parameters of planetary boundary layer height (PBLH) and vertical velocity. Two simulations were performed with the WRF model: one with only HYCOM sea surface temperatures (SSTs) as the static boundary conditions and one incorporating Gaussian filter merged surface currents in addition to the SSTs. The analysis of simulations focused on two regions located at the north and south ends of the LCE based on high ocean surface current vorticity. The mean PBLH at these two regions and difference between the mean PBLH at these times were used to determine an approximate quasi-steady state in which the atmosphere had responded to the currents. The findings were that wind stress anomalies had the opposite sign of ocean current vorticity below them. There was a decrease in PBLH due to currents of 20-25 m when averaged over the quasi-steady state. Horizontal winds decreased at the surface and in the free atmosphere but increased through the PBL and at PBLH. With the addition of currents, sensible and latent heat fluxes as well as net and longwave surface radiation fluxes all exhibited reduced transfer of energy from the ocean to the atmosphere. Vertical velocity was less upward along positive surface current curl. Vertical velocity, horizontal winds, and PBLH all had greater changes over more positive current curl (or vorticity) gradients.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Mark A. Bourassa, Professor Directing Thesis; Jeffrey Chagnon, Professor Directing Thesis; Henry Fuelberg, Committee Member; Robert Hart, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Heat Transfer Fundamentals and Enhancement at Component and System Levels

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This doctoral dissertation pertains to the study of heat transfer, fluid-structure-thermal interactions, buoyancy-driven flows, and the numerical modeling techniques needed to systematically study the different problems related to these topics. The research carried out is based on the numerical models and simulations. It will become apparent that there are two main topics discussed in this dissertation. The first, thought of as a component-level study of the heat transfer and physics related to or influencing the enhancement of heat transfer or stability of the thermal response of the component. Two chapters are dedicated to this topic in which the fluid-structure-thermal interactions of a flexible (passively) flapping flag are studied. The effects of the structure material parameters as well as the fluid parameters are studied 1) within the scope of mixed convection, and 2) under the influence of a nearby free-surface. The latter, although not directly involving heat transfer, considers the flow problem encountered in phase-changing system such as the boiling of a fluid, aided by a passive agitator such as a flapping flag. The second topic addressed in the dissertation adopts a system-level approach, specifically examining heat transfer in a thermally- buoyant fluid system confined within a fully enclosed cavity. Often, differentially heated cavities are encountered in practical engineering systems in which the heat transfer must be enhanced, reduced or used to alter the flow structure within the cavity. The simplest iteration of this problem, the classical differentially heated cavity, is considered and some new contributions are made to this topic. Furthermore, a layer of complexity is added to more closely resemble the conditions typically found in practical engineering situations. This is done through the development of a novel conjugate boundary condition which is applied to the system. The heat transfer and flow stability of the system is studied in depth using this novel technique. A significant contribution of this dissertation lies in the development and application of numerical modeling techniques to simulate and analyze heat transfer in complex systems. High-fidelity computational simulations serve as a virtual laboratory, enabling the exploration of parameters are challenging or impractical to replicate experimentally. The numerical models are validated ensuring their reliability in capturing the intricate details of the physical problems studied here. The outcomes of this research aims to advance the fundamental understanding of heat transfer In summary, this dissertation offers a numerical exploration of heat transfer, fluid-structure-thermal- interactions, buoyancy-driven flows (natural convection), aiming to advance the fundamental understanding of heat transfer.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Programmed Carbocyclization of Conjugated Polyenes
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Strategy Deveopment and Applications

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Programmed Carbocyclization of Conjugated Polyenes
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Strategy Development and Applications

mods:mods.mods:abstract: A new polyene cyclization strategy exploiting Œ≤-ionyl derivatives was developed. Photoinduced deconjugation of the extended œÄ-system within these chromophores unveils a contrathermodynamic polyene that engages in a Heck bicyclization to afford [4.4.1]-propellanes. This cascade improves upon the limited regioselectivity achieved using existing biomimetic tactics and tolerates both electron-rich and electron-deficient (hetero)aryl groups. The utility of this approach was demonstrated with the diverted total synthesis of taxodione and salviasperanol, two isomeric abietane diterpenes, taxodione and salviasperanol, that were previously inaccessible along the same synthetic pathway. After we developed an efficient route to taxodione, we sought to study its pharmacology. Taxodione has been shown to exhibit anticancer activity through multiple different types of mechanisms, specifically via enzymatic inhibition of an essential enzyme, farnesyl diphoshphate synthase (FDPS). We utilize structure-activity relationships (SAR) to design analogs of taxodione which exhibit more selective and potent binding to FDPS.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
James H. Frederich, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Bertram, University Representative; Lei Zhu, Committee Member; Brian Miller, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Ecophysiology of Ectothermic Ecosystem Engineers
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Bioenergetic Effects of Climate and Food on Dominant Consumers and Their Consequences for Coastal Ecosystems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This body of work explores dynamics of temperate marine grazers that are sensitive to food availability and inhabit regions with dramatic contemporary variation in abiotic conditions due to nearshore upwelling. Climate change projections indicate that such environmental fluctuation in these systems will increase in both intensity and variability in the coming decades. Chapter 1 focuses on the temperate red sea urchin Mesocentrotus franciscanus, which can denude highly productive kelp forests through their voracious grazing, often resulting in the formation of barren habitats which can persist for decades. In this chapter I first used respirometry to demonstrate how red sea urchins from wild populations depress their metabolism in barrens relative to kelp forests in the Pacific North West (PNW) \cite{Spindel2021Ecology}. Then I conducted a laboratory feeding experiment which provided evidence that metabolic depression and gonadal biomass reduction in red sea urchins are coupled with food deprivation, but that this response is highly plastic and was not accompanied by differences in feeding rate or assimilation efficiency. Additionally, Chapter 1 provides empirical validation for the use of fatty acid based dietary tracers for inferring algal diets in M. franciscanus. Chapter 2 builds upon these insights by applying the use of gonadal and fatty acid biomarkers in situ to trace the transfer of newly available algal food resources to key forest consumers, M. franciscanus and the endangered northern abalone, Haliotis kamtschatkana in the context of a collaborative ecological restoration project in Haida Gwaii, British Columbia, Canada.This chapter also includes the development of a granular library of kelp forest dietary resources based on multivariate fatty acid biomarker profiles. Chapter 3 investigates the impacts of contemporary ocean acidification and marine heatwaves on rates of herbivory and energetics in the dominant ecosystem engineer, Strongylocentrotus purpuratus using a manipulative mesocosm experiment. Ecological consequences of food and climatic impacts on individual herbivory and energetics are discussed. Collectively, these chapters will demonstrate the importance of considering intraspecific variability and heterogeneity of food availability in understanding and forecasting effects of dynamic abiotic drivers in marine ectotherms.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Daniel K. Okamoto, Professor Directing Dissertation; Markus H. Huettel, University Representative; Jonathan H. Dennis, Committee Member; Don R. Levitan, Committee Member; Sophie J. McCoy, Committee Member; Scott C. Burgess, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Barriers and Facilitators BIPOC Clients Encounter in Receiving Mental Health Services

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Black, Indigenous, and people of color (BIPOC) have historically had lower return rates for psychotherapy and a higher likelihood to discontinue therapy as compared to non-Hispanic White clients. Given that premature discontinuation of psychotherapy treatment has been linked with lower rates of mental health symptom improvement, understanding factors that contribute to BIPOC client continuation and discontinuation of psychotherapy services can help mental health care clinicians improve therapy continuation rates for BIPOC clients. Existing literature has remained unclear, and results are conflicting in identifying factors that contribute to BIPOC clients continuing therapy and factors that contributed to discontinuing therapy. Much of the existing literature has focused on clinician perspectives of factors contributing to BIPOC client continuation and discontinuation, and with wide variety among BIPOC client samples, understanding broader consensus was difficult. Therefore, it was important to understand diverse BIPOC client perspectives on factors that contributed to BIPOC client continuation and discontinuation of therapy services in the U.S. The purpose of this study was to understand, from BIPOC client experiences and perspectives, what factors contribute to continuation and discontinuation of BIPOC therapy services. Participants included 25 BIPOC-identifying individuals with current and/or previous therapy experience. Using a qualitative constructivist grounded theory methodology, participants were asked their perspectives on factors that contributed to continuation and/or discontinuation of therapy services in their experience. Results for continuation factors and discontinuation factors largely mirrored one another. Based on participant perspectives, factors such as quality of services, clinician skills, clinician integration of culture, client-clinician matching, and external factors played a role in some form in both the continuation and discontinuation of BIPOC client therapy services. Findings provide implications for clinical utilization and future research considerations to increase the continuation of therapy services for BIPOC clients, with hopes of improving the quality of mental health care services for BIPOC individuals in the U.S.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigation into Florida High School English Teachers' Response to CS/HB 1467

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Program in Instructional Systems and Learning Technologies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: CS/HB 1467: K-12 Education is a new education law in Florida requiring schools and teachers to be entirely transparent about the material used for instruction and in school media centers and ensuring all materials used are appropriate and vetted. This study seeks to understand how high school English teachers are navigating these changes brought about by CS/HB 1467 and how they have adjusted their pedagogical practices and content being taught. This exploratory, qualitative interview study uses Shulman's pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) as a conceptual framework to investigate how Florida high school English teachers' PCK is being adapted due to the implementation of CS/HB 1467. The data for this study was collected through semi-structured interviews with 10 Florida high school English teachers. Participants described their experiences with adapting their pedagogy and content as well as the support that they feel they need from their schools' administrative teams, school districts, and the state. Four major themes emerged from the interviews: background, practice, reaction, and support. Qualitative analysis showed a need for support from the participants' administration teams, school districts, and state, which is recommended in the form of professional development through online learning opportunities, seminars, and workshops. Three thematic categories were discussed by participants regarding how their PCK has been affected: updating materials, adjusting time, and professional development needs. Finally, I discuss the implications of my findings, which include four professional development recommendations: 1) invite a district or state official to explain the exact wording of CS/HB 1467, how the school district is interpreting it, and what that means for high school English teachers, 2) identify new instructional skills and strategies for high school English teachers to use to support CS/HB 1467, 3) provide an easily navigable database of approved texts and media for teachers to reference, and 4) align teachers' beliefs with reform goals by sharing the purpose and goals the state expects from CS/HB 1467. These professional development opportunities can be provided to teachers in a few ways, such as through seminars, workshops, and online learning.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Program in Instructional Systems and Learning Technologies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Efficient Learning of the State in Dynamic Systems from Model-Based to Data-Based

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Understanding and predicting states in dynamic systems is a core challenge in many areas of study. This involves trying to estimate an evolving signal based on past observations or the understood rules of the system. Main obstacles include errors in observations, the unknowns, and the complexity of these rules. This dissertation delves into the challenge of state estimation in dynamic systems, especially in scenarios with limited information at hand. Central to our exploration is striking a balance between the volume of available data and the precision of our state predictions. Broadly, our sources of information fall into two camps: measurements, which are historical observations, and models, the theoretical frameworks defining system evolution. While dense and precise measurements are desirable for accuracy, they are often constrained by technological limitations. On the flip side, while detailed models can guide precise predictions, they are sometimes elusive for complex systems. Initially, the research delves into model-based estimation, where system models are employed to calculate system states. However, uncertainties in various factors, such as initial conditions or the model itself, introduce errors. A unique scenario within model-based estimation is explored where humans function as sensors in a cyber-physical-human system, sending binary signals based on system performance, shedding light on the challenges of relying on such sparse information. // The research then shifts to data-based estimation in scenarios where system models are undefined or unknown. The primary challenge here is predicting system states with scarce data and minimal understanding of the system's dynamics. Two significant techniques, physics-informed neural networks (PINN) and deep operator networks (DeepONet), are investigated to approach this problem. The proposed method attempts to combine the strengths of both techniques and also integrate findings from prior research on short-term dependencies in systems. The methodology follows two phases: understanding system dynamics and refining estimations to address error accumulations. The former aims to identify key influences of the current state using historical data. The efficacy of this method is demonstrated using the ultra-high magnetic response system as a case study. The latter phase reduces error accumulation by directly mapping initial states and inputs to current states, using a unique DeepONet framework that incorporates findings from short-term dependencies.// This dissertation offers novel insights into the challenges and solutions for state estimation in dynamic systems with limited information. The presented methods and findings have broad implications for fields reliant on accurate state estimations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Lichun Li, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jonathan Clark, University Representative; Omer Arda Vanli, Committee Member; Chiwoo Park, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Optimization of Flow Patterns in a Solid Particle Receiver for CSP

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The rise in energy demand calls for rapid advancements in technology in terms of renewable energy. In doing so, to reduce the carbon emissions in the atmosphere and give the planet a fighting chance to battle global temperature rise. With different forms of energy harvesting through renewable sources, solar energy is one of the fastest progressing and promising forms of renewable energy ( Gon√ßalves Vasconcelos Sampaio & Orestes Aguirre Gonz√°lez, 2017). The sun's energy can be used to produce electricity through light and heat. Semiconductor materials are used to extract photovoltaic energy from the sun. The interaction of photons with the semiconductors , thus producing electricity (Pratap Singh, Kumar Goyal, & Kumar, 2021). The issue arises with the efficiency of these panels. The maximum efficiency attained by using photovoltaics is currently about 22%, which comes from using perovskite material (Kim, Lee, Jung, Shin, & Park, 2020), which leads us to the second issue, the cost of these materials. The question arises on how sustainable it is to continue investing in more expensive materials in order to increase efficiency and produce enough power to keep up with the global energy demand. Routes that use heat, however, have a higher efficiency as it can be concentrated. Concentrated solar power uses reflective surfaces to direct the sun's rays onto a central point or area. This area contains a heat transfer medium which in turn carries this heat and transfers it to a power cycle, thus producing electricity (Lovegrove & Pye, Fundamental principles of concentrating solar power (CSP) systems, 2012). The four most common types of concentrated solar power are: linear Fresnel lens, parabolic trough collectors, concentrated dish collectors and heliostat fields (Lovegrove & Csiro, Introduction to concentrating solar power (CSP) technology, 2012). The concentrated dish collector is e most efficient form of concentrated solar power as it contains a dual axis tracking system and ensures direct concentration of the suns rays onto a focal point rather than focal area. But this also means that it is too expensive to be commercially viable. So, when considering a second-best alternative, heliostat fields are the way to go. Heliostat fields use a set of mirrors that are positioned in such a way that the sun's rays are reflected off them and onto a receiver that is placed on a central tower. The heat is transferred through a heat transfer medium, which is usually in fluid form (gases, molten salts, oils, water etc.) (Jiang, Du, Kong, Xu, & Ju, 2019). The drawback with this is the heat threshold that can be attained by the heat transfer medium. Therefore, solid carbon ceramic particles are considered as they can retain and transfer higher temperatures thus increasing the electricity produced by the power cycle (Jiang, Du, Kong, Xu, & Ju, 2019). In order to retain this high amount of heat, the solid particles need to remain in the area where the reflected rays are focused. There is a need to optimize the residence time (Tawfik, 2022). The aim of this work is to study the motion of these particles through the central receiver. In doing so, try to create patterns or obstructions in their path to increase the resident time of the particles. Reducing the mass flow rate will increase the rate of heat transfer by radiation (directly from the reflected rays) and through conduction (from the receiver's plates and walls). Two different patterns are studied in this paper that show its effect on the mass flow rate of the particles and their results are shown through simulation and proved experimentally. The designs in consideration are the inverted V pattern and a Branched (also referred to as C pattern) inspired by constructal theory. The first design exists in practice and is being studied as an obstruction pattern for solid particle receivers (Ho, 2015). The second is proposed flow idea that interlinks the flow patterns in nature to that of engineering. The pattern is inspired by a combination of the flow of water from the sky to the ground in the form of rain and how this flow is controlled while traveling through riverbeds. It also uses a double three pattern to achieve a point-to-point distribution. It shows how creating channels and crevices in a specific ratio with fixed length and width ratios can facilitate better control of flow (Bejan & Zane , Design in Nature, 2013). By creating this design, the aim is to improve the control over the flow rate and in turn the resident time of the particles in the central region. Increased resident time allows the particle to gain more heat energy, resulting in higher output temperature and overall efficiency of the power plant.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
concentrated solar power, constructal law theory, mass flow rate, mfix, resident time, solid particle receiver
Juan Ordonez, Professor Directing Thesis; Partick Hollis, Committee Member; Simon Foo, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: State of Charge Estimation Using Generative Deep Learning for Electric Vehicle Applications

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Energy storage technologies are being used excessively in industrial applications and in automobiles. Battery state of charge (SOC) is an important metric to be monitored in these applications to ensure proper and safe functionality. Since SOC cannot be measured directly, this study puts forth a novel machine learning architecture to improve on the existing methods of SOC estimation. This method consists of using combined stacked bi-directional LSTM and encoder‚Äìdecoder bi-directional long short-term memory architecture. This architecture henceforth represented as SED is implemented to overcome the nonparallel functionality observed in traditional RNN algorithms. Estimations were made utilizing different open-source datasets such as urban dynamometer driving schedule (UDDS), highway fuel efficiency test (HWFET), LA92 and US06. The least Mean Absolute Error observed was 0.62% at 25 ÔÇ∞C for the HWFET condition, which confirms the good functionality of the proposed architecture. Generative deep learning techniques are being used excessively in machine learning applications. Ongoing research in this field has been amped up by many players in the consumer market because, none of the other deep learning method can synthetize high fidelity data that can be used to improve other algorithms. In this study a combination of BLSTM SOC estimator and CGAN are used to lower the estimation error. The high-fidelity data generated is fed into the SED BLSTM SOC estimator for training and testing is carried out using the actual LA92 dataset to provide an accurate SOC estimate. Two cases are established for testing and highest accuracy was observed while using LA92 25ÔÇ∞C data. The major contributions of this dissertation are: 1. Proposed a new SOC estimation technique using stacked Encoder-decoder Bi-LSTM network that provides an improved accuracy over pre-existing machine learning SOC estimation techniques. 2. A generative SOC estimation approach that uses conditional GAN to generate synthetic battery data that can be used to train the proposed SED SOC estimator to improve the versatility of the estimator. 3. High fidelity battery drive cycle data can be synthetized using this architecture for use in different applications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Deep Learning, Energy Storage, Generative Adversarial Networks, Generative Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, State of Charge
