mods:titleInfo.mods:title: How Ninein Coordinates a Microtubule-Organizing Center in the Drosophila Larval Fat Body
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Structure-Function Analysis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The centrosome, comprised of a pair of centrioles, is the best-studied microtubule-organizing center (MTOC). However, after utilizing the centrosome to organize the mitotic spindle during cell division, differentiated cells will often reassign microtubule (MT)-organizing function to a site apart from the centrosome, creating a non-centrosomal MTOC (ncMTOC). Ninein (Nin) is a microtubule anchor at the subdistal appendages of mother centrioles and the pericentriolar material (PCM) of centrosomes that also functions to organize MTs at ncMTOCs. In humans, mutations in the <italic>NIN</italic> gene have been linked to Seckel syndrome, an inherited developmental disorder, and an increased risk for colorectal cancer. In this work, I characterize Nin using <italic>Drosophila melanogaster</italic> (fruit flies) as a model organism. Nin is not essential in flies, but it does localize to the periphery of the centrosome as well as to ncMTOCs in specialized, differentiated cell types such as the wing epithelia, muscle, and fat body, pointing to a role for Nin in supporting non-centrosomal MT organization. In this work, I dissect the protein domains, key interactions, and epistatic relationships involving Nin at the <italic>Drosophila</italic> larval fat body cells' perinuclear ncMTOC. I have defined domains of Nin responsible for its localization to the ncMTOC on the fat body cell nuclear surface and localization within the nucleus. I have confirmed the interaction seen in human cells between <italic>Drosophila</italic> Dynein light intermediate chain (Dlic) and Nin and have mapped this interaction to an N-terminal domain. Additionally, I have mapped an ensconsin (ens) binding domain to Nin and shown that this domain is sufficient to create a robust, juxtanuclear MTOC together with ens. Altogether, these findings reveal novel features of Nin function and its regulation of a ncMTOC.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
dynein, ensconsin, fat body, microtubules, MTOC, Ninein
Timothy L. Megraw, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hong-Guo Yu, University Representative; Michael Blaber, Committee Member; Gregg Stanwood, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Documenting Domesticy
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Examination of the Home in Late Medieval Yorkshire, England

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Documenting Domesticity
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Examination of the Home in Late Medieval Yorkshire, England

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The home is the centerpiece of medieval life. This dissertation considers the home and household objects and how they represent individual and familial identity that is developed through social constructs. Identities established through the medieval domicile are recorded in three document types that can recall kinship, religious ideologies, economic inclinations, and gender roles. These document types include notary sources, surviving artifacts, and two-dimensional representations of the home. This dissertation defines these document types and then demonstrates how they can be used to understand how everyday objects in the home reflect the cultural norms in medieval Yorkshire, England from 1430 to 1540. I argue that domestic-based documentation is most fruitful for yielding information on the home, the objects it contained, and medieval life when multiple source types are considered together versus independently. Relying on one document type limits the kind of information that can be gleaned about the role of the home as a vessel for preserving the values of a given time and place. I engage with the existing scholarship on domesticity and break down barriers in the field through an interdisciplinary approach that is not dependent on a single source type or method of analysis.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
commodity, documentation, domesticity, home, identity, material culture

Benjamin Dodds, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Erika Loic, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; David F. Johnson, University Representative; Stephanie Leitch, Committee Member; Kyle Killian, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Haunting on Main Street
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Death, Revival, and Reckoning in Doo-Wop and Barbershop

mods:mods.mods:abstract: There are two distinct time periods of the barbershop singing tradition that are often conflated in the scholarly musical community. The first period, generally from the 1860s through the 1930s, is marked by extemporaneous singing in public spaces that transitioned to the minstrel and vaudeville stages. During this period, both Black and White barbershop quartets were a staple of vaudeville shows and could be heard on the radio, early recordings, and the concert stage. The second period began in the 1930s when the tradition saw a split into two sub-genres separated by race. As vaudeville disappeared, barbershop faded from the stage as well, though it continued as a community practice. The tropes and rhetoric surrounding American barbershop singing come directly from the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America (SPEBSQSA), which currently operates under the name Barbershop Harmony Society (BHS). Meanwhile, the African American community transformed the style into what would eventually be called doo-wop. Doo-wop gained crossover popularity throughout the 1940s and 1950s, but was classified by music industry executives, disc jockeys, and record stores as rhythm and blues along with a number of other popular Black idioms such as gospel, blues, jazz, and early rock and roll. SPEBSQSA took that time to develop its own definition of barbershop singing and implant it into the American consciousness through popular media. By asserting itself as the preserver of barbershop practice, SPEBSQSA has fabricated a singular history and style that is maintained through their contest and judging rules. However, barbershoppers still participate in a semi-extemporaneous activity called "tagging" that often expands a singer's understanding and experience of barbershop. Tagging is a social activity where at least four singers get together to sing the final measures, or the tags, of barbershop tunes. Tags are typically 4-16 measures of the end of a song and are nearly always taught by rote. Although the competition model is meant to showcase the now-canonized barbershop style, tagging exemplifies the values and lived experience of the early tradition's practitioners. This thesis examines how labels and preservation practices have changed the perception of the barbershop tradition. I apply Fatimah Tobing Rony's framework of "taxidermy" and Avery Gordon's theory of "haunting" to demonstrate the power of genre labels to reify biases and create new understanding. Using barbershop and doo-wop as a case study, I argue that the racial divisions built into American musical classifications continue to obscure the diverse history, sound, and practice of popular music styles.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Musicology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
barbershop, doo-wop, haunting, singing, taxidermy, United States
Denise Von Glahn, Professor Directing Thesis; Michael Buchler, Committee Member; Frank Gunderson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Incorporation of Œë-Tocopherol into Pea Protein Film
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Effect of Addition Method and pH-Shift Treatment

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The present study focuses on the optimization of vitamin E (Œ±-tocopherol) incorporation into pea protein films, with an emphasis on improving the film's properties and antioxidant capacity. Pea protein offers great potential as a natural emulsifier for delivering both nutritional and functional benefits. The study begins by investigating the modification of pea protein structure through pH-shifting treatment. This process enhances pea protein's emulsification ability, leading to the formation of stable emulsions with small particle sizes that remain stable over one week. Next, the study explores the influence of Œ±-tocopherol addition on protein film samples, both with and without pH-shifting treatment. Œ±-Tocopherol is added either directly or in the form of a nano-emulsion. The findings indicate that pH-shifting treatment improves the film's elongation-at-break compared to the control group. However, the direct addition of Œ±-tocopherol negatively impacts film structure, resulting in a rough and broken surface morphology. The surface becomes smoother after treating the protein dispersion with pH-shifting, leading to a more continuous structure. Nevertheless, the mechanical properties of the film are compromised in the presence of Œ±-tocopherol. To create film samples with excellent antioxidant properties without compromising film texture, Œ±-tocopherol is incorporated in the form of a nano-emulsion. When both the protein dispersion and nano-emulsion are treated with pH-shifting, the resulting film samples exhibit homogeneous, even, and smooth surface textures with tiny pores, as observed in SEM images. Importantly, the mechanical properties of the films are not sacrificed. These films exhibit a tensile strength of 1.52 MPa and an elongation ability of 190.77%. Furthermore, it is noted that the color and opacity of the protein films are significantly altered by different combinations of treatments. However, factors such as solubility, moisture content, and water vapor permeability are minimally influenced. The antioxidant ability of the films is assessed through DPPH inhibition and the duration of antioxidant release. Results show that the films with pH-shifting combined with nano-emulsion treatment exhibit nearly 96.7% free radical inhibition ability and consistent antioxidant release. In summary, the combination of pH-shifting treatment and nano-emulsion incorporation proves to be an effective method for integrating hydrophobic substances into an aqueous environment while minimizing negative effects on the mechanical properties of the film. This approach holds promise for the development of pea protein-based films with enhanced antioxidant properties for a wide range of potential applications in food packaging and preservation.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Active film, Antioxidant, Elongation at break, Emulsion, Pea Protein, pH-shifting
Leqi Cui, Professor Directing Thesis; Bahram Arjmandi, Committee Member; Qinchun Rao, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Real-Time Planning and Control of Dynamic Robots in Dynamic Environments

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Dynamic robots require robust controllers to successfully plan and navigate the unstructured world around us. Novel control methods become necessary when these robots' environments are dynamic and the robots themselves have fast and unstable dynamics that cannot be shaped arbitrarily by control ‚Äì e.g., hybrid dynamics (impacts) or underactuation. Legged robots and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are examples of such dynamic machines. This thesis argues that fast and reactive planning in dynamic environments is paramount for success when facing these challenges where control decisions must be made in milliseconds. To facilitate this goal, this work formulates new implementations of trajectory optimizations and force control as the primary tools for synthesizing legged and aerial locomotion that accommodates rapid environmental changes. As a demonstration of novel forms of dynamic planning and control, this thesis presents: 1) A bipedal robot balancing controller that remains stable in the face of unplanned contact changes (i.e.. soft, moving, orcompletely lost footholds). This feedback controller is advantageous when the dynamic model may be inaccurate, unknown, or changing, and is amenable to other robotic platforms with joint-level torque control, quickly moving limbs, and mechanical robustness to impacts. 2) A monopod motion controller that generates reactive motion plans in milliseconds by solving convex quadratic programs but does not use predefined footfall locations or contact timings. This method allows the system to hop, stand, or transition between the two as an emergent property when the robot's desired height and speed are changed. 3) A monopod motion planner that generates energy-efficient gaits in resistive fluid-like media. After modeling fluid forces on partially submerged legs as differentiable functions, gradient-based nonlinear optimizations were able to reduce computation times observed in prior work from minutes to seconds. 4) A real-time obstacle avoidance motion planner capable of avoiding multiple fast-moving obstacles both on UAV hardware and a simple bipedal locomotion model. The mathematical formulation requires few and easy-to-tune hyperparameters, allowing for straightforward implementation. Altogether, these contributions underscore how simple iteratively updated models, when coupled with fast-solving planning algorithms, yield robust and dynamic robot control.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Christian Hubicki, Professor Directing Thesis; Jonathan Clark, Committee Member; Brandon Krick, Committee Member; Rodney Roberts, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Woman's Worth
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Selling Sex and Virtue in Antebellum U.S. Melodrama

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The nineteenth-century "moral reform" melodrama joined reform newsletters to warn audiences about social evil. These melodramas necessarily depicted vices like drunkenness, slavery, vanity, and rage. In Spectacles of Reform, Amy Hughes shows that the portrayal of such vices became spectacle for some of the nineteenth-century theatre. However, while the theatre depicted many types of vice and moral crusades, one vice seldom appeared. Sex work commonly appeared in reformist short stories and novels but rarely on stage. In a form that thrived on spectacle, danger, and the purity of women who needed saving, why did the perils of the "fallen woman" appear so infrequently? In addition to the question about sex work, this dissertation explores the questions: How were women and virtue presented on the Boston stage? How did the reality of life for middle-class women compare with the ideal presented on stage? What was the reality of sex work compared to the staging? Did melodramatic representations of women and sex on the Boston stage align with more conservative or more reformist social pressures? Ultimately, this dissertation connects attitudes about sex work and virtue in antebellum Boston to its portrayal on stage and link antebellum melodrama and the prostitution plays of the Progressive Era. Using a feminist and sex positive lens and employing literary analysis and cultural history this dissertation investigates gender and the value of women in the antebellum United States.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Theatre in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Antebellum, Boston, Melodrama, Sex Work, Stage, Virtue
Elizabeth Osborne, Professor Directing Dissertation; Cathy McClive, University Representative; Aaron Thomas, Committee Member; Kris Salata, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Structure and Function Studies of a CRISPR CARF Ancillary Enzyme and Its Role in Signaling

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The landscape of RNA biology and its derived biotechnology is continually evolving, and one of the most groundbreaking has been the discovery and subsequent characterization of Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) systems. These systems serve as a defense mechanism in prokaryotes, safeguarding against viral infections by storing and utilizing genetic information to identify and eliminate invading viruses. Renowned for their diversity and adaptability, CRISPR systems have revolutionized genetic engineering in nearly all organisms, enabling precise genome editing and a wide array of biotechnological applications. Within the intricate machinery of CRISPR systems, the Type III CRISPR-Cas systems stand out as a particularly intriguing class, offering unique mechanisms for sensing and neutralizing viral RNA and DNA. These mechanisms include the viral RNA-activated synthesis of novel cyclic-oligonucleotide second messengers, called cyclic-oligoadenylate (cOA) molecules. These second messengers subsequently bind to and allosterically activate a diverse collection of Type III CRISPR ancillary proteins that have a CARF sensor domain, thereby potentiating a powerful immune response. These signaling events are crucial in triggering cellular dormancy or programmed cell death in response to viral infections, making them a central component of the host organism's adaptive immune response. While research has shed light on some aspects of how these downstream CARF effectors are activated by cOA second messengers, there are still many unanswered questions to be explored in addition to uncharacterized CARF effector proteins. Furthermore, the knowledge gained from understanding the cOA signaling system holds promise for harnessing its potential in the development of innovative biotechnological applications. This dissertation uses structural and biochemical studies to shed light on the intricate mechanisms of one member of the CARF effectors, a CARF-fused adenosine deaminase (CADA) in the context of Type III CRISPR Cas system function. Chapter 1 provides an overview of the discovery and characterization of cyclic-oligoadenylate signaling in type III CRISPR systems. Chapter 2 of this dissertation details the team's efforts in the structural and functional characterization of the type III CRISPR system from mesophilic Lactococcus lactis Csm (LlCsm) organism at multiple functional states. The knowledge gained from this investigation serves as the foundation for developing a virus detection technology, MORIARTY (Multipronged, One-pot, target RNA-Induced, Augmentable, Rapid, Test sYstem) as detailed in Chapter 3. MORIARTY utilizes both RNA- and transcription-activated dual nucleic acid cleavage activities, along with internal signal amplification from the cOA-mediated activation of the CARF-effector Csm6 associated with this system. This approach enables highly sensitive virus detection across various settings. Chapter 4 summarizes and compares the structures of three CRISPR enzymes used in nucleic acid detection captured in their respective functional forms and illustrates the current understanding of their activation mechanism. Finally, in Chapter 5, I successfully pioneered the study of the structure and function of a novel CRISPR-associated adenosine deaminase (CADA) from the thermophilic organism Thermoanaerobaculum aquatica (Taq). TaqCADA, a protein featuring a CARF domain fused to an adenosine deaminase domain, forms a homohexamer, where three canonical homodimers come together through their ADA domains. Each dimer includes a CARF domain and an ADA domain. TaqCADA exhibits robust cOA4 ring nuclease activity and, interestingly, shows only weak adenosine deaminase activity, which does not appear to be enhanced by the presence of cOA molecules. The initial characterization of TaqCADA suggests the ability to regulate cOA concentrations to attenuate immunity and possibly to sequester s-adenosyl-methionine (SAM), which is the cells' methyl donor. However, additional studies are required to address its precise roles in immunity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Hong Li, Professor Directing Dissertation; Margaret Elizabeth Stroupe, University Representative; Robert Silvers, Committee Member; Kenneth G. Hanson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Music-Centered Design
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Usability Testing of an Academic Library Web Scale Discovery Tool to Support Music Information Seeking

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Academic music libraries in the US collect resources to support music students and faculty in their performance and research needs. These resources include non-text items such as musical scores and recordings that are difficult to represent in standard library information systems that were built for text items. The advent of web scale discovery tools that combine libraries' entire physical and digital holdings into a central index has further complicated resource discoverability for music libraries and their patrons. While music librarians have shared the challenges that they face describing and organizing musical resources, it is not clear what strategies music students employ to search for musical resources using web scale discovery tools or the challenges that they face. To explore these issues, usability testing was conducted using the FSU Allen Music Library discovery system. Undergraduate music majors were tasked with searching for musical resources including scores, recordings, and music literature using the discovery layer. Behavioral and attitudinal data captured students' music information seeking behavior and the challenges that they experienced navigating discovery layers. Participants demonstrated an impressive ability to navigate the discovery interface and leverage domain knowledge to aid their searches. Simultaneously, they demonstrated a hastiness in examining bibliographic records that significantly impaired their ability to successfully locate musical resources, particularly music literature. Finally, aspects of the user interface including main access points, facet settings, and brief record displays served as barriers to music information seeking. These findings are used to suggest strategies that music librarians can adopt to optimize their discovery layers and adjust library instruction to better support their patrons' music information seeking.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Information in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
domain analysis, music information seeking, music libraries, usability testing, Web scale discovery tool
Paul F. Marty, Professor Directing Dissertation; Charles E. Brewer, University Representative; Marcia A. Mardis, Committee Member; Margaret Sullivan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigating the Causal Evidence of Integration between Cognitive Control Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Cognitive control is an imperative human function that allows one to behave in flexible manners when habit will not suffice. The neural mechanisms and interactions of the activated brain regions underlying cognitive control are not fully understood. Prior work has focused on the frontoparietal control network (FPCN) as the network responsible for executing the goal-oriented behaviors necessary for enacting control. Evidence shows that within the FPCN are three separable control subsystems, the temporal control (TC), contextual control (CC), and sensory-motor control (SC) systems. These systems are organized along a somatomotor-distal to somaotomotor-proximal axis and involved in future- to present-oriented behavior (Nee, 2021). Prior research using effective connectivity between these systems suggested that the CC system is responsible for integration within the FPCN, whereas the TC and SC systems remain segregated. Underscoring the importance of such integration, an index of integration was found to be predictive of broad cognitive ability (Nee, 2021). Based on the roles of the control demand systems, integration therefore may be a key characteristic of control to connect plans with action execution. To further test this model with measured brain signals, the current study used continuous theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation (cTBS) to causally contrast two regions within the TC system and a control site. Based on the TC system's segregative profile, we predicted that disrupting regions in the TC system would lead to increased integration amongst the control systems. Integration was assessed via functional connectivity of the functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) blood-oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) signal assessed immediately following cTBS. In contrast to our predictions, we did not find any statistically significant changes in functional connectivity when comparing cTBS targets. Further analyses probed the within- and between-network connectivity of large-scale networks related to cognitive control. These analyses also demonstrated no statistically significant evidence for changes caused by cTBS. These results and implications for the findings are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Derek E. Nee, Professor Directing Thesis; Caterina Gratton, Committee Member; Wen Li, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Veteran Suicide and the Ideation to Action Framework
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Critical Examination and in-Depth Analysis of Theory

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Suicide is a global health problem, and veterans are at a disproportionately higher risk for suicide than the general population. The theories commonly used in suicide need to be adequately examined and analyzed prior to the use of new methods of statistical analysis to answer the questions suicide researchers haven't been able to answer for over five decades. The purpose of this dissertation study was to do just that. Through nested iterations of multinomial logistic regression analysis, the results indicate that the Interpersonal Theory of Suicide, the Integrated Motivational-Volitional Model of Suicide, and the Three-Step Theory of Suicide can all significantly predict whether someone is thinking about suicide, at risk for attempting suicide, and if they can take their own life. However, results also show that not all the measures that operationalize the constructs of the theories are necessary in determining what level of suicide risk an individual is at. Surprisingly, the final model for the Interpersonal Theory of Suicide only had three significant predictors (SBQ, DSI, and Race; œá2= 1876.100 (40) with strong effect (Nagelkerke = .747)). The final model of the Integrated Motivational-Volitional Model of Suicide had four significant predictors (SBQ, DSI, SIS, and BSS; œá2= 2106.057 (24) with strong effect (Nagelkerke = .796)); The final model of the Three-Step Theory of Suicide had five significant predictors within the model (DSI, SBQ, SIS, and military branch; œá2= 2142.395 (24) with strong effect (Nagelkerke = .803)).These results indicate that not all measures are needed to predict suicide risk and specific measures should be focused on more heavily in suicide assessments. Future research about suicide needs to be able to adequately capture the complexity of the issue. This can include more specific conceptualizations of variables pertaining to the veteran population (i.e., deployment should be further defined to capture what someone did/was exposed to while deployed) and more advanced statistical methodologies.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Social Work in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Mental Health, Military, Social Work, Suicide, Theory, Veteran

Jeffrey R. Lacasse, Professor Directing Dissertation; Thomas E. Joiner, University Representative; Michael O. Killian, Committee Member; Shamra Boel-Studt, Committee Member; Yaacov Petscher, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rethinking Guilt Appeals in Environmental Messages
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Testing the Effects of Empathy-Eliciting and Shame-Free Guilt Appeals on Behavioral Intentions

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Guilt appeals are a widely used type of emotional appeals in social advocacy messages. However, studies have found inconsistent results regarding the effects of guilt intensity on influencing viewers' attitudes and behavioral intentions. Some found guilt-appeal intensity has a curvilinear relationship with post-message attitudinal and behavioral intention changes, whereas others found the relationship is linear or even neither linear nor curvilinear. Scholars pointed out that these inconsistencies might imply several crucial problems and challenges related to the manipulation of guilt in pervasive messages. The first problem might result from inadvertently eliciting reactive guilt instead of anticipated guilt via messages, which can lead to increased reactance among audiences. The second problem might result from inadvertently including shame-eliciting language in guilt appeal messages. Accordingly, it is recommended that messages designed to promote pro-environmental behavioral intentions should attempt to elicit anticipated guilt and avoid eliciting feelings of shame. This study tested effects of messages designed and found to elicit significantly more guilt than shame. Messages that elicit empathy might be effective in eliciting anticipated guilt and promoting behavioral changes. Additionally, narrative messages might elicit greater empathy than non-narrative messages. Therefore, using an online experiment that employed a 2 (message feature: narrative vs. non-narrative stories) x 4 (animal type: more similar vs. less similar to humans) between-subjects design, the first study investigated the causal association between empathy, anticipated guilt, and pro-environmental intentions. Results demonstrated that narrative stories featuring an animal or insect harmed by climate change elicited greater feelings of anger and sadness than viewing non-narrative stories, which led to heightened feelings of empathy among audience members. Results also showed that empathy was positively associated with anticipated guilt. Anticipated guilt was positively associated with pro-environmental behavioral intentions. Finally, anticipated guilt mediated the association between feelings of empathy and pro-environmental behavioral intentions. Scholars also suggested that the magnitude of the request in persuasive messages might influence viewers' self-efficacy, and self-efficacy might be a potential predictor in generating more effective responses to guilt appeals. Based on the proposition of the extended parallel process model (EPPM), including high self-efficacy instead of low self-efficacy components in emotional-appeal messages can promote recipients' behavioral intentions and help reduce defensive motivation such as psychological reactance to the messages. Reducing viewers' reactance to the message is important because psychological reactance theory (PRT) states that eliciting reactance among audiences can lead to ineffective persuasive messages. Using EPPM and PRT as theoretical foundations, the second study manipulated 2 levels of magnitude of the request (lower vs. higher) x 4 (animal type: more similar vs. less similar to humans) with a between-subjects design to examine the effects of shame-free guilt messages on self-efficacy, reactance to the messages, anticipated guilt, and pro-environmental intentions. Results demonstrated that viewing a shame-free guilt message with a lower magnitude of the request generated greater levels of self-efficacy compared to viewing the same message but with a higher magnitude of the request. Results from the mediation model found that self-efficacy was negatively associated with audiences' perceived threat to freedom. Perceived threat to freedom was positively associated with psychological reactance. Results revealed some evidence that psychological reactance was negatively associated with anticipated guilt. Finally, anticipated guilt was found to be positively associated with pro-environmental behavioral intentions. Results from both studies provided further insights into designing effective guilt appeals in climate change mitigation messages. The theoretical and practical implications are discussed, as well as suggestions for future research.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Laura M. Arpan, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Russell B. Clayton, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Rachel L. Bailey, Committee Member; Juliann Cortese, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Prompting Self-Explanation during or after Playing Educational Games

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study employed a pretest-posttest control group experimental design to investigate the impact of self-explanation prompts on content learning in the game-based context. Additionally, it explored the effectiveness of different delivery timings for the prompts‚Äîeither during or after gameplay‚Äîin enhancing students' cognitive engagement in self-explanation and content learning. The physics educational game "Save Kitten" was developed using Articulate Storyline 360¬Æ, incorporating in-game textual self-explanation prompts that asked students to explain their game solutions based on targeted physics knowledge. Students voluntarily responded to these prompts by drawing force diagrams on a handout. The participants consisted of 92 10th-grade students from a large public high school in southern China, who were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: control (playing the game without prompts), during (playing the game with prompts delivered between game levels), and after (playing the game with prompts delivered after completing gameplay). Quantitative data were collected through a demographic questionnaire, pretest and posttest assessments of physics knowledge, and a handout for written self-explanation. Descriptive analysis, correlation analysis, multiple regression, Chi-squared test, independent Mann-Whitney U test, paired-sample t-test, one-way ANOVA, and one-way ANCOVA were performed using SPSS version 25.0 to analyze the quantitative data. Qualitative data collected through in-field observations and informal student interviews were thematically analyzed manually. The quantitative findings revealed that students who played the game with self-explanation prompts, either during or after gameplay, achieved significantly higher scores in the posttest compared to those without prompts after controlling for pretest scores. Moreover, students demonstrated better learning outcomes when more engaged in self-explanation. There was no significant difference in self-explanation engagement between students who received the prompts at different timings. However, during-gameplay prompts for self-explanation proved more effective than prompts delivered after gameplay in enhancing students' content learning through gameplay. Qualitative findings indicated that students displayed a strong level of involvement and interest in gameplay, compared to physics learning, and a collective focus on game achievement. Some students who were not prompted demonstrated spontaneous self-explanation, while others who received prompts did not engage in self-explanation as anticipated. Recognizing the instrumental value of self-explanation could encourage students to engage with the prompts, whether in written form or mentally. This study provides empirical evidence supporting prompting self-explanation when students play educational games and offers insights into effective strategies for designing and implementing the self-explanation prompts in game-based learning contexts.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Geographic Information System-Based Hazard Analysis of Evacuation Accessibility for Hurricane Shelters

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In the present era marked by an increasing frequency of extreme climatic events, the vulnerability of human life has become a subject of paramount concern. The research endeavors undertaken within this dissertation aim to shed light on this critical issue by delving into the most prevalent natural hazard in Florida, namely hurricanes. The catastrophic Category 5 Hurricane Michael, an unprecedented occurrence in the Florida Panhandle region in 2018, serves as a poignant case study. To begin with, the inquiry commences with the simulation of impacts on evacuation congestion considering the inherent uncertainties associated with hurricane tracks. This dissertation unfolds across three main facets of analysis. Initially, three distinct scenarios were generated for the highly populous northern regions of Florida, which were also deemed particularly susceptible to the impact of Hurricane Michael based on initial forecasting datasets. The purpose of this section was to elucidate the ramifications of hurricane track uncertainty on roadway congestion and the exigencies of timely evacuation. This investigation was contributed the next part, which was specifically focused on Panama City, one of the most populous urban areas featured in the aforementioned scenarios. The research tried to discern the vulnerability of the special-needs population during the actual occurrence of Hurricane Michael in 2018. With only one Special-Needs Shelter (SpNS) available in the county, Panama City, characterized by a substantial aging population, grappled with the challenge of ensuring optimal evacuation accessibility for its residents in the face of an impending and formidable hurricane. The storm surge simulation provided a precondition to further geographic information system (GIS) models of roadway network analysis. Shelter repurposing solutions highlighted that the temporary conversion of up to three shelters into SpNS could significantly reduce travel times for the coastal special-needs population, enhancing evacuation accessibility by 20%. Additionally, with climate change consideration, this dissertation focuses on the implications of sea level rise (SLR) on hurricane evacuation accessibility reduction in the Florida Panhandle eastern region. Utilizing the floating catchment area (FCA) method in GIS, various scenarios of different SLR assumptions in conjunction with hurricane simulations were examined to gauge alterations in the region's accessibility index. Findings revealed that the vast rural expansion in the selected research counties was characterized by low accessibility of most of the involved census block groups, primarily due to the lack of nearby emergency facility sources such as shelters catering to coastal residents. Moreover, the storm-evacuation integrated model with FCA applications demonstrated that census block groups closer to shelters experienced an elevated accessibility index due to inequality of facility sharing, as another population residing close to inundation was isolated by storm surges, rendering them unable to access shelter facilities. Paradoxically, this situation placed those coastal residents at a heightened risk of flooding, further accentuating their predicament since a strong hurricane might attack them at first. Another preliminary investigation of marsh plantation impacts on wave reduction and roadway accessibility during hurricanes was generated in this part, employing a steady-state spectral wave (STWAVE) model to the SLR-based hurricane scenarios. According to relative bottom friction parameters, it becomes evident that local roadways had the high possibility of being susceptible to flooding in areas with either thin layers of salt marsh or extremely high storm surge, thereby posing a significant threat to evacuees traveling to inner land regions. This reduced evacuation accessibility beyond the residents' original counties. The investigation furnishes a comprehensive analysis of the vulnerabilities confronting coastal populations of strong hurricanes. To summarize, this dissertation provides a significant analysis of the insufficient accessibility of Northwest Florida evacuation during extreme hurricanes with GIS applications, effectively integrated storm surge models and evacuation calculations by providing more efficient hurricane prediction planning. Its knowledge contributes to a comprehensive understanding of the vulnerabilities inherent in hurricane-prone regions, highlighting hurricane evacuation challenges for special-needs populations as well as northwest rural areas in Florida, helping shape more effective disaster mitigation and response strategies.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Studies of Magneto-Structural Correlations in Spin-Crossover Complexes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Spin-crossover (SCO) is one of the most recognized spin-state switching phenomena as an example of molecular bistability. The ability to convert between high spin and low spin electronic configurations in a transition metal center under various external stimuli makes such compounds useful in the preparation of molecular memory devices, sensors, and switches. The phenomenon has been widely studied in six-coordinate first-row transition metal ions with electronic configurations 3d4-3d7 under an intermediate ligand field strength. This thesis explores the design of several new systems to induce SCO in Fe(II) complexes. The general SCO phenomenon and typical materials are overviewed in Chapter 1, and the general experimental methods used in this work are presented briefly in Chapter 2. Chapter 3 describes the design and characterization of Fe(II) homoleptic complexes containing ligands with mixed N,S- coordination. Such ligands are rarely used for the synthesis of SCO compounds, as compared to the widely studied SCO complexes with the N6 coordination environment. Mononuclear N4S2-coordinated SCO complexes with abrupt and hysteretic spin transitions and crystallographic symmetry-breaking were characterized by single crystal and synchrotron powder X-Ray diffraction, magnetic susceptibility measurements, M√∂ssbauer spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and optical spectroscopy to arrive at understanding of magneto-structural correlations and the interplay between the SCO behavior and symmetry-breaking. Chapters 4 and 5 describes the synthesis of new 2,2'-biimidazole type ligands that were N-alkylated at the protonated nitrogens with naphthalene, anthracene, and biphenyl-quinoxaline fragments and then used in the synthesis of Fe(II) SCO complexes. The difference in the structure-property relationship of the heteroleptic Fe(II) complexes has yielded distinct magnetic behaviors with different degrees of spin-transition abruptness and different temperatures at which the spin transition takes place. Lastly, Chapter 6 describes the design of Fe(II) complexes with non-innocent ligands. The initial results are encouraging, as we are able to switch the spin state of the Fe(II) center via reduction of non-innocent ligands in homoleptic complexes. Based on these initial findings, we offer synthetic recommendations that are derived from structural studies of extremely air- and moisture-sensitive homoleptic Fe(II) complexes with non-innocent ligands and Fe(II) complexes with non-innocent ligands combined with anions capable of electron-donation. Chapter 7 provides conclusions and general outlook at future research opportunities based on the results obtained in this thesis.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: In-Situ Direct Magnetic Loss Measurement in Power Converters

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Accurate measurement of magnetic loss in power converters is a critical task for optimizing their performance. However, timing skew between measurement channels can lead to an unacceptable error in power loss measurements, and its quantification has historically posed a significant challenge to precise in-situ magnetic loss measurement. This thesis addresses this issue by introducing mathematical models and innovative measurement methods. The mathematical model is first established to analyze the influence of timing skew on magnetic loss measurements in a DC-DC converter. The first method, called Intersection method, disentangles the relationship between timing skew and magnetic loss in a DC-DC converter using a mathematical model. Building upon this, the second method, called Dual-curve Derivative method, enhances measurement accuracy and repeatability. The mathematical model in improved considering the loss mechanism of the magnetic component and an improved method, named Triple-curve Derivative method, is then developed to significantly improves magnetic loss measurement accuracy and in-situ measurement capabilities, specifically for lossier magnetic components. Experimental validation and a comprehensive comparative analysis of these three methods are conducted to corroborate the theoretical analysis. Prior methods necessitated a dedicated space on the PCB, resulting in heightened intrusiveness, with capacitance values reaching several nanofarads, which regrettably had adverse effects on the overall circuit's operation. An improved Dual-curve Derivative method is then developed, which not only enhances measurement accuracy but also significantly reduces its impact on the power converter. The operational principles and performance of the improved Dual-curve Derivative method are verified in simulation and validated in experiments in a DC-DC step-down buck converter, subject to various realistic circuit parameters. This method is validated through simulations and experiments under various circuit parameters. The variations in actual timing skew and real inductor loss are minimal, resulting in an overall error in the obtained inductor loss within ¬±4%. This underscores the utility of the proposed Improved Dual-curve Derivative method as a realistic, practical, accurate, and efficient tool for achieving direct in-situ magnetic loss measurement. Furthermore, this method has been extended to facilitate core loss measurement, enabling the precise separation of core and winding losses from the aggregated magnetic loss in direct measurement experimentally. In addition to the loss measurement methodology, this thesis delves into the study of high-bandwidth current shunts. This exploration is motivated by the advancements in Wide Bandgap (WBG) devices, which demand accurate current measurements at high-frequency applications, essential for both direct loss measurement and component characterization. The proposed high-bandwidth current shunts are meticulously constructed using thin-film resistors and innovative PCB layout designs. These resistors are arranged in a coaxial structure to enhance magnetic field cancellation and minimize parasitic inductance. With the introduction of a novel interleaving PCB layout design, the parasitic inductance of the shunt is further reduced, resulting in a higher measurement bandwidth. To validate the performance of these shunt prototypes, they were built and measured using a 2-port network analyzer. The results indicate an impressive 3-dB bandwidth exceeding 2GHz with a resistance of 100mŒ©. This achievement presents an appealing solution for current measurements in the gigahertz frequency range. In summary, this research contributes innovative methods for magnetic loss measurement, core loss separation, and high-bandwidth current measurement, offering practical solutions for power converter optimization and design validation.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Towards a Cure for Diabetes Mellitus
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Regenerating Human Pancreatic Beta Cells

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The pancreas is an organ located in the abdomen. It is made up of exocrine cells and endocrine cells. In particular, the endocrine cells include hormone-producing cells that form clusters within the pancreas, called islets of Langerhans. There are five major types of endocrine cells, namely alpha, beta, gamma, pancreatic polypeptide (PP), and epsilon cells. These cells regulate blood glucose levels by releasing hormones into the bloodstream. Among them, beta cells play the most important role in maintaining glucose levels by producing insulin. Insulin helps lower blood sugar levels by promoting the absorption of glucose from the blood to peripheral tissue, such as skeletal muscle, fat, and liver. When the autoimmune system attacks beta cells, it results in type 1 diabetes due to insufficient insulin production. On the other hand, type 2 diabetes results from peripheral tissue that poorly responds to insulin or uptakes less glucose due to insulin resistance. The two major types of diabetes have different causes, but they both result in a significant loss of beta cells. Here, we will discuss the characteristics of beta cells and suggest potential targets and strategies to regenerate them. Chapter 1 provides an overview of pancreatic beta cells, including their general properties, stressors, and biological processes that lead to generate new beta cells. Chapter 2 focuses on NEUROG3+ cells, which were previously considered pancreatic endocrine progenitors during development. We identified these cells in the postnatal human pancreas and discovered their unique genetic signatures and regulatory networks. Chapter 3 investigates the sex differences in the pancreas using single-cell resolution technologies. We found that female endocrine cells have higher secretion capacities than male endocrine cells. Additionally, endocrine cells in male controls exhibited molecular signatures resembling type 2 diabetes. Chapter 4 outlines our CRISPR/Cas9 genetic candidate screen pipeline to investigate beta cell proliferation and presents promising molecular targets. By inhibiting these targets, we found that beta cell proliferation can be promoted. We also assessed how transcriptional changes under knock-out of these promising target genes affect endocrine function and proliferation. Together, this work provides new insights into beta cell regeneration and its molecular characteristics. We believe this will accelerate the development of beta cell regeneration therapies to treat diabetes.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Concurrent Model and Data Based Resilient Control and Estimation for Cyber-Physical Systems

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Modern CPS are constructed by seamlessly integrating physical devices, computer systems, and communication networks, enabling data exchange and control of physical processes. The networked and distributed integration of computer systems and physical devices provides numerous benefits, such as improved efficiency, reduced costs, and increased safety. However, the closed-loop interaction between the cyber and physical layers introduces an expanded vulnerability landscape with the potential for catastrophic consequences. While substantial progress has been made in vulnerability analysis, anomaly detection, and resilient control and estimation, a unified theory that encompasses these critical multidisciplinary techniques is notably absent. This gap results from the inherent disparity between cyber-centric models and physics-based models used to describe the physical world. This deficiency hinders essential advancements in CPS security. For instance, physics-driven resilient estimation designs are constrained by the requirement that over half of the sensors should be attack-free, while anomaly detection and isolation approaches demand extensive redundancy in sensor deployment and suffer from generalization challenges. Consequently, this dissertation introduces a novel CM-REC framework, which quantitatively explores the synergy between data-driven models and physics-based models to achieve enhanced security. The approach overcomes fundamental physical limitations and generalization issues of learning approaches. The CM-REC framework comprises a concurrent learning attack generator, a pruning algorithm, and a resilient estimator. The concurrent learning attack generator delves into the CPS vulnerability space based on runtime data, generating feasible attack datasets. These generative adversarial data then train the attack detector. To compensate for FP uncertainty in data-driven classifiers, where the attacked nodes may be erroneously labeled as safe, a pruning algorithm is developed to provide analytical guarantees for overall precision improvements. To utilize the detection outcomes, a weighted resilient estimation scheme is proposed, allowing critical operations to persist even when more than 50% of sensors are compromised.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Concurrent Learning, Cyber-Physical Systems, Cybersecurity, Data-driven Models, First-Principle Models, Resilient Estimation

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Scalable Clustering
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Large Scale Unsupervised Learning of Gaussian Mixture Models with Outliers

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Clustering is a widely used technique with a long and rich history in a variety of areas. However, most existing algorithms do not scale well to large datasets, or are missing theoretical guarantees of convergence. In this dissertation, we develop a provably clustering algorithm namely Scalable Clustering by Robust Loss Minimization (SCRLM) that performs well on Gaussian Mixture Models with outliers. We derive theoretical guarantees that SCRLM obtains high accuracy with high probability under certain assumption. Moreover, it can also be used as an initialization strategy for k-means clustering. Experiments on real-world large-scale datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of SCRLM when clustering a large number of clusters, and a k-means algorithm initialized by SCRLM outperforms most classic clustering methods in both speed and accuracy, while scaling well to large datasets such as ImageNet. We further extend SCRLM to Hierarchical SCRLM (HSCRLM) to handle hierarchical structures while maintaining robustness and theoretical guarantees. These advancements contribute to addressing modern clustering challenges.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
